talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2001 contains amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 arising from the government supported electoral reform recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report entitled The 1998 federal election. The government response to the report was tabled on 1 March 2001. The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act (No. 1) 2001, containing the technical amendments arising from the committee's report on the 1998 federal election, received royal assent on the 28 April 2001 and was proclaimed on 16 July 2001.
The most notable amendments of this bill include those which will:

Â· provide for the close of the rolls for an election or referendum for new enrolments at 6 p.m. on the day of the issue of the writ and, for existing electors wishing to update their enrolment, at 8 p.m. three working days after the issue of the writ;
Â· remove the right to vote for all prisoners serving a sentence of full-time detention;
Â· amend the multiple voting offence to provide an increased penalty where it can be demonstrated that the offence was committed deliberately;
Â· increase a number of the financial disclosure thresholds to $3,000, effective from 1 July 2001;

Â· amend the objection provisions to provide that electors may be removed from the roll by objection if they no longer reside at their enrolled address and have not lived there for at least the last month, rather than the requirement that the objection be based on non-residence in the subdivision for the last month;

Â· provide that an elector's provisional vote will not be admitted to scrutiny if an electionâexcluding the election to which the scrutiny relatesâhas been held since the removal of the elector from the roll or if there has been a redistribution of the state or territory that includes the division since the last election;

Â· provide that there will be no automatic reinstatement to the roll for electors whose provisional votes have been admitted to the count. Instead, electors will be required to complete an enrolment form to be placed back on the roll; and
Â· prohibit scrutineers from actively participating in assisted votes.

The government believes these reforms are important. They improve the integrity of the electoral process and I would urge that the bill be given timely passage. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Horne) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI present the report of the Committee of Privileges concerning the alleged threat or intimidation of a potential witness in connection with an inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThis matter, referred by the House in October 2000, relates to allegations of threat and intimidation of a potential witness, Mr Peter Osborne, to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs during its inquiry into health information management and telemedicine in 1997. The allegation is, in essence, that an officer of the Victorian Department of Human Services, Mr Osborne's supervisor at the time, threatened that Mr Osborne's employment might be terminated if he gave evidence as a private citizen at a public hearing conducted by the family and community affairs committee in April 1997. Mr Osborne alleged that the supervisor was instructed to make the threats by another senior officer of that department.

speech.para: The committee received written submissions and held an in camera hearing to seek to clarify the circumstances surrounding the allegation. The committee was faced with a volume of complex and contradictory evidence. In addition, the committee's task was made more difficult by the delay between the time the threats were alleged to have been made and the time Mr Osborne raised the matter with the family and community affairs committee. Some witnesses before the committee were understandably unable to recollect all relevant matters with great clarity or in great detail.

It appears from the evidence that the communication between Mr Osborne and his supervisor was at cross-purposes. While Mr Osborne is adamant that he proposed to give evidence in a personal capacity, or as a director of his company, but not on behalf of the department, his supervisor is equally adamant that Mr Osborne proposed to her that he give evidence as a representative of the Department of Human Services. Mr Osborne's supervisor saw the issue as a matter of protocol, as did the other senior officer in the department who is alleged to have given the instruction for the threats to be made. By contrast, Mr Osborne saw it as a matter of being denied his right to accept an invitation to appear before a parliamentary committee as a private citizen.

The picture was complicated by Mr Osborne's different and sometimes simultaneous roles as a contractual employee of the Department of Human Services, a managing director of his own company and his part in a contractual relationship with a major accounting firm. In addition, the committee notes that departments have protocols as to the levels of officers who may give evidence to parliamentary committees and that this is a reasonable and proper means to ensure that committees receive evidence from those with the adequate capacity and authority to provide it.

The committee concludes that, in her discussions with Mr Osborne regarding his proposed appearance before the family and community affairs committee, Mr Osborne's supervisor's conduct amounted to an interference with the free exercise of the family and community affairs committee's authority and functions in that a potential witness was deterred from giving evidence. The committee concludes that the conduct of the other senior officer in the department also amounted to an interference with the free exercise of the family and community affairs committee's authority and functions in that he contributed to a potential witness being deterred from giving evidence.

However, the committee does not find that the conduct of either officer amounted to an improper interference with the family and community affairs committee's authority and functions, as section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act requires before a finding of contempt could be contemplated. The committee is not satisfied that either officer was conscious that Mr Osborne wished to appear in a capacity other than a departmental representative or that either of them intended to deter Mr Osborne from giving evidence in any capacity other than as a representative of the Department of Human Services.

The committee wishes to record its concern that a witness before a parliamentary committee has been subject to threatsâalbeit as the apparent result of confusionâand confirms its earlier statements regarding the importance of witnesses being able to give evidence freely to parliamentary committees. Interference with witnesses or potential witnesses has a grave potential to diminish the quality and range of evidence that is provided to parliamentary committees. The committee will deal seriously with any matters that are referred to it following allegations of interference with witnesses or prospective witnesses before committees.

The committee recommends that all governments ensure that managers and staff of their departments and agencies are advised of the rights and responsibilities of witnesses before parliamentary committees. In particular, departments and authorities should ensure that the advice, and procedures to implement that advice, take careful note of the distinction between staff appearing as representatives of the department or authority and appearing in a private capacity.

debateinfo.title: FUEL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (GRANT AND REBATE SCHEMES) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise this morning to address the House on the Fuel Legislation Amendment (Grant and Rebate Schemes) Bill 2001. The bill will extend the sunset provisions of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme and the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme for 12 months to 30 June 2003. The Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme provides a rebate for the excise or customs duty which has been paid on locally produced or imported diesel and on fuels for certain eligible business activities such as mining, primary production, marine and rail transport, hospitals and nursing homes. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme provides a rebate for the on-road use of diesel and alternative fuels in vehicles over 20 tonnes and in vehicles of between 4.5 and 20 tonnes in non-metropolitan areas. There are amendments to the scheme which allow for a grant to be payable on all fuel used in an emergency vehicle weighing 4.5 tonnes or more. I indicate at the outset that the opposition supports the bill, in some ways reluctantly. We support the bill reluctantly not because of its intent but because, if we had a competent, honest and efficient government, there would be no need for the House to consider it.

speech.para: With the extension of these schemes, the government are acknowledging that they have not done what they promised over the last two years. I remind the House that the government did the deal with the Democrats to sunset these provisions on 30 June 2002 on the promise that the new energy credit scheme would be ready to replace it. Unfortunately the energy credit scheme is not ready because the work has not been doneâ despite the fact that the opposition over an extended period has been calling on the government to get the work done. Also, representatives of the trucking industry at a peak council level have been pushing for outstanding answers to questions going to the development of the alternative energy credit scheme.

We are here this morning because that work has not been done and, unfortunately, it is highly unlikely now that the work could be done by June of next year. It has been opposition policy to extend the sunset date if the government cannot give the Australian community and, importantly, the trucking industry an assurance that the new energy credit scheme would be ready in time for the sunset provision. That is exceptionally important because it goes to the capacity of the industry to plan for its future in the context of a certain environment and the promise that it would be in place for the purposes of the operation of that industry.

The bill before us today is the answer to our question. Unfortunately, the answer is that, no, the work has not and could not be done in accordance with the originally intended sunset provision date of 1 June 2002. I say to the Australian community that the answer is, `We, the Howard-Costello-Anderson government, with all the resources available to us, have not done the work we promised to do two years ago.' When the government introduced this scheme two years ago they effectively said in a very bald statement to the Australian community, `Over the ensuing period, with a sunset provision of 1 June 2002, we promise to do the work and actually have a new energy credit scheme in place.' So, with this admission of a broken promise and incompetence, the Howard-Costello government have conceded that they will not have the energy credit scheme ready to operate as promised in the negotiation of that grubby little GST package. Therefore, it is fair to say to the House that what is actually being implemented today is the opposition's policy with respect to how to get the Australian community out of this mess.

This is not the first example of the Howard government having to adopt opposition proposals to clean up a mess they have created in recent times. More importantly, it is the second example in just one week where the opposition has been ahead of the government on transport policy. I refer in passing to the decision of the government this week to postpone the sale of Kingsford Smith airport. Again, this was an example where the Howard-Costello government, due to the lacklustre performance of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, did not have their ears to the ground and were therefore forced to put off the sale of Kingsford Smith airport rather than proceed with a fire sale, due to the international experience in the aviation industry and the collapse of Ansett, with a view to guaranteeing Australian taxpayers the best possible return on the sale of that wonderful asset. I suppose it proves to the Australian community that not only is the Howard government tricky and mean, it is also out of touch with economic reality and the needs and expectations of the Australian community for accountability and responsibility in government.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Batman is aware that he has been granted some tolerance on this, and it would be good if he came back to the bill.
âAs I have indicated, it is a wide-ranging bill. And I might indicate that fuel is used in the operation of the aviation industry at Sydney airport.
âThe member for Batman nonetheless understands it was a long bow. It would be helpful if he came back to the bill.
âI thought it was not a bad bow myself, Mr Speaker.
âIt is not the chair's job to judge the validity of the argument, but simply that it be focused on the bill.

âI think it is understood that we are debating very serious issues today, and I am going to accountability and performance in government. What is at the heart of the legislation is not only the extension of the scheme but the reason we have to debate this proposal today. That is because the government has been content to stand by and gloss over mistakes for as long as it can until it is forced to admit them, and then unashamedly shoot the bill to the taxpayer and the Australian community. We cannot avoid parliamentary accountability. We cannot avoid a requirement that the government of the day be attentive, responsible and competent with respect to its handling of a major industry such as the transport industry, which has huge ramifications not only nationally but also in rural, remote and regional Australia. For that reason, I say very clearly that the government today is implementing the opposition's policy.

speech.para: The government also need to answer very serious questions today about why they dragged their feet for so long. They must say why they broke their promise and why they have not issued one discussion paper, options paper or notice about the form of the energy credit scheme, which they promised would be ready by June 2002. I remind the House it was not the opposition's promise. It was the Howard government's promise, when they entered into an arrangement with the Democrats as part of a deal to introduce the GST, that they would implement and develop a new energy credit scheme in time for the sunset provision of 1 June 2002. That is at the heart of the bill before the House today.

It is exceptionally important that the Australian community is reminded that when you accept ministerial responsibilities you undertake to the community to actually do your job. You do not sit idly by, draw a ministerial salary and fail to live up to your responsibilities to do your work and meet the legislative requirements that you undertook to this House to meet when you put in place legislation for the operation of the fuel and energy credit schemes. That is what it is all about. If you make a promise to the Australian community, with more than adequate time to deliver, then the Australian community actually expects that you deliver. That is how you operate in private business, that is how you operate in the community sector in Australia and that is how you should operate in government, especially at the highest level of government in Australia. It is about accountability, integrity and honesty in government.

That is why I also suggest that not only are the government on the spot today, but so are the Democrats, the party that entered into the arrangements with the government with respect to the development of the energy credit scheme. Questions therefore need to be answered by the Democrats in the debate on this bill in the other house as to why they have sat idly by and refused to pressure the government about the emerging sunset provision of 1 June 2002 and why they did not think it was their responsibility, having entered into the agreement, to hold the government accountable to do the work to enable the energy credit scheme to be put in place. I argue that the shoddy performance of both the Howard government and the Democrats is the reason we have to debate this issue today. The failure of both political parties to do their work effectively means that the time of this House today is wasted. If the work had been done there would be no requirement for us to spend time debating this bill.

In essence, we are debating not a change in assistance to industry but a 12-month extension of time to enable the government to do its work, having already had two years to do the work that was expected by the transport industry and the Australian community. The Democrats must therefore explain, as must the Howard government, why they have not honoured the agreement they reached with the government. The Democrats got the promise from the Howard-Costello government about the introduction of the scheme, but the truth of the matter is that, in the same way in which the Howard government has failed to do its work, the Democrats have done nothing to make the Howard government do its work under the agreement that it entered into. In essence, it is another example of the Democrats doing a quick deal on the run for a quick headline, not following it through and leaving the industry worried and uncertain about its future. I suppose that we should not expect anything other than that from the Democrats from time to time. They are always about a cheap headline and a smart alec amendment rather than hard work and dedicated follow-through to make sure that agreements that are entered into are fully delivered in accordance with the legislative intention of the House with respect to this bill.

The new energy credits scheme that is supposed to replace the current diesel grants scheme can still be finalised by June 2002. That is a very good thing, because that is what the House was told would occur when the scheme was first introduced for debate. But I firmly believe that the bill represents a very clear statementâa concessionâby the Howard government that it is unlikely that the hard work expected can be completed. The opposition was virtually convinced of that when the government said that the fuel tax inquiry would not report until March and that the inquiry would look at the energy credits scheme. That was another excuse and another cover-up for not doing its workâ rolling the development of the energy credits scheme into the fuel tax inquiry as a cover for not doing its work.

In effect, therefore, the government has ratted on the GST deal with the Australian community with respect to the diesel grants scheme. The commitment therefore that it gave under the A New Tax SystemâMeasures for a Better Environment deal that supposedly was entered into with the Democrats, on the basis of which the GST was introduced, has been torn up and thrown away. In essence, the Democrats have been sold a pup yet again for a cheap headline because they were also unwilling to hold the government to account with respect to the deal on the development of environmentally friendly operations, which the trucking industry and I regard as important.

I compliment those who operate in the trucking industry, because they are not opposed to the development of an energy credits scheme. On a regular basis they say, `All we need is for the government to do its work. We are prepared to front up to our responsibilities as an industry, because we are a community minded industry. In the same way in which we pursue safety on the road, we want to pursue environmentally friendly work practices. But in order to achieve that, we expect the government, which is largely responsible for the development of those environmentally friendly practices, to do its work so that we know that we have an environment in which we are expected to operate for the purposes of delivering not only an efficient and affordable industry but also an environmentally friendly industry to the Australian community, in accord with our domestic responsibilities to improve our performance in the environment and with our responsibilities with respect to the greenhouse debate.'

The problem is that the Howard government wanted only one thing of the Democrats, and that was their vote on the GSTâ the tax and the policy that have seriously eroded the living standards of Australian workers in recent times and that yesterday accounted for the loss of 1,000 jobs in Coles Myer and 1,000 jobs in Daimaru. More important, that tax and that policy, with the Ansett debacle and the international aviation crisis that we are experiencing, are now contributing to the potential loss of thousands of jobs in the tourism industry around Australia. In essence, the Howard government got its tax because it got the Democrats' vote, but the truth of the matter is that, when it comes to the energy credits scheme and an alternative to the diesel grants and rebates scheme, the Australian community did not get its side of the deal. When it came to the implementation of that arrangement, the Australian public was played for a break yet again. Why should we expect anything other than that? If you are not played for a break, you are given an undertaking that it will never, ever be done. On both counts we know that the Howard government's word is not worth a pinch of salt, because it will break its word according to the political circumstances that suit its own needs at a given time.

This debate is not only about the A New Tax SystemâMeasures for a Better Environment deal, which has fallen apart. It is also about restrictions on the importation of second-hand diesel engines, which is another example of the Howard government's not doing its job with respect to the need to improve our environment. Labor, I remind the House, did not oppose the diesel grants scheme when it was introduced, because it constituted a way to help the transport and primary production industries to mitigate the impact of the GST, and we will not oppose this bill for that very reason. As well as explaining its inaction, the reason for the extension required in this bill, the government must also start to give some idea of where it wants to go in the energy credits debate. The time extension will rightly take pressure off finalisation of the scheme and give certainty to the industry. The government's fuel tax inquiry may give some clues to what might be in the energy credits scheme, but we have not had from the government the slightest clue to what might be in the energy credits scheme. I say that against the backdrop in which the government has had two years. Surely two years down the track it can tell the House, the transport industry and the Australian community what clue it has about a possible energy credits scheme. With all the resources of ministerial officers and all the departmental backup it gets, surely two years down the track we can be given some clue in this debate today about the government's thinking with respect to an energy credits scheme and the replacement of the fuel grants and rebate scheme.

I think I can shed some light today on why there has been inaction and why there have been no proposals on an energy credit scheme. I recently came across a document that sheds some light on this issue. That document is a departmental briefing from Environment Australia prepared for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Dr Sharman Stone, for her attendance and presentation at the Australian Trucking Association Diesel Emissions Seminar, which I addressed earlier this year. I want to refer the House to that briefing document because the department apprised the parliamentary secretary, as she was to speak at the seminar, of the views of the Australian Trucking Association on a range of matters. Of most note is the update on the energy credit scheme. I will quote from the document because it might help the public and the trucking industry to understand why the Fuel Legislation Amendment (Grant and Rebate Schemes) Bill 2001 is before us today and why there has been no action from the government yet again.
The document, minute 1/90, is entitled `Presentation to ATA meeting of 8 March'. Page 2 of that document says this in respect of an energy credit scheme:

quote.para: The Department of Transport and Regional Services, in consultation with Environment Australia and the Greenhouse Office, is preparing a Cabinet memorandum on this proposal.

speech.para: From that quotation from the government's own brief we can now confirm that it is the Deputy Prime Minister, who is also Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who has primary responsibility for developing the energy credit scheme. From the experience of the Ansett debacle, we know that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has a lot of trouble making even the simplest decisions. However, the decision to extend the energy credit scheme is extremely important to people who rely on certainty and who have already been whacked and smacked by the government's GST policy.

In talking about this industry, I remind the House that I am not talking about an insignificant number of jobs. The industry is a huge and growing employer. It moves people and goods and services, and it earns export dollars for Australia which help to create economic prosperity and opportunity in Australia. But these issues are of not much importance to the Deputy Prime Minister because, every time I look around when it comes to a tough decision, I find that he is hiding on the farm or doing an exclusive interview in the Land about how tough it is and, if he is lucky enough to be a minister after the next election, he might have to give up some of his portfolio because it is all tough. Are you surprised that the part of the portfolio he wants to give up because it requires a few decisions from time to time is the very part of the portfolio about which we are talking today which relates to the minister's inactionâthe transport portfolio? I can tell you what: it is tough, but if you do your work it is not tough, it is very rewarding. You are actually working with an industry that makes a huge contribution to the benefit of Australia, and for that very reason it is about time that the minister took his responsibilities seriously.

Returning to the briefing document, not only do we find that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has the primary responsibility, when we see that the energy credit scheme is under his watch, but our concerns can only increase given his record and his lack of interest in matters in the transport portfolio. The minister lost track of interest in his transport responsibilities long ago, as evidenced in the recent interview in the Land. That is obviously a worrying sign for the industry.
That takes me to another part of the confidential briefing paper which was given to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. The briefing paper stated:

quote.para: The Cabinet memorandum aims to develop the Government's position on the scope of reform under the Energy Grants Credit Scheme and the process to be followed in developing the scheme. The Cabinet memorandum is at an early stage of developmentâ

speech.para: this is in March 2001, about 18 months down the track from the date the original agreement was entered into with the Democratsâ

quote.para: and it is not possible to provide any details of departmental thinking to the public or the ATA, particularly as there is no agreement between the Ministers at this stage.

speech.para: That document proves yet again that the energy credit scheme has not been developed because the government cannot do its work and it cannot stop internal division about the nature of a potential energy credit scheme. The document states that `there is no agreement between the Ministers at this stage'. It is there in black and white in the memorandum of 7 March of this year. I would also argue that there is still no agreement between the ministers because, frankly, it is not a high order issue in their minds as it is only about jobs, job security and the future of the transport industry and its capacity to contribute to the betterment of Australia.

So be it, but it continues a trend in terms of the performance of the Howard government. We have a Prime Minister who did a deal for an energy credit scheme to get the votes of the Democrats on the GST. We then find that, despite having done the dealâand I thought that this would have been sorted out before the deal was done with the Democratsâwe now have evidence in this confidential memorandum that the Prime Minister cannot even get agreement across his various ministerial responsibilities. That is because there was never any commitment to the development of an energy credit scheme. It was about a cheap and tricky deal to get a vote. It was another cynical exercise to try and get the GST in place, with all the potential impacts on the Australia community.

A further point I note from that briefing is that the government knew back in March that the industry was anxious to ensure its continued entitlementsâbut, frankly, the government was not very interested in the anxiety of the industry. I suppose this is another example of the minister and the government being out of touch. I seek leave to table the confidential departmental briefing to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Dr Stone, of 7 March this year.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âIs leave granted?
âNo, Mr Deputy Speaker. He has not gone through the normal process of courtesy and shown it to us.
âLeave is not granted.

âI am not surprised that leave is not granted, Mr Deputy Speaker. When it comes to accountability, the government do not want the facts on the table. That is the very answer I expected. But then, it is not our problem; it was not our deal and we were not in on the loop. We will expose the non-performance of this government on a continuous basis.

speech.para: This bill in no way absolves the government of their responsibility to actually do the work. They should start the work, because they have failed to do the work to date. When the Labor Party promised to introduce legislative changes to extend this scheme for an extra 12 months, we promised not to sit on our tails as the Howard government have done. We said we would need to finalise it by 30 June 2003 so as to ensure that an energy credit scheme for the truck industry, with associated arrangements that maintain benefits equivalent to DAFGS, was in place. That is all the industry want. They want to know the parameters within which they are expected to operate. Importantly, as part of the development of those parameters, they expect to be consulted and taken seriously. Labor supports this bill for that very reason. It is about giving the government extra time to do work that should have been done already. But, frankly, given the track record of the Howard government on this issue, I am wondering whether they could do it even with a three-year extension, let alone with this 12-month extensionâshould they be lucky enough to win the election.

In essence, today is about certainty. The trucking, agricultural, mining and related industriesâand not only the operators but also the manufacturers and suppliersâneed lead time to make capital decisions and to properly plan. It is now a matter of fact that the fuel tax inquiry will examine the whole issue of fuel taxes, including the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme. The report is due in March 2002. With the extension of the diesel grant scheme, the government now has more time to devise, consider, consult, debate, negotiate, resolve and legislate, if need be, an energy credit scheme to meet the sunset date. Hopefully, even the Howard government could meet this further extension of 12 months. But this extension does not remove the imperative to get cracking to finalise the scheme now. Transport operators and other business people in the agricultural and mining industries need to plan and they need to know what the regulatory framework is going to be at least 12 months in advance.

Irrespective of who sits on the government side of the House after the next election, we should not wait until 2003 to do this work. As soon as the fuel inquiry report is brought down in March next year, we should get well under way a process of consultation and hard work to work out what is appropriate so that the industry knows well in advance the parameters within which it is expected to operate. This is important, and it requires that the government get moving to put options on the table and to take these issues seriously.

I conclude by confirming that the opposition also supports the changes with respect to emergency vehicles. It was a nonsense that organisations like rural fire brigades had to distinguish between fuel used on road and fuel used when they went off road to fight bushfires. We are pleased to see that matter resolved, because it is about the safety of the Australian community. Labor welcomes the government's roll-back of the provisions through the minor changes to assist the administration of the scheme. These are consistent with our policy of making the GST and its related schemes fairer and easier to administer. We are pleased the government is also adopting Labor Party policy with respect to the sunset provision. I only hope that the Howard government learns from this experience. If you had done your work, we would not be wasting the time of the House today. This bill would not have been required to come before the House if the government had done its work. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â Mr Deputy Speaker, I must admit some amusement in listening to the honourable member for Batman, particularly when he finally got to use the `r' word. We now have an opposition frontbencher who has rediscovered the word `roll-back'. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition is going to now take the hint and explain to us what roll-back really means. But at least the opposition spokesman on transport and regional services has discovered it. We will wait with bated breath to see how that is going to develop.

speech.para: I must admit that, listening to the honourable member, I was amazed. It sounded to me as though he had got out of the wrong side of the bed this morning. He is obviously a bit bitter about life. There were a lot of sour grapes about what the government is doing, and it also seemed that he feels that he has to lecture the minister on what he should or should not be doing. When I was listening to him, I thought, `This is yet another example of Labor trying to rewrite history. All the reforms and all the good things that the government has done to try to reduce the cost of transport in this countryâso many of which were opposed by Laborânow seem to be conveniently ignored by Labor spokesmen, such as the member for Batman.' Clearly, when we sought to make all of those reforms and to make changes which were very much for the benefit not only of the transport industry but also of regional Australia, Labor opposed so many of them. This is something that I am sure we are going to need to remind them of in the lead-up to this election, because through that opposition they clearly showed that they are not exactly in favour of supporting regional Australia.

It is worth going through some of Labor's record when it comes to using fuel for taxation purposes. This demonstrates very clearly that when Labor had the opportunity while they were in governmentâduring 13 years of the Hawke and Keating governmentsâ they quite deliberately used fuel as a source of revenue, they quite deliberately socked it to the country and at times they were quite happy to deceive the voters. For example, in the lead-up to the 1993 election, the Labor Party made it very clear to the voters that they would not increase taxes. But as soon as they won the 1993 election, what was the first thing they did? They put the fuel excise up again.

When we listen to all the bleats about compensation for low income earnersâfor those on pensions, and so onâwe should remember what Labor did in that situation. Nothing. Contrast that with the Howard government. We went out of our way to make sure that, when we made the changes to the tax system, which included changes to the fuel taxation system, we fully compensated people.

I will quickly reiterate some of the details of Labor's policy when they are in government, which always seems to be a bit of a contrast with when they are not in government. In 1983-84, when Labor came to office, fuel excise was just over 6c a litre. When they left office, it was over 34c a litre. So in 13 years it went from 6c to 34 cents, an increase of over 450 per cent. On an annual rate, it works out around 35 per cent per annum. That is Labor's record when in government. The coalition not only has made changes to the effect of excise on diesel but has removed indexation from fuel excise.

It is important to note that, when the government brought in the new tax system, Labor opposed it all the way. They opposed the GST on fuel, which includes diesel. The government's intention was to make fuel cheaper for transport and for people in the country. Nowâsurprise, surpriseâapparently they have done a roll backwards and said that the GST is now part of Labor policy.

I would like to talk a little about some of the details of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. The government introduced the scheme, which came into being on 1 July last year. Diesel is now cheaper for a number of off-road users in the mining, farming, fishing and forestry industries. It is also cheaper for remote residential premises that use it for generating electricity and providing normal domestic services. It also benefits hospitals, nursing and aged care homes and those providing this type of care. It has had a major role in reducing the cost of rail and shipping transport. Labor could not do this; the coalition did.

This government is about getting costs down and making sure that there are no tax inputs, which means that exporters can be more competitive and that the cost of fuel will be cheaper. Australia is a very large country and we have to do everything we can to contain our transport costs, which is a major factor in many industries.

This bill extends the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme until 30 June 2003. The trucking industry, the trucking operators and all those who benefit will be able to plan with confidence. The bill also extends the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme to 30 June 2003 and, as the member for Batman has pointed out, there are amendments which allow for a grant to be payable on all fuel used in an emergency vehicle of 4Â½ tonnes or more and fuel used for associated auxiliary equipment. This would be of benefit to organisations such as the Country Fire Authority. It is important that the governments gets recognition for what it has done.

A number of changes have been made to simplify administration, which again shows that the government are listening and responding. Having introduced the changes, we are now modifying and improving them. These changes simplify the method of calculating the eligible fuel, give third parties the opportunity to submit the claims on behalf of businesses and extend the time for reconciling and repaying advances from 21 days to 28 days so that the on-road scheme and other payment schemes administered by the ATO are in line with this. Those who do not claim them in advance can nominate a monthly, quarterly or annual period for their grants.

There is no doubt that this is a very significant reform. From 1 August this year, fuel excise is 38c a litreâand I remind honourable members that the government has removed indexationâand diesel used in trucks is rebated at just over 18Â½c a litre, which is a very significant saving. The government has reduced the cost of transport and is helping to keep costs down for exporters, thereby making our exports, and indeed many of our domestic products, a lot cheaper for customers here and overseas. This means that we can be more competitive. The simplification of and reduction in paperwork will obviously be welcomed. There will be the opportunity for further discussion about the Energy Grants (Credits) Schemeâsomething I am sure the government will take up when it gets the opportunity in the year to come.

I think it is important to mention that on 1 March the government announced an inquiry into the whole structure of fuel taxation in Australia and the question of rebates, subsidies and grants. That is very significant. It shows that something that is long overdue is now being tackled. There is already an issues paper that was put out in August. I think it is an extremely good paper and I certainly commend ACIL, who have been involved in this. This inquiry is long overdue. It will mean that major fuel users, and particularly people in the country who rely so much on fuel, will have the opportunity to have this whole question of fuel taxation reviewed. I have no doubt that, from the recommendations, we will be able to get a fairer system.

The other point I would like to touch on is that the response to this amendment to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme has been very positive from the community. I will mention two groups that are going to be directly affected. The Australian Trucking Association is a very big organisation. It has 160,000 trucks registered with it. They have made it clear that they certainly support the amendment; in fact, they have gone further than that and said:

quote.para: This legislation is welcomed. We support the retention of the on-road grant. We support this extension because the diesel grant is a vital instrument that delivers the cost-effective trucking service, which at the end of the day sees Australia's industries more competitive both domestically against exports and more in an export-orientated country we need to ensure our exports are competitive.

speech.para: They go on to say:

quote.para: The ATA (Australian Trucking Association) is recognised as operating by world best practise and that is because not only do we have the most innovative but also cost effective Trucking Association. So obviously the ATA supports anything that reduces the tax burden on trucking and therefore will grow the freight task and Australia's economy.

speech.para: I think that shows very strong support from the Australian Trucking Association. The National Farmers Federation, which is a very highly regarded organisation nationally, also commented on the legislation. Su McCluskey, Director of Taxation for the National Farmers Federation, said:

quote.para: We support this absolutely. This legislation gives members certainty for on and off-road usage.

speech.para: This amendment to the grant and rebate schemes is welcomed. It seems unfortunate that the opposition can only begrudgingly support it. It is a pity that they cannot recognise the importance of keeping down the costs of fuel for transport and off-road users. It is important that we not allow the Australian population to forget that it was this government that brought in these reforms in respect of the reduction in fuel taxes, despite being opposed all the way by the Australian Labor Party. I have great pleasure in supporting this bill and look forward to its speedy passage through this chamber and the other one.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I like the member for Wannon. He is a really decent bloke, but he really should study transport if he wants to come into this House and debate transport. What we heard today was someone filling in 15 or 20 minutes with little regard for the facts. It was interesting to listen to the member for Wannon talk about how the government has implemented policies to cut transport costs. If the member for Wannon thinks that transport costs have come down, he ought to get out into rural and regional Australia, as I do where I live. He will find out that transport is actually dearer today than it was before this legislation came into being. The margins for transport operators are less. They are probably lower than at any time in history, and current rates for transport are unsustainable. The member for Wannon mentioned rail transport. What did this government do with regard to rail transport? They sold National Rail. What did they do with shipping transport? They sold Australian National Line. There are virtually no Australian ships in the shipping industry today. And the member for Wannon talks about making costs cheaper! Of course, if the government want to make costs cheaper for international shipping owners, so be it. That is the sort of thing that we have come to expect from this government.

speech.para: Today we are debating the Fuel Legislation Amendment (Grant and Rebate Schemes) Bill 2001 because the government simply have not done their job. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme and the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme were due to be replaced on 1 July with the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme. In other words, since the implementation of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme, the government should have been working to write a policy and develop a strategy about an energy grants credits scheme, and they simply have not done it. Of course, this is the last week of the life of this parliament, so something has to be put in place to give the trucking industry some degree of certainty. This piece of amendment legislation has been described as `reform'. I have never heard an amendment to continue the existence of a piece of legislation regarded as `reform', but I suppose a conservative government in power would consider the maintenance of the status quo as reform. So that is what we are doing. We are simply maintaining the status quo until 1 July next year so that the trucking industry knows that the price of diesel fuel is not going to go up.

We are also debating this legislation today because it was an ill-conceived stopgap measure when it was introduced because of the advent of the GST, because of the new tax system, because of the deal done with the Democrats. The extension of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme is necessary to bring some certainty to the transport industry in particular. The electorate of Paterson, which I represent, which straddles, as it does, the junction of the Pacific Highway and the New England Highway, is a natural hub for the transport industry to locate. It is an important industry to the residents of the electorate I represent. There are many owner-driver operators. These are medium and small sized operators. They provide interstate services and bulk haulage services for products from our farms, our smelters, our mines, our ports and our sawmillers. You name it, and the Hunter produces it. Of course, we have to get it to market, and so the transport industry is significantly represented in the area that I represent in this parliament.

I certainly remember the chaos in the transport industry, with the sudden increase in diesel fuel prices about two years ago. I remember the bankruptcies of owner-drivers. They could not even recover costs, let alone make a profit, after the advent of the GST. This government has been seen as a non-caring government. It has been described by one of their own as mean and tricky. It is a government that does not care about jobs. We saw that in the way the Prime Minister and others answered questions in this House yesterday. This is a government that thinks that the only thing that workers are interested in when they lose their jobs is worker entitlements. That is not right. What those people really want is a job. They do not want their entitlements. No-one wants to saddle up and say, `I've got my entitlements.' If you have a mortgage, if you have a family, if you have commitments and if you want a future, you really need a jobânot something that is going to allow you to exist for the next six weeks or the next six months. You want to know that you can continue paying off your home, that you can continue educating and clothing your children and that, at some time in the future, you will retire in the normal way. This government does not recognise that. This government likes to talk in terms of statutory entitlementâthe national standard of eight weeks entitlement. That is what happens when you get a government that is overconcerned about economic rationalism and really does not care about people, and that is what has happened with the transport industry too. That is why the member for Wannon today stood up and said, `This is a piece of reform.' Make no mistake: this is not about reform at all. That is something that has to come.

The trucking industry, essentially, is small business. There are big players there, too: the Tolls and the Finemores and so on. But they also use subcontractors who are owner-driver operators, the small business with a big investment and, of course, it is an industry with enormous uncertainty. They are working on margins that are unsustainable. The GST has been a disaster to the transport industry, with the government taking 10 per cent of everythingâspare parts, tyres and insurance. Of course, since the HIH debacle we have seen that insurance costs have risen and, therefore, the 10 per cent GST, and the government has its hand in the pocket even deeper. All services of the trucking industry, for the first time, are taxed at 10 per cent. This government has the gall to stand up here, and the Deputy Prime Minister in particular, who represents regional and rural Australiaâhe is the leader of the National Party, which supposedly represents regional and rural Australiaâand repeatedly tell us how much cheaper transport has become. It has not.

The government take from transport is now greater than at any time in history. I know trucking families that are virtually divorced. The only way they can save their home is to keep the truck on the road seven days a week. The husband drives it and the wife does the bookwork, the phoning and trying to get orders. That is their life, and they are going backwards. What do they get in return? Do they get a commitment from the government? Do they get assurance? Do they get certainty? Do they get the security of their job? The answer to those questions is no. What they get is an amendment that extends the status quo to 1 July next year.

As I speak, I see that the member for New England will follow me in this debate. I know that he will certainly be at a rally for `Save the grant'. There is one in my electorate on Friday night. I hope that parliament is up in time so that I can get there to assure these people that they do have the support of the Labor Party, as they have always had, to make sure that the trucking industry, a vital industry to our nation, is sustainable. The shadow minister, Martin Ferguson, gave the assurance on 31 August this year, when he addressed a conference, that the Labor Party will maintain the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme and also the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. Once again, as I said, we are making an amendment to correct a hurried decision that was made to rush through that ill-prepared GSTâthe piece of legislation that now has over 2,000 amendments, and here are a few more. The engineers who designed the legislation did not think it out, so it is amendment, after amendment, after amendment. And it goes on.

What we should be debating today, or should have been debating prior to this, is the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme. That is something that the Democrats demanded, and the government, with their usual honour, are not presenting it in this parliament, and probably never will. That was about the environment. That is why the Democrats demanded it. They said, `We will support the GST, but we want the government to put in place an energy grants credits scheme in an effort to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. As we have come to learn from this government, they are always reluctant to introduce innovation.

The shame of it is that if this government had been positive, if they had been constructive, they could have made enormous inroads with an energy grants credits scheme. I have repeatedly talked in this place about the potential for ethanol as an alternative fuel in Australia. The amazing thing is that we have a world expert on ethanol, Dr Russell Reeves, residing in Australia. His technology is used in Brazil, Sweden, Germany, Spain, England and the United States. He is an Australian; he resides in the electorate of Paterson. He is a good friend of mine. Where is his technology not used? It is not used in Australia. To me, that epitomises the way the Howard-Costello government treat Australians.

We have inventors and scientists who devise products and machinery, and we do not use it. It gets used elsewhere. In a nation that is the greatest per capita producer of greenhouse gases in the world, we have, right on our doorstep, the means for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. You see, ethanol is an oxygenator. That is why the United States introduced legislation that demanded that ethanol be used in certain areas of the United States: to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and photochemical smog. The addition of ethanol to either petrol or diesel produces a cleaner burning fuel. These are the sorts of things that this government could have written into legislation, and they would have got full support and encouragement from the Australian Labor Party. But here we are, in the last couple of days before this parliament breaks up before an election, and this government have squandered an opportunity, despite the fact that they gave an assurance to the Democrats that they would introduce this legislation. That is why we are debating this amendment today: this government, firstly, do not honour their obligations, and, secondly, are completely bankrupt as far as scientific innovation is concerned.

Let us go further. As the world faces the uncertainty that it faces today, I hate to think what is going to happen if there is international conflict. What is going to happen to our fuel supply? What is going to happen to our liquid petroleum supply? Australia is certainly not self-sufficient in it. We are importing increasing amounts of both crude oil and distilled product. If we had in place a procedure whereby we were replacing 10 to 15 per cent of diesel with ethanol and 10 to 15 per cent of petrol with ethanol, that could be a home-grown industry creating jobs.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âI am very pleased that the member for Kennedy is here, because he and I have had long discussions about the use of ethanol. It is a fuel for the future, but it does require a government with a bit of spirit, a bit of foresight and a bit of determination to create jobs. All we have is a government that is prepared to say to workers, `You will get your entitlements,' and all they wanted was a job.
âThey do not even get all their entitlements.

âAs my colleague the shadow minister said, `They do not even get all their entitlements.' All they get is the statutory standard: eight weeks. It does not matter if they have been working for Ansett for 30 or 40 years; they will get their eight weeks redundancy payment.

speech.para: The opposition does support this, because it will give some degree of certainty that is needed in the trucking industry. But the trucking industry needs far more support than this government is prepared to give. This is a stopgap measure that should have been replaced by something far more forward thinking that took us into the 21st century with some certainty that Australia could be a world leader in the trucking industry. But I am very sad to say that this amendment, which we will support today, is keeping us back in the 20th century. That is a hallmark of the Howard-Costello government. This is not a government that should take us into a new century and a new millennium.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Fuel Legislation Amendment (Grant and Rebate Schemes) Bill 2001. It is always a pleasure to follow the member for Paterson. We seem to have been doing this for a number of years. This bill will extend the duration of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Schemeâand what a wonderful scheme it has been. I hope the member for Paterson is not leaving, because I would love to address some of the issues he raised. He is staying; wonderful.

speech.para: When this scheme was introduced, the member for Paterson actually voted against a reduction in the excise of 18c a litre. The trucking industry must never forget that, and I know that the good people of the seat of Paterson will never forget that the member for Paterson voted against a reduction in excise for diesel for the transport industry. It is very important for people to remember that. He also was one of those on the other side who voted against anyone who had a truck of less than 20 tonnes GVM in the city receiving that grant. He also, together with his colleagues on the other side, voted against all those vehicles with a GVM of under 4Â½ tonnesâparticularly in regional Australiaâthat also cannot access that great benefit.

This bill will also extend the duration of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. It is appropriate that we do extend the scheme. I have found, in dealing with the transport industry around Australia and in dealing with many individuals within the trucking industry as such, including owner drivers, that there needed to be a confidence that the program would continue. The main reason for that confidence being extended is the fact that there is an inquiry. We agreed to hold an inquiry into the total structure of fuel taxation in Australia and related rebates, subsidies and grants, and I think that is good. I think the other thing that concerned the transport industry was the fact that the Australian Labor Party did not commit to an extension of the scheme. They were dragged into this place screaming and kicking. It was not until about 31 August that the opposition spokesman actually made a statement to suggest that they will support the extension. The transport industry was very concerned that the Australian Labor Party would not support the extension of this particular scheme.

The bill extends the eligibility of emergency vehicles under the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. Again, this is a progressive amendment, contrary to what the member for Paterson or the opposition spokesman on transport had to say. There was a difficulty with emergency vehicles, when they are not in operation. This legislation will extend support to those vehicles to come under the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. The bill makes a number of administrative amendments to the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. It provides grants, as we are aware, for on-road use of diesel fuel for 20 tonnes gross vehicle mass. The Australian Labor Party could have assisted with that so that everybodyâincluding all those truckies who are in Sydney, Brisbane and other metropolitan areasâcould access a reduction in the rate of fuel for their vehicles of 20 tonnes gross vehicle mass or less and for vehicles between 4Â½ and 20 tonnes GVM that are used to transport passengers by road in the non-metropolitan areas. Again, we have seen that the Labor Party does not always come through and support the initiatives for reform in the taxation area. The Diesel Fuel Rebate Schemeâthe off-road schemeâprovides a rebate of the excise for customs duty paid on diesel and light fuels used in certain eligible off-road activities as specified in mining, agriculture, fishing, forestry, rail, marine transport, electricity generation for remote residents and in the operations of hospitals, nursing homes, aged care and other medical institutions.

I will raise again a very progressive business in my electorate of New England: G&C Foundry. Geoff Swilkes and his wife own a business about 22 kilometres outside the small town of Uralla, where they have no access to power. These people have two very major diesel engines to generate electricity for their foundry business. They employ 21 people and are looking to expand in an expanding market for the particular products that they produce. They are not able to claim the 18Â½c a litre off the excise, and there is only one reason: those on the other side, including the member for Paterson and the shadow spokesman for transport, voted against G&C Foundry accessing the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. So we have the situation, created by the Australian Labor Party, where the fuel company that delivers the fuel to G&C Foundry regularlyâthey use about 1,000 litres of diesel a day for their equipmentâcan claim the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme rebate, and they are very thankful for that; it certainly reduces the impediments to their doing business. But the recipient, G&C Foundry, which is using this diesel cannot claim it. G&C Foundry cannot claim it because the Labor Party opposed the legislation, and therefore changes had to be made. I think that is a pity and a shame. The people at G&C Foundry know, and the people around Australia know, that there are many instances of usage that were blocked when that original legislation came in.

The on-road and off-road schemes were due to be replaced, as we have heard, on 1 July 2002 by the proposed energy grants credit scheme, and I am pleased that a lot more time will be put into the development of this scheme. When the results of the inquiry into the structure of fuel taxation generally in Australia comes outâthe report is due, I understand, in around March next yearâI think that is a good time to look at the provisions as a whole. That is why there has been an extension. As I said, it was not until 31 August, I believe, that the shadow spokesman for transport said that the opposition will end uncertainty and extend the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. It took an awfully long time. The Australian Trucking Association, the Australian Livestock Transporters Association and many other groups, including owner driversâand I am joined by the member for Parkes, who understand the importance of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme for the transporters in his vast area of western New South Walesâlobbied a great deal and for a long time to get the other side of this House to agree to extend it.

We have come to understandâI have over the last three years of this termâthat often the things that are said by those on the other side, particularly by shadow spokesmen, do not necessarily end up coming through when they get into government. We noticed that in 1992âand I just draw the attention of the House and of the rest of Australia to this, because I never like to waste an opportunity to remind the people of Australia of some of the comments made in the lead-up to the 1993 election when we actually had the Labor Party on this side of the House, in governmentâthat the then Labor Prime Minister said:
... what I am promising is not to put up tax.

He said that on 19 November 1992. What happened after that 1993 election? Petrol exciseâwhich includes diesel, of courseâ increased. It increased three times during that period. As you would be aware, it was the Australian Labor Party that introduced automatic indexation on fuel. Every time the CPI went up we found that excise on diesel went up. Not only did they vote against a reduction of 18Â½c in diesel excise when they were in opposition but they also put it up when they were in government. Then they said, `What we really want to do is to automatically put it up.' It was a good system! But this Howard-Anderson government scrapped that automatic indexation and said, `No, we understand that that is a bad way to continue to automatically raise taxes.' The CPI increases that this government has been able to achieve over the last six years are substantially in front of any of those that were produced during the time that the Labor Party were in government. It is interesting when you start to look at those comparisons.

But I was talking about tax and the fact that the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme is part of tax reform. When the Labor Party was inâafter the 1993 electionâ they actually increased the fringe benefits tax three times, increased the Medicare levy and increased company tax. With regard to all those little transport operators who had companies that the member for Paterson was talking about, he assisted in raising the tax rate for companies from 33 cents to 36 cents in the dollar. He had no regard for the fact that small business was again going to be hit. There was an increase. What did this Howard-Anderson government do to assist it? I remind Australians in small business, particularly those in companies, that we reduced the company tax rate from 36c to 30câa substantial reductionâand that assisted all businesses in Australia. When the Labor Party was on this side, they increased sales tax on passenger carsâthere is a wonderful increasing taxation regime on the other side! Bangâthey increased it from 16 per cent to 21 per cent. `Just put the price up,' they said. `It doesn't really matter; just put the price up. It doesn't really matter because you can actually borrow more money if you do not have enough.'

talk.start.para: âThey still couldn't balance the books.

âAs the member for Parkes says, they still could not balance the books. But they thought that really did not matter either because they could just continue to put it on the credit card. When you listen to those on the other side talking about the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Schemeâit has developed and delivered real benefits to regional Australia, real benefits in removing many of the costs that were imposed by the Labor Partyâyou start to understand why they have no credibility.

speech.para: When I came into this House, the member for Paterson was talking about the GST. During all the time he has been in here talking about issues to do with the GST and small business and transport operators, he just does not seem to understand. He keeps talking about the fact that all those transport operators are paying an extra 10 per cent. He just does not understand. And why aren't I surprised at that? I am not surprised, because he does not understand business. He does not understand what it is like to run a business. He does not understand, like the member for Brisbane who is sitting at the table, what it is like to actually employ people, what it is like to face a bank manager on an overdraft, what it is like to get out there and make a sale or what it is like to actually run your truck and to find those things.

talk.start.para: âHe does, actually. He runs a business; he has a farm. You have the wrong one.
âThrough you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I ask the member at the table why he voted against a reduction in excise on diesel?

speech.para: I raise again this question of the input tax credit on the GST. The myth continues to be put out there in the public arena by the Labor Party that this is some additional tax that has been added. This is not a tax like the increases in the excise and company tax rates when they were in government; we are talking about the GST. The GST as it is applied to business is treated as an input tax credit. Therefore, if you are in business and you incur GST, you are able to claim it as an input tax credit so that you do not actually have a tax applying to the business.

The trucking industry and in particular the owner drivers, with whom I have been working very closely over the last 2Â½ years while in this place, giving them access to our ministers to allow them to put their view directlyâand members of that group have said to me that they have had far better access to this government's ministers than they ever had previously; I think that is very importantâunderstand the fact that they are paying less tax now than was paid in all those dark years under the Labor Party. The concern that we and the industry haveâshould, for some reason, Mr Beazley and Mr Crean form a government after the next election; heaven forbid!âis what will happen to taxes. That is easy. They will go up. Excise will go up; there is no question or doubt in my mind that that is their intention. Company tax rates are now at 30 cents in the dollar, giving Labor another excuse to raise them. And personal income tax rates, from which this country has at last been able to receive a significant reductionâ$12 billion has come off income tax ratesâwill go up. We now have significantly lower company taxes, as I mentioned, and exports are saving around $3Â½ billion, because this government took taxes off them.

The states now receive the total revenue of the GST, and in the case of New South Wales that runs to around $8Â½ billion. Let us hope that they start to accept the responsibilities that they have to increase education spending in their state school education system. Wouldn't it be nice if they spent some of that money on their state responsibility roads and on putting policemen back on the beat in country New South Wales rather than taking them out of country New South Wales? Wouldn't it be great if they reduced payroll taxâthat iniquitous tax whereby the more people you employ the more tax you pay? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Fuel Legislation Amendment (Grant and Rebate Schemes) Bill 2001 amends the Customs Act 1901, the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Act 1999 and the Excise Act 1901 to extend the expiry dates of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme and the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme from 30 June 2002 to 30 June 2003. It will extend the scope of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme insofar as it relates to fuel used by emergency vehicles and it makes a number of administrative amendments to the scheme.

speech.para: The schemes were due to be replaced on 1 July 2002 by an Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme. The amendments will mean that the introduction of the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme will be postponed until 1 July 2003 or earlier. Both the customs and excise acts provide the legislative basis for the operations of these schemes and we have legislative provision for the operation of that scheme.

The extension of time in the bill results from the fact that on 8 July 2001 the government announced an inquiry into the taxation of fuels. You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Labor Party has had an extensive inquiry into GST, fuel and taxation issues which has traversed the country. This was well in front of the government's own inquiry, an inquiry which came very belatedly after initiatives from the Labor Party. The government's inquiry has as part of its function an examination of the proposed Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme and is not due to report until March 2002. The Labor Party has argued, primarily through its spokesperson on these issues, the member for Batman, that this would have left insufficient time to resolve the examination of the scheme before the end of June 2002 and was a matter that was therefore causing uncertainty and concern, particularly within the road transport industry. It is clear that, had the government not brought this legislation forward, there would have been only three months between the fuel taxation inquiry's reporting deadline and the implementation of the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme.

While these are complicated issues, there is no agreement within the government on them. This morning the member for Batman referred to a confidential minute from Environment Australia which referred to this fact. It indicated that there was no agreement between ministers at the time of the writing of this minute. That is important for a number of reasons. As the member for Batman outlined, this arrangement came about as a result of a deal done with the Australian Democrats over the introduction of the new tax system, and what a dodgy deal it was. As a result of significant concessions sought by the Democrats, and on the word of the government, the Democrats proceeded to allow the passage of the new tax scheme and, as a result, the GST. This means that the Democrats were a party with the government to the introduction of the iniquitous GST. This is a regressive tax, a tax which the Labor Party is opposed to, a tax which the Labor Party opposed when it was introduced and a tax which the community was clearly concerned about. The Democrats, being aware that they could get some agreement with the government over issues which they perceived to be of importance to themâin this case the Energy Grants (Credits) Schemeâdid a deal with the government for the passage of that legislation.

Here we are now passing legislation to extend these concessional arrangements because the government has yet to finalise its position. I think that sends a number of messages. The first message it should send is to the Democrats. Why did you deal with the devil? It is very clear that the devil is dishonest. In this case, the government has exposed its dishonesty by not coming through with the deal. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you hope that we get some honesty and integrity back into the leadership of the government. Instead of misleading the Australian community, as the government has done, and in this case, as partners to the arrangement, the Democrats as well, we just hope the government does something honestly for a change. Remember that the GST was a tax which would never, ever be introduced. The Prime Minister said itâanother example of dishonesty.

As a result of the poor behaviour of the government, the Labor Party called some months ago for an extension to these arrangements, because we saw that there was no way in the world that there would be sufficient time between the expiry of the government's own inquiry and June 2002, when there was a need to replace the scheme with the new energy credits scheme. We knew that it would just not take place. That was a matter of major concern to various industry sectors, particularly the road transport industry, which is extremely significant to my own electorate.

The Northern Territory has a land mass of 1.3 million square kilometres. It is about one-sixth of the Australian continent, but it holds only 1.5 per cent of the Australian population. So it is a very widely dispersed population, with around half residing in Darwin and Palmerston and the remainder spread liberally around the Northern Territory. The transport industry in the Northern Territory employs around 7,000 people, including drivers and administrators. For those people who have not been to the Northern Territory and to remote Australia, we have all seen photographs of large road trains with three or four dogs. They make an enormous contribution to Northern Australia, and in the case of the Northern Territory they make a very significant contribution to the Northern Territory economy. Approximately 90 per cent of all freight movements into the Northern Territory come by road train. That is a significant amount. In 1999-2000 the industry contributed around 5.5 per cent of the Territory's gross state product. So it is a significant contributor and a very important industry to the Northern Territory.

The extension of this scheme is important to the road transport industry, and it is important to the Northern Territory community. I have spoken in this place on a number of occasions previously about how important the road transport industry is and how important this scheme has been to keeping costs down within the industry. There is a range of issues which confront the road transport industry in the Northern Territory, one of which is the price of diesel. Clearly, a reduction in the price, which is a result of this rebate system, brings significant benefits to the road transport industry and thereby Territory consumers. If we accept that 90 per cent of freight that comes into the Northern Territory comes by road transport, you do not have to be Einstein to work out how important a contribution it makes to the Territory economy and to the Territory lifestyle.

There is a range of other matters which impact upon the ability of the road transport industry to efficiently and appropriately provide services to the Northern Territory community. An issue of great importance to the road transport industry in the Territory is the state of the roads. We know that the Commonwealth has primary responsibility for the national highway system. The Commonwealth has spent significant dollars in the past for the establishment and then the maintenance of the Stuart Highway, the Barkly Highway and Victoria River Highway. These are the major access points into the Territory for the road transport industry. But the industry does not only rely only on those roads, and we know that roads are falling into disrepair and require a significant amount of investment to put them into a position where they efficiently provide for the needs of the road transport industry and, indeed, of vehicle transport generally.

We also know that a large amount of the work done by the road transport industry in the Northern Territory is to remote communities. I have mentioned in this place on a number of occasions the importance of access to remote communities for the road transport industry and what that means for the Territory community and Territory business. An example I have used is the gold province in the Tanami region of the Northern Territory, and the need to ensure that the road which attends to those goldmines, the Tanami Road, is of a standard which will meet the needs of industry. We have had the Roads to Recovery money, which I have spoken about here on any number of occasions. I have made the point, again on a number of occasions, that, whilst the member for Gwydir, the Deputy Prime Minister, is able to secure in excess of $40 million for his electorate in that program, the Northern Territory received around half that amount, when the Territory is one-sixth of the Australian land mass, with 110,000 voters, almost 200,000 people.

I have exposed in this place on a number of occasions the inequity in the distribution of those funds. That is important because the Tanami Road has been effectively closed on a number of occasions in the last 12 months because of flooding and it requires a significant investment of money to upgrade it.
