talk.start.para: âToday we are debating the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 which gives legislative backing to the 10 signed regional forest agreements around the country, particularly in New South Wales, Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia. The fact that there are 10 agreements now rather than the more limited number when we last explored this legislation reflects a clear change in the situation. In the interim, of course, the Western Australian agreement totally collapsedâ in the end, with all of the political parties in that state abandoning it. Quite frankly, Labor's original position that there should be a disallowance resolution to review the Western Australian situation is clearly vindicated.

âMembers opposite can raise their eyebrows all they want, but the Premier of WA, Mr Court, the National Party, the Democrats and Labor abandoned that agreement. The only person who stood for it was Minister Tuckey, who was repudiated by the Western Australian Liberal government. Unfortunately, in the interim, he had given guarantees to Western Australian workers that all of their jobs would be protected when he knew they were going out the back door throughout the whole process.

speech.para: Labor supports the current bill with minor amendments. Last time we were here this bill was carried with 16 amendments. This week, Labor has a very reduced number of amendments and, quite frankly, large parts of industry as well as significant numbers of backbenchers opposite know that the nature of these amendments constitutes no significant detriment to the industry and the wood is on the government to accept this smaller number of minor amendments. The electorate and industry will be watching to see whether there is going to be a constructive approach by the government to get this legislation through the parliament.

The RFA process along with Plantation 2020 Vision, of course, arises out of Labor's historic national forests policy statement of 1992. Labor remains totally committed to the national forests policy statement and to the RFA process. It is not only the federal opposition that wants this measure through the parliament and does not want it to be thwarted or stuffed around by the minister with convoluted arguments about minor technicalities and what is wrong with our amendments; the premiers around this country want this legislation through as well.

We are extremely critical of the timing of the introduction of this bill by Minister Tuckey. We hope his destructive behaviour does not destroy an historic opportunity for bipartisan cooperation to secure the passage of the legislation through both houses before the current parliament is dissolved. If, at the end of the day, we do not manage to achieve that outcome, the minister, who professes to be only person in the whole country concerned with the welfare of the timber industry, will be clearly to blame.

Let us recap the history of consideration of RFA legislation by the parliament. An RFA bill was first introduced into the House just before the 1998 federal electionâvery convenient timing. It passed the House with Labor's support but was not considered by the Senate when the coalition called an early election. When we look at the current situation and the timing, there has to be grave doubts about the minister's sincerity or whether he is just going through the motions and that the real power in this government resides with Senator Hill. I am fed upâand so is the industryâwith the constant excuses by Minister Tuckey that he cannot control Hill, that Hill mucks him around in the Senate and that he has no control over what is happening. He is the bloke out there supposedly defending the industry.

An identical bill was reintroduced in November 1998 and passed the House in early 1999âI stress that timingâwith Labor's support. The Senate referred the bill to an inquiry which reported in early 1999. Ironically, the committee rushed its inquiry into the bill because the government purported to believe that the legislation required urgent consideration by the Senate. So the Senate committee rushed through its normal processes to cooperate with the government because it thought the legislation might get through the Senate. For reasons best known to Minister Tuckeyâwhich we will hear from speakers opposite laterâthe government did a complete backflip and failed to bring on the bill for its scheduled debate in June 1999. This is the bill that the minister told the Australian electorate, the industry and the workersâwho went out the back door because of his incompetence in WAâ was urgent. He says it is urgent and then withdraws the bill in June 1999! This delay meant that the Democrats, who everyone in the world knows oppose the RFA process, held the balance of power in the Senate when the bill was finally brought on for debate. So the bill was taken out and, it would seem, introduced just so the Democrats would be able to thwart it.

The bill was subject to protracted consideration by the Senate in September 1999. It was eventually passed on the combined vote of the coalition and Labor with 16 amendments. The key amendments were: the insertion of an object clauseâ

talk.start.para: âThe member opposite says `useless'.

(Mr Hollis)â Order! The member for Blair will be participating in this debate. I suggest that he contain his remarks until he makes his contribution and that the honourable member for Reid should ignore any interjections.

âSome would say, in trying to defend the minister and the government, that these amendments are useless. Quite frankly, wouldn't most people in the electorate think that you have an objects clause in a bill to explain just what it is supposed to accomplish. Is there anything wrong with the Australian parliament, elected by the people, having some right of parliamentary review, given that not all the RFAs were finalised at the time and given that, in Western Australia in particular, it went down the gurgler, dropped by all political parties, including that of some members opposite?

speech.para: There was a call for a clarification of compensation provisions. The Labor Party thought that, if we were going to compensate people in this industry, there should be good reasons why they are compensated. The Australian people should know why we are giving money to timber yards, to a variety of sawmillers and to this or that bloke around the country. The Australian taxpayer just does not want to give them a blank cheque, and that is what the government wanted. It is clear from the actions undertaken by the federal government that they did not want any clarification of what the compensation was for. It was not as a result of them having a lack of planning approval or something.

Another amendment is in relation to the need for structural adjustment funding for timber firms and workers to accompany each RFA. Labor says that we should not have a narrow, short analysis of what FISAP money can be utilised for. I was at the TCA conference earlier this year and, after the minister spoke, a clear point was made by the industry that they do not share his very narrow, limited, restricted analysis of what FISAP money should be utilised for. They say that people are going out the back door, and the minister can get up on his soapbox for the next 20 years, for all they care, but people do go out of the industry and they need assistance.

The establishment of a forest database was the end of the world as well, as far as the government was concerned. There is an amendment in relation to the continuing Commonwealth oversight of listed world heritage areas and Ramsar wetlands, as provided for in other government legislation. Perhaps the minister could not stop Senator Hill with regard to that other government legislation, but the fact of life is that it is on the public record. It is effective; it is part of the law of this country. Finally, there is an amendment in relation to the establishment of a wood and paper industry council to drive further investment in industry development.

The government rejected each and every amendment, even ones that the minister himself admitted were innocuous. One has to ask oneself why, if they are ineffective, a waste of time or whatever. Let us just accept for the sake of argument that the minister has some case: you really have to ask yourself why the government would try to undermine the possibility of bipartisan support for legislation by being just a complete blocker and an obstructionist to agreement. Of course, the government made another amendment of its own: to establish an advisory council. The Senate then insisted on its original amendments and substituted Labor's proposed wood and paper industry council for the minister's advisory council. The minister, ever conciliatory, then moved that the bill be set aside. He essentially halted any further debate. That was the end of the process.

Despite changed circumstances in the interim, the minister made no attempt to reintroduce the bill until late August, in the dying days of the current parliament. I admit his attendance at the TCA conference was rather truncated; it was rather short. He was not there for that much of the conference, but the industry well and truly knows, and he has known since March this year, that Labor has made a firm indication that, in the context of the collapse of the Western Australian agreement, there was no need for our disallowance resolution and that Labor essentially supported an RFA bill. We ask ourselves: are we convinced that he could not get it up the list in the Senate? Can we really be assured that it was a lack of power on his part that he could not get it past Senator Hill? Can we really believe that, on legislation that is so important to this industry, he could not get a bill here six or seven months after he well and truly knew there is support for it?

He could have tested us in that period. He could have found out whether we really were genuinely supportive. He could have actually exposed us if there were any doubt. But he has chosen to bring this bill into parliament in the dying days of the parliament to try to create a situation where it cannot be considered, so he can try to manipulate a scene showing that Labor is not supportive. He took no notice of my public indication six months ago that the completion of the RFA process and the outcome in WA had significantly improved the chances for approval.

The current bill is essentially the same as the earlier legislation that has twice been before the parliament. It does incorporate some modest but welcome changes to the earlier bill by inserting an objects clauseâ the end of the world when it was considered in previous legislation. The collapse of Western civilisation was going to occur if there was an objects clause, but I notice that there is one in this government bill. The bill also details the requirements for RFA amendments to RFAs and that RFA annual reports and five-yearly review reports to be tabled in the parliament within set time limits and details the establishment of a forest and wood products council.

While we may have chosen slightly different terminology, the opposition welcomes those changes. We are happy to accept them unamended and to not get in the way, not cause delays and not undermine the possibility of getting the legislation through with bipartisan support. To facilitate the business of parliament, we will not be moving any amendments in the consideration in detail stage of debate in this Houseâno amendment whatsoever will be moved in this House. We will be discussing with the government a small number of amendments that we think would improve the bill and that we propose to move in the Senate. I want to say, in the context of who is responsible for the situation we have now reached, that the valuable time of this parliament is being taken up with consideration of an electoral bill about the internal problems of the Liberal Party. We are spending valuable time this week in the dying days of this parliament on whether the federal Liberal Party can get finance from the state branches of the Liberal Party. They cannot sort out their own internal problemsâ

talk.start.para: âI rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is a bill about trees, not about other bills that are in dispute in the Senate.
âI am sure that the member for Reid will come back to the debate.

âWith regard to the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, there is going to be debate in this country about who is responsible if this bill does not get through parliament. I am saying quite clearly that one of the reasons that this bill might not get through this parliament is that we are wasting our time on the internal problems of the Liberal Party. The situation is that there is very limited time. This bill is now before us in the House of Representatives, one day before the Senate is probably going to finish up.

speech.para: I acknowledge that, to try to cover himself, the minister last night brought the bill forward a day, so you can argue he has introduced it a day before the Senate is to consider it. That is a bit better than the morning of the same day. But I think we all know that, whether or not you agree with the minor parties, they have a say in this process in this country. People do vote for them; they have got a number of senators. In the normal processes, they have got some right to have their say on legislation, and the minister well and truly knew when he started this process that they would endeavour to make a contribution on this legislation. Where matters are contentious and controversial, he will not be able to cite many instances where debate is guillotined and smashed over by the government and the opposition in the Senate, because he knows the way the Senate works. So one has to question why we have this important piece of legislation coming to this parliament so late in the day.

I turn now to the opposition's second reading amendment, which has been distributed. It essentially refers to the coalition's mishandling of structural adjustment funding under the FISAP program. In December 1995âI think everyone realises how long ago that isâthe former Labor government set aside $107 million in funding to help the industry adjust to reduced harvesting under the national RFA progress. One of the first actions of the new, supposedly pro-industry coalition government was to cut $6 million out of that funding in the budget of July 1996. They get on the soap box or on a stump out in the forest and talk about how they are pro the industry, et cetera, but they could not wait to reduce that $107 million of FISAP money by $6 million. But five years later, after all the speeches and the meetings in country towns, all the rhetoric at furniture and hardwoods conferences around the country, it is appalling that nearly three-quartersâthat is, $75 millionâof the remaining funding for New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia remains unspent in Commonwealth coffers.

Several factors have contributed to this situation. There was the minister's suspension of all funding to New South Wales in November 1998, which he did not restore until April this yearâquite an undermining of the industry's interests, I would have thought. There were delays with the finalisation of the RFA process, such as the minister's tactics in New South Wales. I have to say that in New South Wales, as in Western Australia, there was some commonsense in the coalition. He gave them his riding instructions; he told the New South Wales coalition what they should do on this and what he thought of forestry. And when it came to a test in the New South Wales parliament, he was left on the beach; he was ditched. They voted with the Labor government on the outcomes in that state.

Then there was his refusal to hand over $15 million owing to Western Australia as part of his war with successive Western Australian state governments. Whether it is Court or Gallop, it does not make any differenceâthey are all wrong. There is only one person in the whole country who understands the interests of the industry. The whole WA cabinet is wrong, everyone is out of kilter, and there is only one person who understands it. If the industry suffers collateral damage, if people cannot be assisted when they need it, bad luckâthey are the innocent bystander victims; and he will have a hard line and be very narrow and restricted in how he assists industry when people are going out the door.

We are repeatedly told that FISAP funds will flow `in the near future'. And, with monotonous regularity, the coalition fails to deliver. The minister has repeatedly expressed opposition to business exit assistance and workers' assistance elements of FISAP. That is a view he is entitled to, but I can assure him that it is not a very popular view with a lot of people who traditionally support this government and who know the realities out there. They say, `Let's not get too technical, let's not get too legalistic, let's not just try to hold the line for the sake of being difficult and obstinate; let's see what the industry needs.' They know that we need a more liberal interpretation of what the industry requires and we need to assist people whose future livelihood is in great danger.

Labor is also concerned about the minister's unwillingness to help the industry in Victoria work through the adjustment process required because of the new sustainable yield system that has been developed in the state. This follows a variety of blues with the previous Liberal state government ministers. They did not know anything about forestry as well; they were all dunderheads, apparently. Anyway, we have had a change of government there and they are trying to work their way through sustainable yield. Despite the attempts of the government to say that they have got nothing to do with it, that they are irrelevant and it is all the problem of the new government in Victoria, that new system is clearly required by the Commonwealth as part of the signed RFAs. It is clearly a requisite; it is part of what is needed. The minister pretends it is nothing to do with him. Victoria was shortchanged in the first place and needs help to work through its current difficulties. It is time coalition federal MPs from Victoria stood up to the minister and demanded that he helped the industry.

In conclusion, the opposition seeks to ensure that this bill goes through parliament. I think people watching this process will judge us to have been extremely reasonable in reducing amendments from 16 to four. We no longer wish to pursue a disallowance resolution with regard to a number of RFAs around this country. What we said when it was last debated, what is on the public record and in the press releases we have issued, has been borne out. Our opposition essentially related to the process in Western Australia where there was a view that CALM had been, let us say, too overwhelming in the process, too strong in driving their outcomes and decisions and what they thought should happen, and essentially walked over other interests in the process. We have been vindicated: the Western Australia agreement went down the spout big timeâthere was no-one left defending it. So we are vindicated in saying that this parliament, elected by the people of the country, should have some oversight of what happens in the RFA process. We could not give the minister opposite a blank cheque and just let him get what he wanted regardless of other players and interests in the industry. I reiterate that we seem to have had a few people who agreed with us at the end of the day. We seem to have had the agreement of virtually the whole of the parliament in Western Australia, regardless of what party they were in. We seem to have had divisions in the Liberal Party and breakaway parties that left them over the matter. We seem to have had an overwhelming majority of the Western Australian people saying that process was wrong.

Today, many months afterwards, we are not quibbling over the wording of the few crumbs that the government has given us in regard to our previous amendments. We are not seeking to delay debates in this House with as many speakers as possible who are interested in this matter. We have constrained them; we have reduced the number of speakers. We are not moving amendments in this House, except for the second reading position in regard to FISAP. The people will judge whether it is reasonable and fair that, at two minutes to midnight, the government expect a very controversial piece of legislation to be rammed through the parliament at the same time as they seek to take up our valuable time sorting out their problems with Senator Brandis and Senator Mason. We have had the ridiculous situation where two Queensland Liberal senators basically have told the Prime Minister of this country to go jump. Those two Liberal senators have said, `We don't care what the federal Liberal Party says about electoral funding, we are going to send this off to a Senate committee to make sure that we try to be as difficult as possible in getting through our own government's legislation.' We are spending the last week of parliament on whether Lynton Crosby can get some money off the federal taxpayer to finance the Liberal Party or whether the state branches are right in saying, `We are bankrupt, we need the money; give it to us, please.'

âWe had more farewells in that speech from the member for Reid than from Dame Joan. It went on and on. There was a series of lame excuses from the member for Reid about why his organisation, the Australian Labor Party, is twisting on a hook not to support the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 while trying to maintain a facade of support for it. He mentioned that people have observed the process. We should look at Bills Digest, because someone has been observing this process and reporting on it. In the Bills Digest the writer has pointed out how many sticking points there were between the Labor Party, other interests in the Senate and the government in its endeavours to get through the former Regional Forest Agreements Bill. In the concluding comments on this amended bill, the Bills Digest states:

quote.para: The bill has been modified since its introduction in 1998; however, none of the amendments make any significant concessions toward the Senate's previous position over the sticking points outlined earlier in the Bills Digest. The only immediate practical implication of a failure to pass the bill is the doubt which would remain over the compensation provisions of the various RFAs about whether they are legally enforceable. On the other hand, passing the bill would illegally reinforce the RFA compensation provisions and modify the operation of the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act and the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

speech.para: That writer says that there is virtually no difference, yet there has been an effort by the member opposite to make out that there are significant differences.

We have had an effort by the member opposite to try to make out that there are significant differences. He has also endeavoured to say, as did Tasmanian senator Kerry O'Brien, that Labor in fact passed this legislation. They have tried to maintain this fiction that they passed it. They did not pass it; they put strictures on it that gave it no value as far as the industry is concerned. We had Senator Kerry O'Brien writing to the North Eastern Advertiser saying that the Senate passed the government's RFA legislation last year. That is a nonsense. They did not. They provided a lead weight around its neck. They endeavoured to make sure it was going to cause the industry as much pain and difficulty as possible and they endeavoured to say that that was in fact supporting the legislation. If they were truly supporting the legislation, they would have supported it unamended or without including the nonsense about requiring the parliament to overview it and also without objects clauses and other difficulties like that which merely provide legal openings for such agreements to be challenged.

The purpose of providing these agreements is to provide surety. These regional forest agreements have three different elements. They provide surety for economic, environmental and social reasons. In the NAFI News, the industry publication, Mr Ferguson, the member for Reid, who just a minute ago was saying that the government could have had any opportunity to have this passed and that the Labor Party is supportive of this, it is reported that:

quote.para: Mr Ferguson provided further clarification of the ALP's position during parliamentary debate dealing with the increase in the government's contribution to the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

speech.para: That is in relation to this bill. It continues:

quote.para: In the aftermath of the Western Australian election, Labor's fundamental need to block this legislation has disappeared.

speech.para: He is admitting that they were trying to block the legislation and now, of course, after the Western Australian election he is saying that their fundamental need to block this legislation has disappeared. The article goes on:

quote.para: It is very clear, he said, that our reasons for opposing this legislation have disappeared.

speech.para: They speak with forked tongue on this issue every time. The last five minutes of the speech from the member opposite was really a series of justifications as to why he is going to turn Bob Brown and other people loose in the Senate tonight, or whenever this bill is discussed, and allow them to filibuster and carry on so that this bill can die a death and he can maintain the fiction of his support while he ensures that this bill goes down the gurgler.

NAFI has been encouraged by his attitude, and I hope that he will come round; that he will ensure that this bill goes through. It is certainly within the province of the Labor Party to ensure that. They do not have to let Bob Brown off the leash with all of his communist blatherings. We can have a reasonable debate because, according to the members opposite, there is a degree of agreement on this. Despite their flip-flopping, the flop has become a flip and we are in a position where we are supposedly in agreement. I would like to see if that is the position; if the Labor Party expedites the process of this bill and we see it pass into law.
I would like, just for the sake of the debate, to put into larger detail what was said within the NAFI News. It said:

quote.para: Recent statements by the opposition spokesman on forestry and conservation, Laurie Ferguson, have rekindled the forest industry's hopes of maintaining a bipartisan approach to forest policy at the national level. Speaking at the recent Timber Communities Australia Conference and subsequently in the parliament, Mr Ferguson confirmed that the opposition will support the passage of the Regional Forest Agreement Bill.
The bill has been laid aside by the government following repeated attempts by the ALP to make amendments to the bill which were unacceptable to the governmentâ

speech.para: As we have said, NAFI was also unhappy with the proposed amendments because they would have made every RFA subject to review by the parliament. NAFI is not opposed to public involvement in and scrutiny of the RFA process, but the purpose of the process was to provide for rational science based decision making rather than the simplistic emotive basis which we see when complex issues become political footballs.

Speaking of political footballs, members opposite have been kicking this bill all over the place. They have done it now since 1998. They have been basically unfaithful to their electorates in failing to support this bill. We did see the vote on the amendments. When the vote on the amendments came through, the member who is going to speak next, the member for McMillan, was not present. He was missing in action on that occasion. Perhaps in this debate we can hear from him as to why that was. If he were legitimately representing the needs of his electorate, he would have been voting on this side where there were 69 ayes, where people were supporting the passage of the bill, instead of being on the side of the noes, where people were stopping the bill and stopping the legitimate aspirations of these very important timber communities. The people who were on the side of the noes included many members opposite, but mysteriously the member for McMillan was not present on that occasion.

Of course, what we are supporting here is science based legislation. The member for Reid went on about the Western Australian situation. I think that is illustrative of the whole timber issue becoming a political one and not a science based one. That is when it becomes a problem. The whole purpose of an RFA is to take the politics out of it, to establish what is scientifically sustainable and then to proceed with it. Where have we seen that not in evidence? It is not in evidence in the subsequent actions in Western Australia, and it is not in evidence in Queensland, where there is no agreement. There is no agreement in Queensland because of a slimy, political deal done between vested interests on the Queensland Timber Board, the state Labor government and representatives of organisations referring to themselves as conservationists. There are plenty of conservationists in the timber industry, and they do not support the South-East Queensland forest agreement, which was the creation of the Beattie government. It is an absolute abomination. It has no basis in science.

At present, operations in Queensland are relying on transport subsidies, which are provided for a limited period of only three years, to make their operations viable so that they can seek from a vastly reduced number of native forests the timber that they need to continue to operate over a period of 25 yearsâsupposedly while we build a resource of new hardwood plantations. There is no person who has anything to do with the timber industry in Queensland who realistically believes that there is going to be a single millable log available from those plantations. How many years has it been now? It has probably been two years since the signing of the South-East Queensland forest agreement. The very few plantations that are around supposedly providing native hardwood for this ridiculous process have still got seedlings that would not come up to my knee. No trial in Queensland at any time in the past has produced a millable log, and everyone in the Queensland industry knows it.

What we have is an agreement with the Queensland government, which is going to sponsor the export of Queensland jobs to places like Malaysia and Indonesia, where, in the name of conservation, we are going to strip down trees with no regime of management to bring timber into Australia to prop up the Queensland timber industry when we have perfectly good timber resources in our state that are going begging, that are not being used appropriately and that all have a sustainable level of use. This is happening in the name of an agreement between the Australian Labor Party and the Greens. They are after Greens preferences, and that is what the process is about.

As far as Peter Beattie and the member for Reid are concerned, the timber industry in Queensland can go down the chute. They can kiss their jobs goodbye. Towns like Linville, where there is a perfectly reliable timber mill ready to operateâand it is operating at present but on borrowed timeâare heading into history, and everyone in that community who is reliant on that mill for their job knows it. They can thank Peter Beattie, the Premier of Queensland, for the uncertainty about their jobs. If a proper regional forest agreement had been reached in that state and if there had been a commitment by the Australian Labor Party to the regional forest agreement process, we would have sustainable jobs. We would have sustainable forest industries. We would have sustainable social access to these regions for recreational use and those kinds of things, but none of those opportunities have been provided because of the intransigence of the Beattie government and its total focusâits obsessionâwith keeping the green movement under its thumb and within its scope.

What is absurd is that the real conservationists, who know we have to come to a sustainable level of use based on science, are crying tears of blood over this nonsense. We are putting this into an absolute limbo land. What will happen in the meantime while we keep forest areas like the Conondale Ranges locked up? What is going to happen to them? There is nobody providing firebreaks anymore. There is nobody ready to provide an adequate fire response if something does happen. That is appalling when we face one of the greatest fire threats ever. That is thanks to Peter Beattie and the Queensland government, the nonsense of the South-East Queensland Forest Agreement and the nonsense of the feigned support from members opposite of this Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001. Under its fallacious South-East Queensland Forest Agreement Bill, the Queensland government promised that it would provide 100 extra forest management workers. That did not happen. It did not provide 100 extra workers. Rather, it took 100 workers away in its last budget. It is just a pathetic abomination. Whichever way you look at itâas a resource for timber production purposes or as a resource from an environmental standpointâthat resource is placed at risk because it may be burnt out as a result.

While the Premier of Queensland was taking away 100 of the very jobs where he had promised an extra 100, I have to compliment the Minister for Forestry and Conservation in this place because he went ahead with FISAP grants to Queensland, despite the failure of that state to come up with a regional forest agreement. Near my electorate is the Australian Hardboards Ltd plant at Bundamba. Some $666,000 of that money went into that plant to provide an I-beam production facility. That will provide jobs in my electorate and in the neighbouring electorate of Oxley for some time to come. This minister is supporting the industry. It is absolutely disgusting that members opposite have done so much to try to stall this legislation and to try to make it unworkable because of the nonsense of this objects clause, providing worm holes for lawyers to take this agreement apart.

The people of Australia expect political parties to be genuine in expressing their viewpoint. The Labor Party has not been genuine. It has only been genuine in serving its own needs. These regional forest agreements support communities that need to look to the future, that need some surety and a sense of direction from government. They are not getting it from the Australian Labor Party. They are being sold down the river, and I condemn those opposite for it.

talk.start.para: âI have been looking forward to making my contribution to the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001. We have heard all sorts of comments from those opposite today as to how regional forestry agreements are about people and communities, but these are the things which those opposite are not concerned about. Their view of forestry is all about making profits for companies and has nothing to do with those small country towns that depend on the timber industry for their livelihoods. Whenever there is any sort of discussion about forestry, those opposite give no recognition at all to how important the timber industry is to those communities which depend on it, those regional communities covered by the regional forestry agreements we are talking about today. Despite all of the rhetoric, all of the words and all of the shrill talk from the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, his period as minister for forestry will be remembered as a period of lost opportunity, a time when there was plenty of rhetoric around, plenty of words said and plenty of promises made, but nothing committed to, or done, to improve the lot of timber workers and their families.

speech.para: There has been discussion already in relation to who was present for the debate on the regional forestry agreements legislation. I am very happy to say where I was. Let me be very plain about this: I was not in the House. I was at a place called Swifts Creek in the Tambo Valley in far East Gippsland, working with timber workers and their communities to try to help them to recover from the closure of the timber mill in that town. I say to those opposite who shriek, yell, carry on and act like a pack of clowns that there was someone with me at that meeting in Swifts Creek. It was David Treasure.

talk.start.para: (Mrs De-Anne Kelly)âOrder! The chair has allowed interjection from both sides and does not need advice from those in the chamber. If members wish to raise a point of order, they should do so.

âI do raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. The interjections that have been coming from your right have far outweighed anything that occurred while the previous speaker was making his speech. I suggest that you call them to order.
âThere have been a lot of interjections from both sides. I take the point, though, that the member for McMillan should be allowed to speak without too unreasonable a level of interjection.

âI remind those opposite that when I went to that public meeting in Swifts Creek in the Tambo Valley to discuss the closure of the timber mill there was someone at that meeting who was also in politics: the then state member for Gippsland East, David Treasureâ`hidden Treasure', as we used to refer to him. He was not standing with those people in Swifts Creek in relation to the closure of their timber mill. He was doing what Liberal-National party members opposite always do in these circumstancesâ being an apologist for the company. He said, `It is a restructure. These are just commercial prerogatives.' Too bad for the people of Swifts Creek! Too bad that they have lost the only employer in their town! This is the typical Liberal-National Party approach when it comes to the timber industry: `Let the companies do whatever they want. Let them carry out whatever restructures, commercial arrangements or dodgy deals they will come up with in relation to the way they structure their enterprises, and we will just be apologists for them.' That is the Liberal-National Party way.

speech.para: Let me give the member for Eden-Monaro and the member for McEwen, who thinks this is all so hysterical, a tip. David Treasure was not re-elected. Everyone thought there was no chance in a million years that the National Party would lose the seat of Gippsland East, but it did. The voters elected an Independent to that seat. Swifts Creek was pretty important in terms of kicking out David Treasure and changing voting patterns. People want representatives who will stand with them and their communities, deliver for their communities and understand the importance of the jobs associated with the timber industry in places such as Swifts Creek, parts of my electorate, parts of East Gippsland and other places in rural and regional Australia which depend on this industry.

We have always had a different view. We have always understood the importance of regional forestry agreements to people and to communitiesâto contractors and people in small business who depend on the industry for their livelihood. It is a very different approach from that taken by our opponents, who are long on rhetoric, short on action and very keen to take the company's side when it comes down to whose interests will be looked afterâthose of the company, the workers, the communities or the small business people who depend on this industry for their livelihood. We understand very starkly that, when push comes to shove, we on this side of the House will be standing with those people, while those on the other side of the House will be standing with the timber companies, who seek to make a lot of moneyâ and that is fair enough; Their objective is to make a lot of money. Our interest is with those workers, communities, small business people and contractors, because they are the people we seek to represent in this place.

It should be noted that regional forestry agreements were first put in place by the Keating Labor government. They were a tremendous initiative and a way of breaking the deadlock which existed between competing interests in the industry and in the environment movement. They were a breakthrough. They were important to Australia's national development and incredibly important for the industry. We have seen a lot of progress and development take place since the Keating government introduced regional forestry agreements.

We have had some discussion about Labor's position in relation to the regional forestry agreements legislation. Let me make it plain that we have always sought to have a bipartisan view in relation to regional forestry agreements legislation. We have understood the importance of having a bipartisan position in relation to this industry. It has been our political opponents, the Liberal and National parties, who have sought to exploit this issue and gain political advantage from it. Those people should be condemned for their pettiness in relation to this. They are long on rhetoric but short on bipartisanship. People in rural communities, especially those dependent on the timber industry for their livelihoods, do not want to hear the shrill rantings that we always get from the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. They do not want to see partisanship and attempts to score points off someone. They want to see us working together to try to get some benefits for their industry and to try to get value adding and growthâsome of those high-skilled, high-wage jobsâinto the timber industry.

People want to be able to stay in rural and regional communities. They want to be able to stay in those places where the timber industry is strong and is an employer. And the only way we can make that happen is by making sure that we link resource security to job security and that we link all those things together into value adding, so we end up not only with the lowest possible price for our resource but also with a value adding chain which creates opportunity in those rural and regional communities. We on this side of the House have always offered a bipartisan position in relation to this legislation. All that members on the other side of the House have offered is a sneaky approach to try to get some sort of political advantage out of their approach to the forest and forest products sector.

Plainly, people are fed up to the back teeth with the hysterical rantings and carry-on from people like the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, the member for McEwen and the member for Eden-Monaroâall those people who carry on about the forest industry but do not actually deliver on any of the things they talk a lot about. People want to see bipartisanship and cooperation. What we are offering the government, by supporting this legislation in the House today, is an opportunity to pass this legislation, which is very important to the people who rely on the timber industry for their livelihoods. We have made that offer to the government very deliberately. The shadow minister for forestry, Laurie Ferguson, made that very plain public commitment in March this year, I think. And here we are, ages since that happened. Months and months have passed since Laurie Ferguson, the member for Reid and shadow minister for forestry and conservation, made that public offer to help get this legislation through and to provide that resource securityâthat legislative underpinningâfor this industry. The Minister for Forestry and Conservation has sat on his hands. Perhaps he has been distracted. Perhaps he has been busy with a few other things and acting on behalf of a few other interests. Maybe he has been too busy to focus on the main game. I suppose that is a question which other people are going to have to ask him.

The thing that we are most concerned about is getting this legislation through. The member for Reid, the shadow minister for conservation and forestry, said that we are moving some very minor amendments in relation to this legislation which we think will improve it. It is really in the government's hands as to whether or not we see the passage of this legislation. There has been some discussion already about what the government's real priorities are in terms of its legislative program. Let me state plainly for the member for McEwen and the member for Eden-Monaro that, if this legislation is not passed, they will have to go back to their electorates and explain to them why the Liberal Party thought it was more important to pass a piece of legislation which guaranteed $15 million to the Liberal Party secretariat to help sort out its internal problems as opposed to dealing with this legislation which deals with the regional forestry agreements, which is what we are supposed to be discussing today. They will have to go back to their electorates and explain why that slimy piece of legislation was more important than the regional forestry agreements, which support so much employment in their electoral districts. They are the ones who will have to explain why their political partyâthe political party which promises so much and delivers so littleâhas prioritised this Liberal Party bill ahead of the regional forestry agreements legislation. They are the ones who will have to wear it in their electoral districts.

Let me be very straightforward about this: people know that this government has had months and months to deal with this legislation. People know that the shadow minister for forestry and conservation has put on the public record Labor's commitment to passing this legislation. And people know the Minister for Forestry and Conservation too well. They understand that, if this bill is not passed in the Senate, it will be all about the Liberal and National parties seeking to be partisan in their approach and not doing the right thing by timber workers and their communities. The Liberal and National parties will have to go back and explain that to the timber mill owners; they will have to go back and explain it to the timber workers; they will have to go back and explain it to the forest contractors; they will have to go back and explain it to the transport operators in their electorates; and to those small business people who depend on this sector for their livelihoods.

The Liberal and National parties should be put on notice in relation to this legislation. They do a lot of talking. They say, `Look, we are really with you; we're on your side,' but, in truth, we all know that they are not. Increasingly, people know that, although the Liberal and National parties always talk about their commitment, when it comes to delivering, when it comes to standing with people instead of the interests of companies, it is never those people who stand with timber workers; it is always those people on this side of the House who are prepared to stand up and be advocates for those people and not leave them in the lurch, which is exactly the approach that people want to see. People do not want to see more of the shrill rantings of the Liberal and National parties in relation to this matter. They want to see people deliver, and deliver in a bipartisan way.

So members opposite have their opportunity. They have been talking about this bill. The Minister for Forestry and Conservation and I have exchanged some correspondence in relation to the regional forest agreements legislation. Whilst the Minister for Forestry and Conservation regularly stands up in this place and says, `I've never received anything from the member for McMillan in relation to forestry,' and whilst we all get a chuckle out of how ridiculous that makes him sound, the truth is that this is an old issue. I wrote to the minister in relation to the regional forestry agreements in Gippsland and the minister wrote back to me on 30 September 1999. He said:
Dear Mr Zahraâ
I am surprised that he did not cross it out and write, `Dear Christian'â
Thank you for your letter of 21 September and your support for the regional forestry agreement process in Gippsland.
The minister ends the letter with this statement, which I think shows that the Liberal and National parties say one thing and they do something else:
I agree with your view that this is an issue above the pettiness of partisan politics.

What a joke! What a farce from a man who has epitomised the lowliness of this debateâ a man who has done more during his term as Minister for Forestry and Conservation to end bipartisanship in relation to this issue than anyone else. This is from a man who has gone out of his way to pick fights with people, to condemn the industry, to condemn companies, to condemn timber workers and to go out of his way to insist to people that it is either his way or people get nothing; they get no support.

No-one in those regional and rural communities which depend on the timber industry wants to see that. They want to see bipartisanship, they want to see cooperation and they want to see someone actually understand the importance of providing support to this sector, to all of those people who are employed in it or who draw their livelihood from it. They do not want to see a situation where someone who just happens to be the minister says, `You either do it my way or you get no money,' and too bad for the timber communities who suffer, too bad for those people who have to go without, too bad just because the Minister for Forestry and Conservation wants to get 100 per cent of his way, just like he wanted to get 100 per cent of his way in Western Australia and just like he wanted to get 100 per cent of his way in Queensland.

Whilst the minister might enjoy that, it is not something that people want to see. People want to see some sense, some cooperation and some reasonableness in the way in which we deal with these issues. We on this side are very concerned about the administration of the FISAP program. Despite the fact that this money was allocated in 1995, some 75 per cent of it remained unallocated at the beginning of this year. The Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Program is an incredibly important program to those rural and regional communities that depend on the timber industry.

We want to see that money made available to provide support to people who are affected by any changes in the timber industry and we also want to see some of that FISAP money used strategically to provide for investments in value adding, to see more of an effort in the timber industry in relation to value adding and the creation of high-value, high-skill jobs in the timber industry. We do not want to see a timber industry which survives from year to year; we want to see a timber industry which grows and prospers and which increases the amount of value adding it does.

Whilst it might be funny and make for interesting commentary from time to time for the Minister for Forestry and Conservation to be in so much conflict so much of the time with state premiers and state ministers for forestry and conservation, it does not help those people and those communities on the ground. It does not help the timber industry one iota. It does not help them at all. It provides no relief at all for those families that depend on this industry for their livelihoods. Today I say to the minister: be true to what you said in that letter to me. Agree, like you said in that letter to me, that you think that this is an issue above the pettiness of partisan politics. If you believe that, you would expedite this process and see this as a great opportunity to pass the regional forestry agreements legislation and you would do everything you could to pass this through the Senate. Instead of prioritising a dirty, slimy, grubby Liberal Party funding piece of legislation which will deliver $15 million to Lynton Crosby at the national secretariat of the Liberal Partyâ

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Already on two occasions the previous speaker from the opposition and this speaker have had it pointed out to them that this is a bill about trees, regional forest agreements and matters of that nature. If there is another bill in the Senate, there is some argument, I think, in the standing orders that you do not refer to those bills other than when that debate is going on. All that the spokesman is trying to do is give enough excuses why his party intends not to support this legislation. But I request that he be required to come back to the legislation to which he is speaking.
âThe point of order is valid.

âPerhaps I could talk about some timber companiesâAPT Projects Pty Ltd, Western Australian Plant Farms or Rimble Pty Ltd; these are companies which have an interest in the timber industryâbut I will come back to my point, because it might be a little less uncomfortable for the Minister for Forestry and Conservation.

speech.para: What people want to see is an end to the rhetoric and they want to see some cooperation and some outcomes. This is a government which has done a great job in being partisan. It has done a great job in being divisive. It has done a great job in seeking to erode support from the timber industry. But it has not done a good job when it comes to supporting timberworkers. It has not done a good job when it comes to providing for any sort of security or plan for value adding for those people in the timber industry and forest products industry who depend on this industry for their livelihood. Whilst it might be funny sometimes for the Minister for Forestry and Conservation to get into fights with people and for the conflict to be in the newspapersâand he probably feels like a big manâit delivers nothing at all to those people in the timber industry who depend on this industry for their livelihood. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â We have just had 20 minutes of absolute rhetoric. Absolutely nothing was said about the Regional Forest Agreements Bill except for one single thing. The member for McMillan said only one thing about regional forest agreements and forestry in that 20 minutes of diatribe. He said that there should be more happening in the value adding area as opposed to the business exit area. His shadow minister, who spoke before him, castigated the minister for forestry by saying that we should not have moved funds from business exit to value adding. They cannot get even that part right. I will come back to the actions of the ALP, which are so hypocritical and so flip-flop it is not funny when it comes to this particular bill.

speech.para: The member for McMillan also declined to comment on the fact that on two occasions the ALP has rejected this legislation. He stands here saying, `Come on, get this legislation passed,' but he forgets to tell his electorate and he forgets to tell the people of Australia that twice over the last few years the ALP has rejected this legislation. When we do get around to voting, he scurries away and does not organise a pair so that he will be listed as voting against it; he does not even have the honour to do that. His poor old friend the member for Braddon and also the member for Lyons were left in here to vote against it; otherwise they would have been thrown out of the party. They were left holding the bag. The member for Braddon and the member for Lyons are constantly left holding the bag. They did not even know about amendments that their own party was going to move on this legislation yesterday. The shadow minister was behind the scenes quietly putting forward amendments for the Senate to deal with. He did not bring the amendments in here. He said, `These amendments are nothing, really.' If they are nothing, why doesn't he bring them into the House? Why aren't they part of this debate here? `Oh, no,' he says, `we will put that in the Senate.' There is another agenda in that. We have the member for McMillan saying, `We have to get this passed,' but in the Senate we will see the ALP doing some sort of deal with Bob Brownâwho would never want to see a single tree knocked down anywhere in the country by legitimate meansâ to possibly postpone this bill and then find some way to say, `It's the government's fault.' The member for McMillan said nothing. In 20 minutes he said nothing other than that aspect I just mentioned with regard to value adding and business exits.

The member for McMillan also said that RFAs were first approved under the Keating government. Not a single RFA was signed under the Keating government. He talked about all the development that took place under the Keating government. That is absolute rubbish. Under the Keating government, and the Hawke government before it, hundreds of timber workers were thrown out of their jobs and communities were virtually closed down. That is what occurred under them.

talk.start.para: âThey were here protesting.

âAs the member for McEwen reminds me, all the trucks were lined up around Parliament House, protesting. That was under a Labor government, when all the workers were getting thrown out. I am not sure which school the member for McMillan was in at the time, but he obviously did not get around to reading the newspapers to work out that what was happening under a Labor government at that time was closing the industry down. It has only been under the coalition government that we have finally got some RFAs signed. We have seen some sensible ones in some cases, but not the best results that I would have liked to have seen in other ones. Let me just elaborate on that in relation to my electorate of Eden-Monaro.

speech.para: This legislation is all about guaranteeing the RFAs that subsequently have been signed. The first RFA that was signedâI have spoken on this many times in this House because this legislation keeps coming back and the ALP keeps refusing itâwas the Eden RFA. That was a prime example of how the ALP played political science with the RFA rather than practical science. This is what the RFA process is all about: it is not a political process; it is a scientific process. We went right through a scientific process. We had all the various science related people lined up doing all their work. We were going through that in a very strategic way, bit by bit. We got about 75 to 80 per cent of the way through the scientific process and what happened? Bob Carr walked into the parliament in New South Wales and put through legislation locking up all the forest areas into national parks. It was a fait accompli; the RFA became totally useless. What was there to sign? There was nothing to sign any more because the New South Wales government basically walked away from the RFA process and put through legislation locking everything up. He was virtually saying, `That's it. Bad luck!' If the minister of the day, Minister Tuckey, had sat back and accepted that, we would have lost a lot more jobs than had already been lost out of the Eden area. But we said, `No. You have defied the RFA process. You have passed legislation locking forests all up into national parks and as a consequence there are going to be even bigger job losses than we have already seen there.' We haggled with them and haggled with them. Finally they made some amendments and we were able to save a few jobs.

One would think that Bob Carr would have learnt his lesson. It was exposed how he had gone outside the RFA process by putting that legislation through and totally ignoring the practical science. Along came the southern RFA, which covers the other part of my electorate. We went right through the scientific process of that as well. This time we actually got to the end of it; we did not get to only 75 to 80 per cent of the way through before Carr raced off and put through legislation.

With respect to the southern RFA, we actually got right through the scientific process and down to final negotiations between the federal government and the state government. The federal government and the state government were getting pretty close to the mark. We believed that there needed to be a bit more timber available than the state government did, but there were not huge differences. In fact, the state government officials finally decided on what they were going to put to the government as their position. It was not quite what the Commonwealth wanted, but it was reasonably close. They put it forward with all the scientific evidence as to why it was a good result. And what occurred? Bob Carr just pulled out a big black pen and said, `No, knock quite a few thousand cubic metres off that.' There was a scientific reason behind that: a political scientific reason. He got out the black pen and put it through what was going to be available.

talk.start.para: âAbout 10,000 cubic metres.

âThat is right. As the minister reminds me, it was close to 10,000 cubic metres less than his officials and all the science said it was possible for a sustainable industry in the southern RFA to produce. At the stroke of a pen, Carr knocked off 10,000 cubic metres, which involves a lot of jobs. Earlier in the debate, we heard the sanctimonious comments of the member for McMillan about the loss of jobs. What would he know? I am sure he was not racing up from Victoria to say to Bob Carr, `I stand for looking after our rural communities. I stand for not allowing any jobs to be lost. I stand behind the timber workers,' as he said earlier. What a load of garbage! Instead, those opposite watched the timber workers go straight into the Centrelink office and onto the dole. That is what the Labor Party's policy on timber was. That is exactly what was about to happen in my electorate with the southern RFA.

speech.para: Fortunately, once again the minister for forestry stood his ground and said, `There's no way in the world we will sign an RFA when all the science says one thing but Bob Carr at the stroke of a pen knocks off 10,000 cubic metres and along with it a couple of hundred jobs.' Wilson Tuckey would not agree to that. We held back the FISAP money. Why wouldn't we hold back the FISAP money under those circumstances and say that we would provide money for business assistance when the New South Wales government came clean and did something in accordance with the RFA process, not in accordance with some political process? We held back, negotiated and said, `No way.' We managed to get back about 5,000 cubic metresâ

talk.start.para: âSix thousand.

âWe managed to get back close to 6,000 cubic metres of the 10,000 cubic metres lost. We wanted the full 10,000 cubic metres. In fact, we wanted a little bit more than the 10,000 in the first place. We were prepared to accept 10,000, but we dragged back 6,000. Everybody would agree that every thousand cubic metres means 17 jobs. By digging our heels in and saying, `No way, Bob Carr,' we were working not with political science but with practical science and real science, because we wanted that extra wood. We finally got the 6,000 cubic metres back and basically saved 100 jobs in my electorate. If we had sat back and let the ALP do what it wanted, which is what the member for McMillan seems to think we should have done, another 100 jobs would have been lost in my electorate. That is 100 jobs too many to lose, because the area cannot afford to lose those jobs.

speech.para: We would have had a good balance, but this whole issue has been totally taken over by politics for far too long. For over a decade, it has been politics all the way. Agreements are reached and then governments back off and do something else. The only people who are hurt are those people in the timber industry and the towns that only survive because those industries are there. We have ended up with RFAs that we are accepting. It is now crucial that this legislation is passed, because this legislation guarantees those RFAs.

The history of the ALP in relation to this legislation is absolutely pathetic. Twice they have knocked it back. They have constantly played politics with it and flip-flopped from one position to another. They say they will support it and then they say they will not. Their members run around the forests saying to the workers, `We are with you,' and then they come back here and knock off the legislation. This has been going on forever in that sense.

In the 1996 federal election campaign the previous member for Eden-Monaro was a prime suspect for doing that sort of thing. He used to race around to the timber workers and say, `I am a great mate of the timber workers.' Then he would whiz up the coast somewhere and talk to the extreme green movement and say, `I am with you.' In the 1996 campaign he actually got caught out, because he wrote a letter to the timber workers saying one thing and another letter to the extreme Greens saying the complete opposite on the same subject. We happened to get hold of those two letters. It was a bit embarrassing for him that he was saying one thing to one group and something totally different to the other.

That is exactly what the current shadow minister for forestry is doing. After rejecting this legislation twice, as we get closer to a federal election he is running around saying, `We actually really support this. We want to help the minister out and we want to get this legislation through.' He goes along to Timber Communities Australia and says, `We have to have bipartisan support for this legislation, and we agree.' But the ALP have stalled it all the way. Not only have they stalled it; they have knocked it off on two occasions. This is about the fourth time I have had to speak on this particular legislation, either on the legislation specifically or on the amendments. I do not want to have to speak on it again. We need this legislation to pass through the parliament. The legislation, as put forward by the government, ensures that the regional forestry agreements can be in place.

The process in relation to the FISAP money, which is going out to help investment, is correct. The applications have come in and are being assessed. There is sufficient money there to cover the applications that have been put forwardâand they are good applications relating to business development and value adding in the region. If we are to have companies investing many millions of dollars in further value adding in the hardwood timber industry, we have to have security of resource. The only way we can have security of resource is to have security of the regional forestry agreements that have been signed. We cannot have them overturned, as occurred under previous agreements. I give the example of Harris Daishowa in my electorate. On their wall are lovely copies of agreements, signed by Bob Hawke, and by Nick Greiner of the New South Wales state government, setting out what is guaranteed. Those agreements were not worth the paper they were printed on.

Can members imagine what overseas investors would have thought? They would have thought, `I have a piece of paper signed by the Prime Minister and by the Premier.' They would have thought they were pretty right to access a certain resource for a certain period of time. They would have thought they were pretty right with that sort of commitment. They would have gone in and made many millions of dollars of investment as a result of that. The agreement was not worth the paper it was printed on. It was undermined immediatelyâundermined by pressure on the ALP of the day from the extreme Greens.

This legislation is so important because the existing agreements could be torn up tomorrow by another government. We know the way in which the ALP have flip-flopped on this issue. If they ever managed to get into government, no doubt they would be backing off at a million miles an hour on some of those agreements. The actions of some of the state Labor governments are enough to show that that is what would occur. This legislation must be passed. We must get it through the parliament this week to ensure that it becomes law, so that security is there and the investment that many companies are willing to make in my area is made soon.

talk.start.para: âThe municipality of Latrobe was recently amalgamated into the electorate of Braddon. As the minister and those who have visited my region in north-west Tasmania may be aware, at Latrobe there is an excellent project called the Axemen's Hall of Fame and timberworks. It truly reflects the traditional and ongoing importance of the wood, paper and forestry industry in my neck of the woods in Tasmania. Tasmania signed an RFA in 1997. From the initial meanderings into this area commenced under the Labor government, in 1997 Tasmania signed under the Liberal government of Premier Tony Rundle. I noticed recently that, as he announced his retirement, he said that he regarded that as one of his crowning achievements.

speech.para: The RFA in Tasmania is very important in securing certainty with respect to resource and investment and the maintenance of an ecologically and environmentally sustainable industry. I wholeheartedly support the RFA process and I support the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001. I ask the Minister for Forestry and Conservation and members opposite to reconsider, in the spirit in which they are meant, the amendments that were put to them which related to those areas of the bill that were regarded as insufficient.

What perturbs me about this issue is that some members opposite spoke with me over two years ago about the RFA bills and their processes. We all support our forest, paper and wood industries; we all support our timber communities. We are very concerned that those communities have a sustainable future, that our environment is protected and that we can look forward to a future that involves downstream processing and value adding. We share those aspirations, just as we always have.

What tends to divide us is the term used by the previous speaker, the member for Eden-Monaroâthat people are playing politics with this issue. We on this side are accused of playing politics with it; we accuse the other side of playing politics with it. Either we are all right or we are all wrong. That is what concerns me about this matter. I can make out a case quite clearly to show that members opposite have been playing politics with this matter, for whatever reasons they deem are important to them. I can take members through the process that I saw and was part of, with all its problems, warts and all, in trying to come to an agreement by which we can all live so that our industries and our communities will be sustained into the future.

An RFA bill was introduced in June 1998 with little consultation with stakeholders. It was passed in the House of Representatives with Labor's support but was suspended because of the 1998 elections. And how quickly those three years have gone. It was reintroduced in March 1999, and I took part in that debate, as did members opposite. It was passed with Labor's support, but it was not until August 1999 that it was introduced into the Senate.

In September 1999 the Senate passed the bill with amendments. That is the right of a democratic process. We do not get it all right all the time. We have a right, as democratically elected members of this parliament, to peruse legislation, to seek amendments and to try to work through the legislation with its proponents to come to some form of consensus or agreement. That is how we do things, instead of pointing the finger every time and saying, `Because you don't agree with us, you're no good,' or `You're black instead of white.' It is ridiculous, but that was the process.

In October 1999 it was returned to the House of Representatives with amendments, as I said, but was rejected by the government. On 9 December the minister moved to lay aside the bill. Then another year went by. So where was the bill between December 1999 and September 2001? Why is it that, during the last minutes of this parliament, we have the bill before us? Why has it taken this long?

talk.start.para: âAre you going to support it?

âA bill I was debating with other members in this House in 1999 has not been seen again until today, two years later. I heard someone on the other side of the House scurrying about busily and asking, `Are you going to support it?' Yes, I am going to support it. That is why I am here. But why has the government waited until the last minute to try to again ram this legislation through, and expect it to go to the other house and have it rammed through there, when they know that Australians want to debate this bill, they have a right to have this bill debated, and that should be done? So what is going on here? It is either incompetence on the part of the minister, who is at the table, or it is testimony to his inability to deliver for the industry and the timber communities within his own coalition parties.

speech.para: Reference has been made to Labor machinations. The members opposite point the finger at the ALP. I can equally point the finger at the Liberal-National coalition. Talk about playing politics and hypocrisy! What about the resolution that was passed recently in the Senate? The minister's members supported Senator Brown and his resolution on old-growth forests. The minister can laugh. I did not hear much from him a couple of days laterâ

talk.start.para: âYes, you did.
âYou do not have control over what is going on in your own party, so do not point the finger at us.
âOrder! The honourable member for Braddon will direct his remarks through the chair.

âIndeed. Mr Speaker, that was no reflection on you. I say to the minister that pointing the finger at the ALP will not mitigate the blame for the incompetence that he has shown in the process of delivering this RFA bill. The fact that two years later we are standing here with two days notice to deal with this important legislation is a reflection on the minister and his incompetence on this issue.

speech.para: I said before that the RFA is very important to my community on the north-west coast of Tasmania and, indeed, to Tasmania as a whole. Instead of the minister coming to Tasmania and picking fights with people at public meetings, as he did on his last rant and rave through my state, he ought to deal with the issues that he is meant to be dealing with as a minister of the Crown. In Tasmania, we have a world-class forest reserve system: 40 per cent of Tasmania is reserved for conservation; 39 per cent of Tasmania's forests are reserved; through our RFA on old-growth forests, 86 per cent of our public land is reserved; 95 per cent of Tasmania's wilderness is reserved. The forest industry in Tasmania employs more than 8,200 people. As the minister knows, the industry contributes sales of over $1.1 billion to the state's economy. The industry has reinvested over $190 million a year for the past four years. But let us not kid ourselves. The RFA is about offering certitude to an industry and offering a sustainable environment and protection for important environmental areas of our state and Australia. We should be talking about jobs, and the jobs that I am talking about do not have to rely on a minister trying to ram through RFA legislation which he has had in his bag for three years and which he has waited until the last minute to deal with. We want value adding, and that is why these RFAs will exist.

We also put this on notice: the RFAs are important, but they should be about leading to downstream value adding and jobs. The minister should not play with the jobs of Tasmanians. He should not play with the forest jobs of people throughout Australia by hanging on to this bag of legislation and trying to ram it through this place, because he knows that people will not accept it. If the minister wants to pick a fight, he should at least have the gumption to come out and not scurry around at the end of the sittings of parliament.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A.

Mr HOWARD
