talk.start.para: â Very tragically, the tourism sector in this country is facing the biggest crisis in its relatively short history. Sadly, the Howard government refuses to even acknowledge the extent of the problem, let alone do something about it. This crisis is the equivalent of the pilots dispute and the Gulf War put together. The big difference is that we had every reason to be confident that the pilots dispute would be resolved in a reasonably short time; similarly we had every reason to believe that the Gulf War crisis would not be a long and protracted affair. In contrast, this is a present-day crisis that will reverberate through the industry for years to come. Some in the sector are talking about job losses of up to 80,000.

speech.para: This is no `little blip', as the Minister for Sport and Tourism described it; this is a crisis affecting real people, like Peppi Iovanelli, who runs one of Australia's largest dive operations. Peppi has been forced to lay off 10 fully qualified staff. He operates in the Cairns region and now has one of his boats for sale. Unlike the government, Labor have developed a rescue plan for the industry. Coupled with our plan to help get Ansett back in the airâand the minister for tourism has clearly demonstrated she does not understand the issues surrounding capacityâthe rescue plan is about providing cash-flow strapped small businesses with concessional loans. It is about providing additional funding to the Australian Tourist Commission, the body charged with marketing Australia overseas; and it is about doubling the amount of money available to fund tourism infrastructure projects in the region.

During question time today, the Treasurer made a fist of his attempt to portray Labor's plan as economically irresponsible and unfunded. When I did first-year macro-economics, I learned that, when economic activity rises, so does government revenue. At the same time, government outlays fall. Similarly, getting Ansett back in the air will add significantly to the value of Sydney airport when it is eventually sold.

There is no question about our ability to fund Labor's package; the big question today is this: what is the government's plan for the tourism sector in this hour of need? Unfortunately, as all members know, the government's first response was to impose a new tax on the sector. It is not the first tax it has imposed on the sector in recent times. There was the GST on services in this service based tourism sector. There was an increase in the passenger movement charge, which is reaping far more than the government requires to undertake those customs and quarantine procedures that it purports to raise the money for.

This is a rewrite of the petrol and GST issue, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl. You will recall that when petrol rose the GST windfall came in; similarly now, when the price of air tickets risesâin some cases some 500 per centâthe GST component rises and the government receives a windfall. Rather than turn to that windfall, the government turns to the very industry in trouble and imposes a new tax to fund workers' entitlementsâsomething that would not be an issue if, five years ago, the government had started to work towards a proper process to protect those entitlements, as the Labor Party has done.

I am pleased to say that there is more in the government plan. The second string to the government's bow is to form a committee. When all else fails, you form a committee. I will say this: it is a committee of highly regarded people in the industryâChris Brown of the Tourism Task Force; Andrew Burns of the Australian Tourism Export Council; Ken Boundy of the Australian Tourist Commission; Jenny Lambert of the Meetings Industries Association; and Richard Mulcahy of the Australian Hotels Association. In total, there are 17 highly qualified people to lend the government advice in this hour of needâwith one exception: the minister herself. I do note, though, that the government was sensible enough to make Andrew Burns the minister's co-chairperson to keep things under control.

I make the point about the quality of the membership of the committee for a very good reason. The members of the committee have put forward some very sensible initiatives to address the current crisis in the tourism industry. The Leader of the Opposition referred to some of them during question time today. The initiatives include increased ATC funding, concessional loans for tourism related small businesses andâhere is the real killerâGST relief to alleviate cash-flow problems in tourism related small businesses. This is the new tax that was going to increase cash flow for the small business sector. The minister's own working party has suggested that GST relief should be granted to those in the tourism sector to alleviate the cash-flow problems brought on by the crisis. Unfortunately, the government is yet to embrace the ideas of its own working group. What it has decided to do instead is to undertake a survey, which will cost the Australian taxpayer some $50,000. I did not hear the Treasurer talking about how the government was going to fund its survey, in itself not an insignificant amount of money. I have the survey with me. I want to make the point that the survey, which I assume will go to all tourism operators in the country, gives those people the opportunity to indicate whether the current crisis has been good for their business or bad!

talk.start.para: âTick the box: yes or no.
(Mr Nehl)âI remind the member for Batman that he has already been warned.

âThere is a third choice: `or will have no effect'. Why are we surprised, given the minister's earlier description of the crisis before us as `a little blip on the industry'? The Minister for Sport and Tourism has lost the confidence of her industry. I say to the Prime Minister that leaving the member for Lindsay in charge of tourism is a bit like replacing Mayor Giuliani with Dan Quayle in New York's time of crisis. What the industry needs now, more than at any time in its history, is strong leadership. It needs a champion, someone who can take the fight up to the government. Sadly, this minister has not been capable of fulfilling that role.

speech.para: I do not begrudge other industries assistanceânot by any measureâbut it never ceases to amaze me that when the dairy industry is in trouble there is a $1.7 billion package, when car jobs are at risk in South Australia the Prime Minister is on a plane to Japan to talk to industry leaders and that country's Prime Minister, when a smelter in North Queensland needs money $200 million from the government is immediately in the bank, and when we have a drought we have exceptional circumstances measures to address the adjustment issues in those industries affected by drought. But when tourism, Australia's large export earnerâif you disaggregate the resource sector, 4.5 per cent of this country's GDP and around a million jobsâgoes to the government for help in this time of crisis, what does it get? It gets a new tax.

talk.start.para: âAnd a survey.

âAnd it gets another survey. It gets a new tax and a surveyâa tax, the burden of which will fall disproportionately on rural and regional Australia; a tax which will disadvantage the regions which will be affected most by this crisis. Ansett carried around 64 per cent, if not more, of the region's air services.

speech.para: Tourism was struggling even before this crisis. The big problem with tourism and one of the reasons it seems to often be turned away when it is in trouble or when it goes to the government for assistance is that it is always growing. But the big question is: is it growing to its full potential? That is the important question to ask. Unfortunately, last month the Tourism Forecasting Council downgraded its predictions for tourism over the next 10 years. Basically it halved what it believes will be the growth in our inbound tourism over the next 10 years. This comes on the back of a crisis in Australian Tourist Commission funding because of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. One of the ATC's main outlays is the purchase of television advertising overseas. You can imagine what the low dollar has done to its purchasing power. Let us get rid of this myth that the lower dollar helps inbound tourism. For a start, most, or all, airline tickets are written in American dollars and, let us be frank, that is the largest component of the cost to an international traveller. In addition, people do not sit in their lounge rooms in Tokyo or Boston checking the value of the Australian dollar from day to day. Indeed, they usually plan their international visits well in advance, probably more than 12 months in advance.

The ATC came to the government pre-budget, in trouble, asking for additional funding to get it through what was then, in hindsight, a very minor crisis. It requested $10 million over four years. It was not an additional $10 millionâ$10 million would have only maintained the ATC's current funding level in real terms.

talk.start.para: âNot even a month's political advertising.

âAs the member for Batman indicates, $10 million over four years is not even one month's political advertising at taxpayers' expense, as has been the habit of this government. What was the government's response to the ATC request? The government response was `No, sorry, tourism, we can't help.' Today the Labor Party has made a commitment to the Australian Tourist Commission. We will give it its $10 million immediately. We will await the results of its internal review and we will discuss with the ATC the appropriate level of funding in the out years. Unlike this government, the opposition are prepared to act. We will get planes back in the air, we will double funding for tourism infrastructure and we will instil confidence back in the tourism industry.

speech.para: I said that this is a crisis affecting real people on the ground, and I gave the example of a dive operation in Cairns. Let us talk about Matthew Brennan, who runs Branxholm Tearooms in Tasmania, a small business which relies on the tourism sector. Located on the Tasman Highway, a major tourist drive, it is the only coffee shop between Branxholm and the east coast. He, of course, relies on passing tourism traffic for his business. Mr Brennan's business has collapsed by 50 per cent since this crisis hit the tourism sector. We find these sorts of stories in every tourism region around the country, and the aggregate effect on the Australian economy is appalling.

Let me contrast what the Minister for Sport and Tourism had to say about the crisis in the industry with what industry leaders are saying. Mr Peter Shelley, the CEO of the Australian Tourism Export Council, said that the US terrorist attacks `could mean up to $5 billion worth of export tourism income that will not be realised for the next 12 months.' Mr Ken Boundy, Managing Director of the Australian Tourist Commission, said that he had never seen the industry hit this hard in such a short space of time. Mr Paul Fleming, Harvey World Travel and Thomas Cook managing director, said that the Ansett collapse was `the most catastrophic thing that's happened to the industry', saying that it outranked the Asian economic crisis, the Gulf War and the 1989 pilots strike.

Today I call upon the minister for tourism to finally acknowledge the crisis in the industry and the impact it is having on jobs in this country, particularly jobs in regional Australia, and to embrace Labor's tourism rescue plan. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism

talk.start.para: âIt is great to see that, after three years of my tenure as the Minister for Sport and Tourism, the opposition is finally seeing tourism as a matter of public importance. In those three years, the federal government has allocated a record level of $360.9 million over four years to the Australian Tourist Commission. That is a record level of funding, and nearly $92 million of that funding will be provided in the current financial year alone. I will compare that to the state expenditure and get back to what Labor says and what it actually does when it gets into office.

speech.para: During my tenure as minister, $8 million has gone towards the very successful See Australia domestic tourism initiative. That was the first time that the federal government had managed to gather the states together into a cooperative marketing effort to grow the pie. We also saw the export market development grants expanded and extended. That scheme will be providing over $150 million. On average, tourism receives just under 20 per cent of all grant money, which exceeds its total share of exports. We also saw the launch of the $5 million New Century, New World. Australia 2001 campaign, which was designed to encourage business travellers from overseas to visit Australia for meetings, events, conferences and exhibitions, as part of an incentive rewards program.

There is also the doubling of the regional tourism program, to $16 million over four years, which will help to spread the benefits of tourism to regional and rural Australia. The government have allocated $5 million in grants to hotels in rural and regional Australia to meet up to 50 per cent of the costs incurred in preserving their historic features and attributes. We also provided $6.6 million over three years for the Cultural Heritage Projects Program, to foster partnerships with local government and community based organisations and individuals to conserve and restore significant Australian heritage sites. We have allocated $6.4 million over four years for the refurbishment and ongoing operation of the Townsville Aquarium to, among other things, enhance visitor facilities. We have also provided $4 billion to enhance the transport infrastructure of regional Australia, including $850 million in this financial year for roads; around 80 per cent of domestic travel is by road.

We allocated $20 million towards a scoping study to examine the feasibility of a very high speed train network link between Melbourne, Canberra, Sydney, Brisbane and major regional and coastal centres. We outlaid $1 million for the development of a tourism satellite account, which was the first time that tourism had been officially measured for its contribution to GDP. No matter what the opposition says about tourism, this government has actually done an active assessment of what the measure of tourism is to the Australian economy; it is 4.5 per cent of GDP.

We also provided a million dollars as part of the government's assistance to the Newcastle region, to assist in the planning and development of the Hunter region's tourism potential. I will get back to the Hunter region, because it is apparent that the member for Hunter does not know about a few things that are happening in his own area. We launched a national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tourism strategy that has provided a national framework for the development of indigenous tourism, which is something that had not been done before. The government have also facilitated the development of an ecologically sustainable tourism industry through the involvement of initiatives such as the National Ecotourism Accreditation Program. We have committed $14.7 million in funding over seven years for the establishment of a cooperative research centre for sustainable tourism. We have negotiated approved destination status with China, which is now one of our explosive markets and one that is set to provide an enormous boost to inbound tourism from that source that we have never had before. We have provided $2.5 million to assist the tourism industry with the implementation of the new tax system. We have committed $200,000 to find a solution to the barriers to growth in Tasmania's tourism industry that have been imposed by the Bass Strait. And we have developed an online tourism strategy.

In all that time, in all the days that I have been here in parliament, I did not get one question or one MPI on all of the great things that this government have done for tourism, which has seen a surge in tourism and record levels of international tourists visiting this country. Now the opposition have the sniff of a political opportunity and wish to bring an MPI into this Houseâit is such a matter of public importance that they did not secure many of their members to support the member for Hunter.

talk.start.para: âHow many?
âThere are 27 out of 67 who turned up.
âTwenty-seven out of 67 were here for the MPI.
(Mr Nehl)â Order! The Chief Government Whip!

âLet us have a look at what Labor does when in office. Last year the New South Wales Labor government allocated $44.5 million to tourism and this year it is $41.6 millionâa cut; Queensland allocated $42.9 million and that is now $42.4 millionâa cut; Western Australia, $37.04 million and that is now $34.2 millionâa cut. South Australia actually increased their contribution to tourism. In Tasmania there was another cut; the ACT increased their contribution; and the Northern Territory had a slight cut. Overall, the Labor states have managed to slash the tourism marketing campaign while this government has kept the ATC funding at record levels.

speech.para: In addition to everything we have been doing for tourism to this point, the minute that Ansett collapsed we were in there with solutions. When it became apparent that the workers' entitlements were not secured, we moved to assure the workers that their statutory entitlements and a community standard of eight weeks redundancy pay would be paid. We did not pledge a 100 per cent redundancy pay-out from taxpayers' funds. I am sure that taxpayers on $20,000 would not be that happy about pay-out figures of $175,000 in redundancy pay being taxpayer funded. But it was a significant effort. It is certainly more than was done for all of those tourism workers who lost their jobs through the collapse of Qintex, Budget and Compass 1 and 2, when no entitlements were secured. We have also moved to secure those entitlements with legislation and, again, that has not been supported by the Labor states.

We also ensured that stranded passengers got $120 per night for three nights, and we guaranteed reasonable costs to help people get home. We worked with Qantas and, over a week or two, we have ensured that stranded Ansett passengers got home. We have underwritten loans to other airlinesâHazelton, Kendell, Skywest et ceteraâso that they could be excised from Ansett to start operating. We have worked with Qantas and Virgin Blue to increase their capacity on air links. As I said before, industry's assessment is that capacity is up around 90 per cent. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services thinks that is somewhat optimistic, but, with the addition of rail and road travel, demand is being met.
I will give you a few examples about how diverse the impact isâand the member for Hunter had a few things to say about the survey. An article in today's Sydney Morning Herald stated:

quote.para: At Cypress Lakes Resort at Pokolbin in the Hunter Valleyâ

speech.para: I presume that is in the member for Hunter's electorateâ

talk.start.para: âIt is.
âThere you go; it is in the member's electorate. The article continued:

quote.para: Occupancy rates are healthy, in stark contrast to Sydney's CBD hotels. Sydneysiders are booking three- or four-day holidays at Cypress Lakes, about a 90-minute drive from Sydney.

speech.para: An article in today's Financial Review reported:

quote.para: Queensland's Gold Coast is recording strong accommodation bookings for the next two weeks and the school holiday drive market is expected to fill beds left vacant by the Ansett collapse.
âIt appears that, against all odds, we've got pretty good occupancy rates with last-minute pick-up from a strong drive market ...

speech.para: An article in the Australian today, under the headline `Tourism bosses adjust itinerary', said:

quote.para: The managing director of the Mirror Image Touring Company, Chris Carpenter, backed Mr Boundy's comments, saying there had been a 20 per cent decline in US business but a 30 per cent rise from Britain.

speech.para: So obviously the impacts are varied. Yet the Leader of the Opposition, in classic Labor style, would race out there and announce a package, with taxpayers' money and with no grounds for doing it. He has no surveyâhe would just go into the British market or the US market and start advertising. We have actually pulled out of the United States market.

talk.start.para: âThey can't afford it!

âThe ATC has stopped advertising in the United States because it is not appropriate and it is not the right time. It is important to assess that market to see when the time is right to go back in with an advertising campaign. We are seeing movement out of Asia, where we are seen as a safe destination that is close. We are seeing some bookings there. As I said, China is another market that we can move into. Out of Europe there are varied aspects. So the survey and the feedback are critical in determining a way forward and in finding solutions to the very substantial problems facing the tourism industry.
âThere are no grounds for our package?

âNot surveyed or not looked into. You are simply coming out and promising $2 billion to underwrite Ansett. Then you say, `Oh well, we won't do that; that seems a bit excessive. We will give $200 million to get it flying, so long as we can ignore the debt.' Then you say, `We will give $100 million from the Commonwealth debt program, and we will give $68 million in tourism initiatives.' That is all in one week. I can only think: if this is their crisis management on an ad hoc basis as they run alongâblow money, blow moneyâwhere would we be? We would be at record Commonwealth debt, as we were in 1996, which leads to excessive interest rates. And I will tell you right now: the tourism industry does not need high interest rates from an irresponsible Labor government. That is why you really have to analyse what Labor says in opposition and what it does in government. The state Labor governments have continually carved away from tourism. They have said a lot about it but have not done anything about it. Our record in terms of action and delivering has been quite a proud record. Now we see a situation where the current opposition is trying to make political gains out of it.

speech.para: I have a quote from an emailâobviously one of their sourcesâwhich says: `Our intention is to encourage a local media campaign about the tourism crisis and its potential to disrupt the economies of key marginal electorates.' Whether that is effective or not, they are out there to talk it down. At a time when we need Australians travelling within Australia and signing up for their holidays, the opposition's only policy is to talk it down and take all sorts of action to increase interest rates and to make sure that holidays are completely unaffordable. In addition to that, they want to have a GST roll-back. The litany of responses, their argument all this week, has been in terms of increasing the government's liability and, consequently, a rise in interest rates. It does not serve the tourism industry very well. The Leader of the Opposition has come out this morning with a typical Labor package: basically spending taxpayers' money without consultation, with no grounds, without any regard for consequences. When we are in government we create very stable economic conditions; and, believe me, at this stage, with what is happening in the world, the ratepayers and taxpayers of Australia would prefer to see people with a sound economic record in government than someone who has just an attitude of `pay it out now; chuck it around quite freely; whoever wants it, have some money and we will worry about interest rates later'.

Labor have not learned from their past mistakes. They are committed to spending additional money on education, on health, on Knowledge Nation, and $200 million on Ansett. At the same time, they want to roll back GST. The figures just do not add up. The only thing they add up to is high budget deficits, high interest rates and high inflation. And the key loser in that scenario is the tourism industry. That tourism industry is made up of small to medium-size businessesâthe very people that Labor says they are trying to help. Labor in government would undo the great work that this coalition government has done. We have a sound record as economic managers. We are certainly the guiding force and the captains of the ship that you want in charge to steer us through this crisis, and the tourism industry recognises that.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)â Member for Lalor, are you attempting to be the next speaker? If so, stand up.
âLet the record show that the three government members whom the Chief Government Whip managed to round up to support the Minister for Sport and Tourism are now leaving the chamber.
âThey were just eyeing her back.

âThey were certainly eyeing her backâthat is exactly right; the member for Lalor is completely accurate. In fact, last Wednesday, when she was about to get up to answer the first of that abysmal set of responses that she gave, the member for Menzies got up and took a point of order. He tried to spare her. I sent him a note, and the note said:

quote.para: Kevin, your attempt to save the minister from herself was a very Christian act.

speech.para: After the next election I think there will be a repeat of what happened after the last election. The Prime Minister rang the member for Lindsay and he said to her, `Are you sitting down? I've got a very pleasant surprise for you: you're going to be the minister for tourism.' I suggest, in the remote possibility that the Prime Minister were in a position to make a similar offer after the next election, that he might say, `Are you sitting down? I've got a very pleasant surprise for you: you're not going to be the minister for tourism.' She will go down in history as `little blip'. She described this vast disaster as a `little blip' and said that the tourism industry was running around like Henny Penny, complaining that the sky was falling in; that the problems were only coming from the commentators; and that they were just anecdotal. They were only anecdotal because they had not been enumerated. They had not been enumerated because they had only just happened. They are nonetheless real. The minister had a tourism summit listening to her abysmal performance in the House last Wednesday. They were utterly astonished.

For the minister's benefit, I will go through the obvious implications of the Ansett failure: first, the loss of a very substantial part of the capacity on Australia's major trunk routes; second, the loss of a majority of Australia's regional carriers' capacity and the only capacity to some regional areas. The implications of that for the tourist industry are quite simple. If there are no airline services or fewer than half the airline services to a region, there are fewer customers, no tourists and no tourist businesses. Hotels and resorts start laying off staff and some will close. For the minister, these are just anecdotes coming from commentators. For the tourist operators, the people who work for them, and their families, it is their business, their job and their economic security. Those are just the first-round effects. The implication of a loss of airline capacity is a loss of competition. I will quote from Alan Kohler, writing in yesterday's Financial Review:

quote.para: Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Darwin can probably kiss goodbye to discount fares for a long time, which, as citizens of those towns are already discovering, is a painful experience. A corporate monopoly could result in steady increases in business travel costs and leave the air travel market permanently unbalanced.
Most in the industry reckon that a new Ansett, with a new shareholder, will be lucky to start with 20 per cent market share overall, almost entirely concentrated at the lower end of the market.

speech.para: We are already seeing those fares rise. That means that there will be fewer package deals and they will be more expensive. Fewer people will be flying to regional areas and those who do will have less money to spend when they get there.

Then there is contagion, a concept that we generally think of only in terms of financial markets, but it applies to this situation. Contagion: where the failure of one or more companies or financial institutions causes the failure of other companies that are linked to them. Most obviously, there are Ansett suppliers: fuel companies, catering companies, cleaning companies, travel agents, taxis, hire cars, hotels that look after not only Ansett's customers but their air crew, conference businesses, printers who print their tickets and magazines, and the airport terminal operators. That is just a very small list of them. I have done a little ring-around this morning and I have some examples of how the contagion is spreading. From Australian Major Events: the WA Piper Band could not get to Adelaide to participate in the International Police Tattoo and some culinary teams cannot get flights to Adelaide for Tasting Australia. At the moment, there are no events in jeopardy. Ansett sponsors Australian Major Events; therefore, Australian Major Events will lose lots of free flights. From the Adelaide Convention Centre: no conference or event has yet been cancelled, but there is a decline in the number of delegates of about 10 per cent to 15 per cent, with a significant fall in delegates from the USA, though I will concede that that might be for other reasons.

From the Australian Hotels Association in South Australia: Ansett owes Adelaide hotels $1 million in outstanding bills. South Australian hotels have recorded losses of $600,000 in cancelled bookings and 3,500 room nights in the first week since the airline collapsed. Adelaide hotels expect to lose $8 million in revenue and 50,000 room nights. From Phil Hoffman Travel: small and/or isolated cities such as Adelaide, Darwin, Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns and Hobart are adversely affected because there was already limited capacity relative to the heavy traffic of the east coast trunk routes. Those cities are heavily reliant on air transport, unlike Melbourne and Sydney where good ground transport is more feasible. Anecdotes include a Perth family, booked on Ansett and stranded since the collapseâthey cannot get a flight home until 10 Octoberâand business passengers who are flying from Perth to Adelaide and the east coast via Singapore. When you have a disaster on that sort of scale, it is going to affect the overall performance of the Australian economy. Certainly, the government has not done enough to mitigate those effects. The Labor Party, on the other hand, has published a tourism industry rescue plan.

But we should not forget the government's part in contributing to the Ansett failure. On Tuesday of last week, the Prime Minister tabled a document to explain what the government knew, and when, about the Ansett failure. What he was trying to point out was that he believed Ansett was in stronger shape than it actually was and that it was therefore all a bit of a surprise to him. The document that he tabled was this document which I have in my hand, and I will come to its provenance later. The Deputy Prime Minister described it as one of those things that they flip over. In actuality, I think it is called a chart packâit is for one of those presentations that merchant bankers give you that leads inexorably to the simple conclusion that they want you to draw from what they are telling you. They flip them over. But it seems it was all a bit much for the Deputy Prime Minister to give it any critical analysis. He tried to play down its significance and he said:

quote.para: I did not regard it as a set of financial figures. It was an overview.

speech.para: He nevertheless followed it absolutely diligently. Later the same day, the Prime Minister told the House that on 27 June the CEO of Ansett, Mr Toomey, told him that the Air New Zealand group had $1 billion in financial reserves. He did not say whether it was New Zealand or Australian dollars.

talk.start.para: âEither way, they are not worth a lot.
âThe member for Rankin is totally right. The Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... the advice I had was that it was likely to be exhausted within a year. I was informed during that meeting that they needed a capital injection. The capital injection talked about was obviously a capital injection that was to come from the Singapore Airlines application to the New Zealand government being accepted and, in turn, Air New Zealand injecting more money into Ansett. We discussed that.

I indicated that the objectives of the government were to ensure competition in the domestic market and to ensure that, on the assumption that two major airlines continued, at least one major airline was Australian owned. That is why the government did unashamedly have a preference for what was called the Qantas option for quite some time ...

speech.para: We already have an airline that is Australian owned; it is called Qantas. It is our national carrier.

The Prime Minister was given a documentâand the document that he tabled in the House was this document which has a Qantas logo on the bottom. The Prime Minister, and the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services took the competitor's advice about the state of Ansett. And what did Qantas tell them? They told them what was in their own commercial interest. They told them that Ansett would not fail. And what did they ask them to do? This is what it says on another page of that document:

quote.para: Qantas seeks Australian government support in diverting SIA from its current path.

speech.para: What was the SIA proposal? That SIA was to increase its shareholding in Air New Zealand from the current 25 per cent to as much as 49 per cent if the New Zealand government would allow it. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: âWe have heard a lot about Henny Penny. I would like to talk about the chooks that cluck around the fowl yard pecking at the odd piece of wheat, pecking at the odd grub, pecking at the odd wormâin fact, trying to peck at any little thing that might be negative, that might give the opposition a bit of credibility, that might help them to flip and flop and fluff around like a lot of old chooks in the fowl yard. Isn't it interesting that today, which will arguably be the second-last sitting day, the opposition finally put forward an MPI against the Minister for Sport and Tourism? All this time Australian tourism has been boomingâthere has been year after year of improvement, the Olympics, year after year of increased spending from the government, the restoration of the EMDG grants, the whole scenarioâyet there has hardly been a question from the shadow minister. I ask the shadow minister: how many questions have been asked? Was it one or two during the term? What a marvellous performance! He then came into the House today with confected outrage about the standard of the Australian tourism industry. Hypocrisy knows no bounds! Henny Penny is a compliment to you. A couple of old chooks pecking around the fowl yard for a sliver here and a sliver there of something negativeâthat is as much as you would know about tourism.

speech.para: Before I entered this place, I was general manager of a regional tourism development board in Bundaberg. At the weekend I was given honorary life membership of that body, of which I was the co-founder 30 years ago. It is one of the few that has survived the test of time. These boards start up with a lot of hubris and no-one wants to put any money into themâleast of all Labor governments, I might addâand then they fall over. But not this one. It was interesting because we coalesced 400 businesses around the districtâ 11 shires and a number of government departmentsâto form a very effective board.

I come here with some knowledge of the tourist industryâwhat it is capable of doing and, particularly in circumstances such as this, what we can do with tourism as a substitute to air travel. Tourism and regional development are my great passions. For that reason, I sought to come to this place, because I thought I could add something different. Today I listened to the confected outrage from the other side about the state of the Australia tourism industry. But when I looked through the various states I found that every Labor state government has reduced its funding this financial yearâevery one of them. Only two states increased their funding: the ACT and South Australia, both in coalition circumstances. That says it all, doesn't it?

Tourism comes fairly easily in my electorate, although we can always do with more help. We have the Great Barrier Reef, beaches, two beautiful citiesâBundaberg and Gladstoneâand a marvellous hinterland. We have the classic tourism model. But tourism is never a magic pill or an overnight success. Any tourism market's success comes with long-term strategic positioning and marketingâand that is what the minister is saying in this crisis.

You do not go rushing out, as the press reports say today, suddenly wanting to put $70 million into tourism, $50 million into business concessional loans and $10 million into the Tourism Commission when you do not even know where the problem is. It might be the state tourism bodies that need the money to boost local tourism. Wouldn't you think in a circumstance like this that the ALP or their regional development or tourism committee, if they have one, might have said, in their collective wisdom, `Hey, listen. Isn't this a great opportunity for Australians to holiday at home?' Did that ever occur to you? Do you know that 80 per cent of Australians undertake their holidays by car? That would have been a marvellous opportunity. The minister wants to have this consultation and place the government money strategicallyâ we cannot have the luxury of saying, `We'll just put the $2 billion to one side and suddenly, somehow, magically we'll save Ansett with a loan or a gift of $150 million or $200 million.' Quite frankly, if you could put the debt to one side or get rid of the debt, Ansett would not need the $150 million or $200 millionâthey would be able to raise it themselves. You go on with such nonsense arguments in this place.

talk.start.para: âThere is no-one interested in Ansett.

âNo, we are very interested in Ansett. It stands to reason that, when tourism encounters a crisis like the pilots strike, the Compass collapse, Ansett's grounding or the US terrorist attacksâwhich you have said very little about, and I suspect that has put more people out of aircraft in recent times than even the Ansett thing, especially when holidays are concernedâpeople have a natural reluctance to travel. As a result of the grounding of Ansett, there has been an increase in the price of airline tickets that will affect tourism, and you have been keen to make mention of that. But I will take you back a little way to when you were in office and Compass got into difficultyâand remember that in those days Compass was providing the budget fares and stimulating the tourism marketâ
âWhat did they do?
âWhat did they do? Nothing. In fact, I think this quote of Brian Grey's is marvellous:

quote.para: I went to the government on Wednesday and I asked for some relief. Kerin, Beazley and Collins came in and sat down and before I even opened my mouth, Kerin simply said there would be no cooperation from the Commonwealth government. He said, `Under no circumstances will we help you by any means.'

speech.para: Marvellous! And that was the organisation that was delivering the low cost fares at the time. Later, in the current circumstance, when the Leader of the Opposition wanted to justify himself, he said, `There were only 1,000 employees affected,' as if they did not matter. They all matterâwhether it is 13,000, 14,000 or 1,000. They matter because of the service they were delivering. So does it mean, if segments of Ansett start to fly againâand in the unlikely event of the ALP attaining government this yearâthat if one or other of those small airlines falls over, we will just say, `There were only 1,000 employees affected,' or `All the employees of Virgin Blue are non-unionists. If Virgin Blue falls over, it will not matter'? That is the sort of cynicism that you have come into this House with today. That is the sort of cynicism we have had to put up with.

What is more, you have gone on this week with confected outrage about the entitlements of employees. We are the only government in Australia's historyâapart from one brief foray by the Carr governmentâ that has ever done anything serious about employees' entitlements, right down to eight weeks redundancy. It is well within the capacity of those states that we have just talked about, even in the savings that they are making on tourism this year, to fund the additional entitlements of the Ansett employees. If you are really so keen about it, start working on your state colleagues. The Leader of the Opposition comes into this place flipping and flopping all the time.

talk.start.para: âMore flop than flip.

âYes. He did nothing about the Compass collapse; he did not even safeguard workers' entitlements. Hansard records that on 19 September he claimed to be misrepresented after comments that the government should underwrite Ansett were attributed to him. He said, `I have never suggested that at any stage.' Now he wants a bailout. How many times has he changed his position on this? How many times have you changed your position on this? How many times have you helped the tourism industry? We have given record funding, we have given export market development grants; you have done nothing. (Time expired)
