talk.start.para: â We are back in the chamber today debating the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 yet again. We are back here debating this piece of legislation because the government is trying to get this legislation passed through the parliament in order to provide security for all of those people who work in the timber and forest products industry. Anyone watching or tuning into this debate would wonder why on earth this is taking so long. This legislation was first introduced into this parliament three years ago. People have heard of very long debates taking place in this parliament, and especially in the Senate, but I do not think any debate has taken as long as this one. The reason that this debate has taken so long and the government has been unable to provide the security and the certainty for people in our regional areas of Australia in particular, including many in the towns of my electorate, is that the opposition has prevented it. I have listened to some of the previous speakers today in this debate and have heard some absolutely hypocritical and unbelievable excuses as to why this legislation has not been passed, especially from the member for McMillan, who seems to have forgotten that it was his party that voted down this legislation. So I thought that for the purpose of this debate today I would go back and detail some of the reasons why we are still standing here today trying desperately to provide that security and certainty for the timber industry.

speech.para: On 9 December 1998, the bill was referred to the Senate's Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The committee reported on 25 February 1999. In the chairman's report, there was a recommendation that the bill be passed unamended. Previous speakers here today have talked about bipartisanship on this important issue. Did those opposite provide that bipartisanship to ensure the safe passage of this legislation? The answer is that they did not. They started engaging in stalling tactics which, I am very sorry to say, are still continuing today. Firstly, the opposition issued some amendments which were no more than spurious amendments. They were just opening up the gateway to create a lawyers picnic. In fact, when the ALP raised their amendments, the Minister for Forestry and Conservation said:

quote.para: We have grave concerns about an objects clauseâ

speech.para: which is what the opposition proposedâ

quote.para: because that just opens up the opportunity for people who seem to have heaps and heaps of money to take someone to court after the event when they have committed their billion bucks in a paper making plant and say, âYou cannot do this because RFA No. 5 in Victoria does not meet the objects of the act.â That is a great opportunity for a couple of lawyers to make a lot of money. The fact of life is that investors do not want that problem; they want uncontestable arrangements. That is what you achieve with an objects clause: you start to create opportunities for litigation. That is why I think it was totally unnecessary. But we were prepared to have some limited objects that we felt would not open the legislation to that sort of litigation, and we said so.

speech.para: But that was unacceptable. Spurious amendments like that provide not one iota of hope, not one iota of certainty or security, for those people in an electorate like mine in towns like Alexandra, Seymour, Yarra Junction and Powelltown where people have invested millions of dollars. They need the security of the resource, and the RFA legislation is designed to underpin that security. If we were to agree to such spurious amendments as those I have just described, we would be doing those people and all who work in the mills, in the forests, in the trucks and in the service industries the greatest disservice, because we would just simply pull from under them any rug of security or certainty.

Further to that spurious amendment, the opposition put forward disallowance provisions, which the government opposed. The first, as I said, related to this open-ended delay, and the government would not have a bar of that. The second one raised a constitutional question, and we certainly were not going to have a bar of that either. Once again, that was not providing what the RFA legislation was in fact designed to achieve. Further amendments related to compensation, and let me give the reason why the government rejected that particular amendment. We rejected it because it proposed to alter the compensation clause in the bill and would have been confusing, as the liability to pay compensation continued to rise out of the terms of the RFA itself. It was unclear as to what the term `losses arising from the loss of legally excisable rights' in the proposed amendment actually meant. Once again, this was simply going to be opening the doors so that the lawyers could have a picnic. That is just not on, and I wanted to get that very clearly on the record today.

As I said, I have been listening to speakers saying, `We need bipartisanship in this.' We certainly do, but there is no way that any responsible government could have possibly agreed to those amendments, not when they were going to have those sorts of effects. I would ask those opposite to just consider for a minute the industry on which they are putting up every obstacle to further advancement. We are talking about an industry that employs over 82,000 people nationally, that has an $11Â½ billion annual turnover and that represents 1.9 per cent of GDP. This is an industry that in recent years has invested millions in high value adding equipmentâ the very end of the market that we are most anxious to improve and that is leading to increased growth in exports. Take a firm like Goulds in Alexandra in my electorate: they are now exporting to Japan and China because of the millions of dollars they have invested in their particular business. They, and thousands like them, are listening. They are waiting on the outcome of this debate, as they have been waiting for years. They are getting fed up with the tactics of the opposition, who are simply using no more than stalling tactics. Every one of those spurious amendments was a stalling tactic.

I think it is also about time that we got on the record the backflips, the flip-flopsâ whatever description you want to give to themâof the shadow minister for agriculture, fisheries and forestry. In March this year, he was at the timber community's conference at Lilydale in Melbourne. I was also at that conference. In his address to that conference he said:

quote.para: Providing all key players approach the matter in a positive and constructive fashion, the prospect for securing bipartisan passage of Commonwealth RFA legislation is extremely good. For my part, I can assure you that I will make every effort to secure such an outcome.

speech.para: When he said, in front of a group of timber industry representatives, that he was going to make every effort to achieve an outcome in regard to this legislation, people were so much wanting that to be true that they believed it. But, once again, they have been let down, and they have been let down very badly. This Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 has been on the Notice Paper for a couple of weeks, but at five minutes to midnight the shadow minister decides to move yet more amendments, none of which he is prepared to have debated in this chamber; they are only to be debated in the other place. Once again, he is simply putting up obstacles. He says one thing when he is out there talking to industry representatives, but he does something quite different in here.

If we had been monitoring the shadow minister's statements, we and industry would have realised that the words he spoke in Lilydale in March this year were, sadly, just empty rhetoric. In August of this year, speaking in Tasmania, the member for Reid expressed `concerns that the new regional forest agreements may be delayed because of the pending federal election'. He was already flagging his concerns. If anything, it was probably a Freudian slip, because he was firmly intending the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 to be held up once again. At around the same time, on 18 July this year, Senator Kerry O'Brien wrote a letter to the editor of a Tasmanian publication telling Tasmanian readers that the Senate had passed the government's RFA legislation. The mind simply boggles at all this. We have a Tasmanian senator telling Tasmanians that the RFA legislation had been passed; we have the shadow minister attending a timber conference in Melbourne saying he was going to do everything in his power to ensure that it would be passed; and then a little later in the year, one month after Senator O'Brien made his statement to the Tasmanian press, we have the shadow minister starting to flag the possibility that this might be a bit iffy and that there might be problems. This really is an absolute disgrace.

In a way, though, you can almost understand why the shadow minister is all over the place. He is only following in the steps of his leader, who is also all over the place. The Leader of the Opposition is all over the place on issues like airlines, immigration, border protection and tax. He changes almost from one day to another and, on the airline issue, he changed his position twice in the same day. He is running around the country and changing his policy positions as he goes. He launched his Telstra appeal in Healesville, in my electorate of McEwen, and he made a pledge that he was not going to sell Telstra. One of my constituents stepped forward and asked whether this was the same sort of pledge that he had given regarding the sale of Qantas and the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. That question left him absolutely floundering.

The Leader of the Opposition is not just all over the place on these other issues but also on the important issue we are discussing today. On 26 July, he was in my colleague's seat of Eden-Monaro. In relation to this matter, he said:

quote.para: These are matters which have exercised us over the years and we thought that the Regional Forest Agreement process, that the balance was being sustained, be it between preserving higher value native forests and allowing also jobs to be kept in the timber industry in this country.

speech.para: The journalist asked what that meant, and the Leader of the Opposition replied:

quote.para: Who knows? We thought that the balance had been got right with the RFAs and those agreements were signed up and at the time it seemed to suit people. Things have changed not just here but elsewhere and concerns and complaints have arisen from that.

speech.para: The only thing that has changed is that people have less certainty. They have less certainty than ever before about what role the opposition is going to play, because this opposition has demonstrated that, unfortunately, it really does not stand up for the timber industry nor for those 82,000-plus workers in the timber industry. It is not prepared, as the opposition's shadow minister claims it is when he is outside of this place, to come in here and take a bipartisan view. It has not done that.

It is really crunch time for the opposition. It is time for the opposition to stop vacillating. They have to put up or shut up in regard to this whole question of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill. They have to demonstrate that they are either for the timber industry or against it, that they are either for the thousands of people who work in the timber industry or they are against them and that they are either for all those businesses that have invested millions of dollars in this industry or they are against them. There can be no other outcome to this legislation. If the opposition stall this legislation again, they will have proved to the Australian public, and in particular to all those who work in the timber industry, that they do not care about them and they do not stand for them.

On behalf of all people in my electorate, especially those people in the timber towns and the timber industry that supports those towns not just in an economic sense but in a social sense, I want to reiterate that, if the opposition again put up obstacles and walk away from this regional forest agreement legislation, they are walking away from all of those small regional communities like the ones I have in my electorate. Those people who work in the timber industry are those rural communities: they are the people who volunteer in the local SES and CFA and in hospital and school fetes and every other event that happens; they are the backbone of those communities. And be assured: I will let all those communities know exactly what was said in this debate today and what obstacles the opposition have again put in the way of this legislation, and I will make sure that every single one of those workers knows what the opposition are really about.

talk.start.para: âAll I can say to the previous speaker is: bring the bill on in the Senate tomorrow. That will be the test for you.

speech.para: The Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001 gives legislative effect to certain provisions of the Commonwealth-state regional forest agreements, particularly provisions on compensation and the exclusion of specified Commonwealth laws, and provides legislative recognition for the existence and work of the Forest and Wood Products Council. This bill is enabling legislation which takes on board the state RFAs which collectively provide the blueprint for the future management of Australian forests and the basis for an internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable forest products industry.

This is the most important environmental bill that could pass this House. There should be no argument about which government or party put it up or did not put it up: it has been a collective effort stretching back to the early 1990s. Both the major parties believe that this bill should be enacted, but both have used delaying tactics. This has effectively made this an issue of confrontation which both parties like to have around election time. Once again, this time is no exception.

This bill is too important for that. The industry needs certainty, the value of the forests themselves needs a proper and sustainable management system to survive, and those that are in the industry and who, because of the strict guidelines that were developed in the national forest policy statement, need to scale down or leave their land need to have proper compensation. This is what this bill provides. It does nothing different from what has been discussed for years and really does not need significant amendment. However, in the interest of trying to get a more inclusive opinion, some amendments have been suggested.

I have been continuing to push for my party to stand by its decision to support the legislation as it has been reintroduced into the parliament in the last session. It is quite possible to support the legislation and that support should now be bipartisan, as the discussions within the two major parties have not changed the direction of the legislation. Now is the time to finally put this matter to bed and continue to get on with developing the industry along the lines of world best practice. I will stand by my commitment to the industry, the workers and their families in that industry and the communities that are based on them. I can only hope that the government is prepared to put aside any one-upmanship or political games and get on with the process before we have to fight another election on forestry issues. But it is up to the minister: he has to ensure the bill's passage. It is on his head if, once again, it fails.

We are debating this legislation two days before the end of the 39th Parliament. Two days! It was put on the Notice Paper two weeks ago. The legislation has been ready and it could have been brought into the parliament earlier. In saying that, I would like to spell out my position and philosophy on the forest industry as we move towards an election. As you know, I have always felt that it is important that we maintain a balance between the valuable contribution that forestry makes to the Tasmanian economy and our need to keep our unique environment in a healthy state for the future. Forestry in Tasmania has been the subject of long-term debate and, although questions still remain, the major part of the concerns has been addressed. We have a world-class forestry system and our forest practices are second to none. But that does not mean that we are perfect; there is always room for improvement and I am conscious that I must take note of all those that write to me or ring me on forestry issues, because sometimes people do make mistakes and we can always learn new and better ways of doing things.

The RFA guidelines, along with the national forest policy, were a long time in development. They went through an exhaustive consultation process which came out with a solution that should provide an excellent base for the careful development of the industry. The RFA allows best practice to be put into place and will allow for careful and healthy development of the forest industry and encourage further processing and value adding in the state. Although Tasmania is not quite perfect yet, we are seen as a world leader in forestry practices. We are recognised by those who lead in Scandinavia and Canada. Forty per cent of the landmass, containing some of the best timber, is locked up in national parks and reserves, and that which is left can be better cared for by allowing harvesting from time to time. Plantations are becoming the dominant forest type, used for such uses as pulp and chips which are then used for paper making, both in Australia and overseas.

Tasmanian forest strategy was born out of work done by professional foresters and bush workers. They have worked in the area for over 150 yearsâprobably longerâand it is due to them that we have so much old-growth forest still standing and in good shape. But, like people, trees die and need to be replaced to allow the life cycle to continue.

The role of the RFA is to maximise the timber return while minimising the impact on the forest biodiversity. This means better work practices, as well as setting aside stands of forest that are not represented elsewhere. These have been carefully screened and documented for their special values and are spelt out in Tasmania's RFA. If man's activities have impinged on the area at all, which in most of the private forest areas they have, weed species enter, the ground is disturbed and the undergrowth becomes prone to fires and can be a danger to the rest of the area. So they need to be cleaned up now and again to allow the strong, healthy trees to reseed the area. Just saying that we will promise to stop old-growth logging will leave us with a resource that is not useful anymore and therefore will not be looked after as it has no economic value.

As it is, the cost of looking after national parks is very expensive, involving the maintenance of building access, the provision of centres for people to visit, the provision of interpretation and the enabling of further research to be carried out. The same number of people work on this as they do in some other forest practices, but the return is different. The resource in the reserved areas does not have an economic value, but it does have a value in its role of retaining the biodiversity of this particular climatic period, so it still remains a long-term asset, with ability to store our biodiversity and help rejuvenate the area. Therefore, the overall cost of maintaining national parks is more than it returns in the short term, but it can be seen as an investment for our future.

We do not have the population in Tasmania, as some people would argue, to replace forestry harvesting with tourism. There just is not the population to achieve that, so there has to be a happy medium where we keep the really good rainforest and mixed forest in conservation areas and allow economic activities to go on around the edges to ensure both areas are managed for posterity. Sensible management, along with an understanding of how the ecosystem works, is the key to the sustainability and therefore the certainty of the industry. Once the federal legislation is in place, I am keen to start working with the industry to see how we can further improve industry's positionâto look at timber certification and to look at further downstream processing.

During all this time of negotiation, I have met with forest workers and their families. I have been involved in many consultations with the state government and industry bodies and also with the Timber Communities Association. It has been a rewarding and enlightening time. All these people show the human side of the industry and what happens when there is conflict. I have witnessed the awful grief and family hardship that occurs as the timber community tries to keep the employment that they and their families have been undertaking for many generations.

Regional jobs are hard to come by. Little by little they get whittled away by those who live in cities who see great new visions for the world but who do not seem to include people in their visions. Our foresters and timber workers are now the true conservationists. They are the ones out there looking after the working forests, keeping the species diverse, keeping the forests healthy and renewable. While this struggle has been occurring, I have been able to meet thousands of people from all over Australia, and I have welcomed their friendship and have been hearing their concerns. Whether or not they like my politics or what I have to say, they have always given me a fair hearing and a friendly debate.

To ensure the future of these people, I would like to see this bill passed. It should not be put off anymore. The time for talking is over. We need to get on with our lives and start developing an industry careful for the future, so that our working forests are ready for our grandchildren to harvest so they can build their houses from the best timber in the world. I have a diagram here which shows the regrowth forest reserve growth in Tasmania over the last two decades. I will ask the minister later if I can table it. It shows the increase in the amount of reserves, national parks and world heritage areas that we now have in Tasmania.

The previous speaker said that this bill has been hanging around for two years; it is a lot longer than that. The minister has been fiddling around with it, not putting it forward. In 1998, when we went to an election, it was in the Senate. It was brought back in after the election and it hung around in 1999. It was then withdrawn in 2000 and set aside. It has not been brought back until nowâtwo days before the end of the 39th Parliament. The bill sits poised to go to the Senate to be debated, but we know that the government has already taken it off its list of priority bills in the Senate and, unless it puts it back on that list, this bill will not be debated in the Senate. It is up to the minister to get this bill into the Senate to be debated. It is already off the list there; it has to be put back on the list.

I would also like to remind the House that I have never voted against an RFA bill and the Labor Party has never voted against an RFA bill. The only major party that has voted against an RFA bill is the Liberal-National parties, and that was in 1992, when the original bill was brought in by the Labor Party. It is time to stop mucking around. This is the time to get on with the job of passing this bill. As I said, it is now up to the minister, and I challenge him to get the bill into the Senate. That is his task; that is his job. Put it back on the list to be debated so that it can be passed. Let people have the certainty that they need in the forest industry so that it can grow and expand, and let our working forests continue to live. I support the bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the document I referred to earlier.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â When we look at the history of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001, we can see it is a classic example of a government playing wedge politics. Every Australian wants our unique forest system to be saved, and every Australian wants habitat for our unique fauna and for those animals to be saved for future generations to maintain our biodiversity. The problem with the implementation of the RFA legislation is the will of the minister at the timeâand that has been highly questionable.

speech.para: When we look at the history of this legislation and its passage through this parliament we see that the bill was introduced in June 1998 after virtually no consultation with relevant stakeholders. It was passed in the House of Representatives with Labor support, but was still before the Senate when the 1998 election was called. An identical bill was reintroduced immediately after the 1998 election and was before the parliament for all of 1999. It passed this Houseâagain with our supportâin March 1999, but was not brought on for debate in the Senate until August that year. By then, the Democrats had assumed the balance of power in the Senateâin July that yearâand on 2 September 1999 the Senate passed the bill with the inclusion of 15 amendments. That was carried by 50 votes to 8. The key amendments imposed a limited process of public and parliamentary review of draft RFAs and amendments to RFAs, clarified the circumstances in which compensation was payable by the Commonwealth and explicitly linked the bill to the requirements of Labor's groundbreaking national forest policy statement of 1992.

But when the bill was returned to the House in October 1999 the government rejected all of the Senate amendments and added a new clause proposing the establishment of a Forest Products Advisory Council. The Senate then insisted on its original amendments and adopted a further amendment, substituting Labor's proposed Wood and Paper Industry Council for the coalition's Forest Products Advisory Council. And on 9 December, Minister Tuckeyâthe minister at the table todayâmoved that the bill be laid aside on the basis that the government was unwilling to accept the Senate's amendments.

There is going to be an election between now and the end of the year, and what do we find? In the last days of this parliament, here is the RFA legislation back on the agenda. That is the thing: this is a highly controversial bill. We heard the member for McEwen saying that it has been the opposition that has procrastinated on this legislation. That history I have just read out of the passage of this legislation through this House is an honest and true statement of it which can be verified; and on every occasion it has had the support of the Labor Party. Everyone knows it is not the opposition that is in charge of determining when legislation comes to this House; that is the job of the minister. I understand there was quite a farcical situation in the Senate earlier today when the debate on this legislation was thrown out by some unwitting government senators who did not realise the importance of it to the minister's role.

talk.start.para: âI think they did!

âThey probably did; they probably knew the controversy about it and thought, `Maybe this is something that it's better we don't debate.' Perhaps that is itâI do not know. But we can see the slant that the government is taking on this issue every time.

speech.para: Forestry is an important industry in the electorate of Paterson. As a matter of fact, it is so important that we had the minister himself there a month or so ago. I was delighted that he was there. I am only sorry he did not advise me he was coming or I could have taken him to meet every forestry worker and every sawmiller, because I am very proud of my association with them. I have encouraged those sawmills that are still in the Paterson electorate to invest in value adding, whereby they employ more people, use less resource and receive greater returns for their products. I was highly delightedâand the minister would know thisâthat earlier this year S.A. Relf and Son became the first accredited producer of kiln-dried hardwood flooring in New South Wales. That happened to be the very mill that the minister visited in Bulahdelah only a month ago.

Back in the early nineties, when this RFA legislation had been brought forward by the then Keating government, we knew there was going to be a change in access to resource; but that was happening naturally anyway, because 100-plus years of logging automatically has that effect on resource availability. The Dorney family, which owns S.A. Relf and Son, have invested millions in plant and equipment. They have put lots of money into training and acquiring staff who are aware of what is needed, what the market needs and the quality assessment they must carry out on their product. Naturally, they have accessed FISAP money, and I have encouraged, guided and helped them to do that. There is no doubt that what they have today is a quality outfit, producing probably the best quality product of its sort in Australia. Royce Dorney, the patriarch of the family, and I have some serious discussions from time to time, but he knows that the forest industry has changed and that it must be sustainable.

These changes have been taking place because of investment and because of the market. I heard my colleague from Tasmania say that he sincerely hopes that young people will be able to build a home out of hardwoodâout of the best timber available. Even in hardwood towns like Bulahdelah, Stroud and Gloucester, and towns in my electorate where hardwood has always played a very big role, when you see a new house going up you do not see hardwood scantling being used. You might see radiata pine which was grown in a plantation, and you see a great deal of steel-framed places going up, because technology changes. I must admit that I am pleased to see those pine frames going up, because that again tells me that it is about sustainable forestry. That is what both sides of the House are trying to do, but there is always a certain amount of jostling and confrontation, and that is the shame of it, because it should be done with the support of both sides. The Labor Party certainly discovered that back in the early nineties, when the annual affair of woodchip licences came up. That was something that had to be avoided, and I suppose it precipitated the RFA legislation in the first place. Let us make this a sustainable industry. Let us guarantee that biodiversity is ensured for future generations. Let us make sure that samples of all sorts of forestry are set aside and will continue. Let us see what we can do for the forestry industry to make it sustainable. That has happened in the electorate of Paterson. I understand that, nationally, reserves have increased by 28 per cent since the legislation was introduced, and that is a very good thing.

Those are the points that we should be making together, because if we are not together the division will be very unpalatable and it has the potential to be very damaging to the timber industry. The minister certainly knows that and I certainly know it, because I have received a significant number of emails and letters opposing the legislation. I do not believe that the opposition to the issue is either informed or reasonable. I believe that it is highly emotive and that it does not look at the true facts, the true statement or the true science of the RFA legislation. I walk around forests with foresters on a fairly regular basis. I am aware that, within the forestry compartments that have been set aside for harvesting, positive policies of environmental control and biodiversity maintenance are being practised between filter strips around drainage areas and between old growth forest and candidate old growth forest being set aside not to be harvested. I am aware of that. I certainly do not see the process of clear-felling occurring anywhere in the forestry compartments in the electorate of Paterson. I know that it may not be the same for other areas, but I can only go on what I see. When I walk through the forests of Bulahdelah and Gloucester Tops and the Dungog state forest areas, I am amazed that I am looking at forests that have been continuously harvested for well over 100 years. I am confident that the biodiversity that is still there represents much of the biodiversity that was there initially when the first timber-getters first walked into the area.

That is the balanced argument, and it is the job of the minister and the opposition to make sure that the argument goes forward. We can play politics over itâthe minister plays politics with it from time to time; I certainly doâbecause we are in the game of politics, and that is what it is all about. When the minister comments that he believes that there should be logging in national parks, it certainly drops his guard and leaves him open. That is exploited not so much by meâ as a matter of fact, I have not put out a single comment on itâbut certainly by the environmental movement, which has taken him to task over it. Those are the things that should be removed from this argument. It is not one or the other; we are talking about a total situation. We are talking about trying to get the policy right.

The Labor Party, when it first produced the RFA legislation, moved that it should be reviewed from time to time. We know that the RFA debate has moved on and that it is now focused on the implementation, reporting and review stage. Five-yearly reviews of the first two RFAs are due to be completed next year. The challenge will be to carry out those reviews and see whether we have the science right and whether we have to change our tack. We are not setting it in concrete. We have to be open to moderate our views, to modify our procedures and to ensure that the objectives of the regional forest agreements are being met. That is what this is all about. I am pleased to be here today, because I believe that this is certainly the best policy that has evolved in the whole of the forestry industry. It removes confrontation, brings in logic, brings in science and allows the development of a model that will retain representation of all our native forest types, maintain our biodiversity and maintain an industry that is vital for many parts of regional and rural Australia, an industry that has traditionally been there since the first settlers strode into many parts of Australia. As we walk around those areas, we see that the biodiversity is still largely intact in many areas. That is how this argument can and must be won. The emotion must be taken out of it and commonsense and science must prevail. That is why I am pleased to be here today to have the opportunity to say a few words and to support the legislation.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Forestry and Conservation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âIn summing up on these issues in respect of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 2001, people here are getting prepared to make speeches which I am sure they are very anxious to distribute within their electorates. It is encouraging, of course, to hear people say things which unfortunately have been in conflict with their votes. Notwithstanding the comments just made by the member for Paterson, I find him listed under the noes on 13 October 1999 on page 965 of Hansard in respect of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998. I also find the member for Lyons there. It is useless coming into this place and trying to rewrite history. We have something called Hansard which records these things quite clearly.

speech.para: I want to address a couple of fundamental issues, the first of which is that this bill has come to the House in a form that is totally supported by the dominant trade union, the CFMEU, in terms of its content. On previous occasions, I read to the House some of the very straightforward comments they chose to make when it was suggested that it would be amended, because they saw that as dangerous for the bill. In that regard, as someone said here today, the danger was that it might open the bill up to litigation. It could allow those people who seem to always have large sums of moneyâotherwise frequently known as green activistsâto attack the principles of the bill where they thought it could be undermined. It is their policy to undermine the bill, or legislation of this nature, simply because they have a standard process of being opposed to any form of forest products industry.

We did not want any complications. We have constantly opposed amendments that were either not relevant to the fundamentals of the bill or which we thought could put the bill at risk at some time in the future. In that regard, our position is unchanged. We have put forward a bill which contains some alterations from the past, principally to meet what we thought were quite sensible requirements, particularly from the CFMEU, in terms of a Forest Products Advisory Council. That is functioning and I attended a meeting last week in that regard. One of the principal contributors to that is Mr Trevor Smith of the CFMEU, whom I find most helpful, and who gives leadership on some issues. We are progressing that matter. I give him credit for raising this point in our preliminary discussions. Most of those attending are high-ranking executives of the businesses and not just association CEOs. That again adds very substantially to it, and the legislation we are debating today formalises those arrangements. It leaves in a sunset clause because there may possibly be a point in time when it has done its job and we do not want something hanging around our neck which is costly when those funds could be better used in the interests of the industry.

People like the Tasmanian Labor government say that they want this bill without amendment. We had representatives at the executive level of the Tasmanian industry in the parliament today saying that their entire investment program is locked up awaiting the security from sovereign risk that this bill will provide. In itself, that is the reason why the bill should go ahead unamended and with alacrity. It is all right for people to say when it might have been brought in and when it was not brought in. The fact is that we have time by tomorrow, when I come to a particular point, to pass this bill into legislation. There should be no mucking about. We do not need other amendments. If there is a genuine feeling amongst the Labor Party that they would like to add amendments to this bill, win the election and do it. That is your right. You can win an election, become the government, and you can do it. While we are the government, we believe that it should pass unamended. Every time amendments were attempted, we rejected them and, as I have said, there were a number of reasons for that.

While people may say that objectives cannot be misused by the law, the member for Lyons might realise that, in the fishing industry in Tasmania recently, because the AFMA act had been grabbed by the lawyers, something was done with respect to blue-eyed trevalla which our people and the Tasmanians did not want. Something that the two governments had agreed should not happen was taken out of their hands. In that case, it did not get to the court because a senior AFMA official simply said, `If you knock them back, they'll beat you in two days in the court. You can't win because of precedent that has been established.' In other words, everything about the AFMA act now is decided on the objectivesâwritten, I might add, with our support, as I recollect, by the then Labor government. That is a prime example of where objectives are abused by the legal system. I understand why they should be there, but we now know that you cannot do that and, as I said, the reason why a trawlerman now has blue-eyed trevalla quota in Tasmania is because he was prepared to use his lawyers and legal interpretations of the objectives of the AFMA act. Any suggestion that that was a good idea is disproved in Tasmania by a set of circumstances here and now.

This bill is about guaranteeing that people who make investments, because of their trust in the Regional Forest Agreement Act, are protected and compensated should a future government shift the goalposts. In the case of Tasmaniaâand this applies only to Tasmaniaâthe state government has already passed regional forest agreement legislation. Were the Labor Party to assist us in delivering this bill tomorrow, Tasmania would be the leader in Australia in attracting high levels of investment. It is clear, from the visit of the Tasmanian industry leaders today, that they are breaking their necks to do just that.

Why won't it happen? Two speakers have told us that there has been some sort of administrative problem in the Senate. Let me tell you what has happenedâit is what I told you would happen in my second reading speechâthe Democrats and the Greens have said, `You bring this bill on and we will talk out the entire day,' and, presumably, the next day and the day after that. I warned the House of this in my second reading speech. The government has a huge number of other pieces of legislation, one of which I understand represents something like $400 million in revenue. If it were to bring this on and confront the Democrats and the Greens, none of that other legislation would be dealt withâand the Labor Party has agreed to give it precedence and to debate it with alacrity.

There is a simple solution to this. We would be delighted to join with the Labor Party in this House and send a message to our colleaguesâto yours in the Labor Party and to mine in the Liberal Partyâthat we want them to combine and gag the Democrats and the Greens. There has been speech after speech made here today by people, as I have said, who are getting ready to send the message outâ`I am with you, boys, trust me. Forget l-a-w.' The fact is that it is not worth a zack if you are not prepared to apply a simple process: gag the Greens and the Democrats in the Senate. It is a very simple option. We just have to stand shoulder to shoulder and the bill will pass. We all know there are time considerations, but we have seen it all before. We could have sent this up to the Senate a month agoâ

talk.start.para: âYou could have brought the bill here two weeks ago for debate!

âSenator Bob Brown spoke for eight to 10 hours in the Senate last time. In no way could that time be provided to him again. Is it reasonable to have that lengthy debate? Let us consult history, as we have been reminded to do today. This bill has been in the House twice, it has come back twice and it has been debated on every one of those occasions. The Senate has had two inquiries on the bill, designed for one reason only: to try to extend the time by which the bill could be delayed. All of that has happened. But what happened the other night? The Democrats moved a motion for the hearingâit was necessary for them to be further informed on a bill which is two or three pages long!
âHow long did they get to report it?

âWith the assistance of the Labor Party, we restricted that to a practical amount of time. Who turned up to listen to the evidence? Not one Democrat. The people who created the committee did not turn up to listen. Why? Because they do not want to listen.

speech.para: This issue is simpleâI will come back here in the morning, if you like; you can let me know the answer to my questionâif I moved a motion in this House calling on the senators of our two parties to pass this bill, with one speaker a sideâthat is, one for the Greens, one for the Democrats and one for One Nation, as far as I am concernedâand then called for a vote, would you support me? That is the challenge. That is fair enough. We know what will happen. You cannot ask a government, in what is admitted to be probably the last debating week, to put at risk all the other legislation so that Senator Bob Brown and his mates can talk for eight or 10 hours. If you believe in that, come back in the morning and stand up in this place and tell me so.

talk.start.para: âYou know that this is all about your Liberal funding bill and no other bill!

âThe shadow minister for forestry and conservation makes a point that is in total contradiction with what some of his colleagues, including the member for Lyons, have said. They have said, `Let's get together on this, let's get something on the record and let's not muck around with side issues.' If you want a special committee, get them to move a motion in the Senate and get them to move a motion down hereâbut it is not appropriate to be tied to a bill which is all about giving financial guarantees to people who want to invest in forestry. We all know the process.

speech.para: The member for McMillan said we only do these things so that big business can make a quid. That just shows how juvenile he is, and he is all of that. The reality is that, when big business takes the risk, a lot of other people get jobs. We have had people standing up here every day over the last couple of days crying crocodile tears about some people who have lost their jobs. They were crocodile tears because when an opportunity is available to this House and to this parliament to lay the groundwork for substantial forestry investment, we are not going to take it because we are too frightenedâor someone isâto stand up to the Greens and the Democrats.

I saw Senator Brown this morning daring the Labor Party to gag him. I said in my second reading speech that what we are doing here is a waste of time unless the Labor Party is prepared to stand with us and gag Brown. If any member of parliament from Tasmania can go back to his electorate and say, `Boys, I was with you but we didn't have the guts to gag Bob Brown,' they should try it.

talk.start.para: âThis should have been debated two weeks ago.
âIf we had had the debate two weeks ago, Bob Brown would have spoken for another two weeks and you would not have gagged him.

âYou did not write to me at any stage. We have had plenty of time. We could rush that thing in there tomorrow morning and, as long as the two major parties were prepared to limit the debate, it would go through.
âWhy didn't you bring it in last time? Come on!

âFrom the beginning of the debate today, the shadow minister was setting the scene for the fact that it was not going to happen. Labor knew it was not going to happen because they knew in their own hearts that they did not have the guts to stand up and tell Senator Brown to shut up. That is why. He lined them up this morning, and they knuckled their foreheads. It is the old story: in the end, a forest worker's job to the Labor Party comes down to 30 Green preferences.
âThey won't believe you this time.

âThey will believe me because the solution is so simple. I will give you the opportunity: tell me that tomorrow morning you will support me in a resolution of this House calling on the Senate to pass that bill. Would you vote with me?
âWe all know that this is about your Liberal funding bill.
(Mr Hollis)â Order! We are not going to have the debate over the table. The minister has the call; no interjections.

âI do not need any smokescreens or spin doctoring. All we are talking about is one bill. There are a lot of other aspects of that particular bill that we know the Labor Party and the trade union movement do not like. You can do what you like about that. I think you have done a pretty good job by saying that it is only a one-clause bill. It is not. The fact of life is that, if this bill is to progress from this parliament at any time in the future whilst we are the government, it has to go in a simple and direct form that everybody outside this place wants, bar a few people whose determination is to have the bill so complex that they can get their lawyers or that, when somebody is seeking the assistance they needâor worse, when the industry reads itâthey will say, `I won't invest in that.'

speech.para: The government has just received a report from one of the world's leading forestry consultants, Jaakko Poyry, which is a name that is well known in the industry. They delivered the preliminary findings to the government on 8 August 2001. On page 8, there is a list of greenfield processing opportunities. Let me say that some of these are softwood; in other words, plantation. But look at the future: firstly, a softwood sawmill in Bombala can be done now from a resource position; a reconstituted softwood panel mill in Bombala now; thirdly, a proposal for Central Victoria now; and then we get to the big one: a bleached hardwood craft pulp mill in Tasmania now. The resources are there and the opportunity is there, according to one of the world's leading consultancies in this area. That is their advice to the government.

Wesley Vale is indelibly burnt in the memory of every major investor in the world. I know; they come to see me. They see the opportunities of an exchange rate, they see a resource waiting to go and they say, `Minister, when is your payment going to guarantee us a simple ride through to it and a guarantee of complete protection from sovereign risk?' That is the issue. People say it will be an issue in the election if we do not resolve it. I can promise you it will be. On that simple case, you will not be able to go to the workers in these areas and say, `They messed it up,' when you were warned in my second reading speech that if you were not prepared to block off Green's Senator Bob Brown, you could never get it past the Senate.

Bob Brown would have talked for a week, and there is no need for it. You have power in your caucus. Go and see your leader and say, `This is dumb. We shouldn't have Bob Brown telling us how to run our affairs.' It is no good saying that he would have been different if this thing had been debated a month ago. He would have talked it out. You have watched himâeight or 10 hours of debate on an eight-clause bill, as it then was. If you think you can sell that logic to working people who know who the true enemy is and who is in bed with him, you cannot do it and you will not do it. But it is up to you. Ring me up tonight, Member for Lyons, and say, `We will support you tomorrow morning in a motion calling on the Senate to give this priority and a limited debate.' Then we will know you are fair dinkum. (Time expired)

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Slipper:
