talk.start.para: âI move an opposition amendment to the motion for the second reading of this bill:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

speech.para: (1) imposing a complex and cumbersome new tax system on Australian businesses rather than delivering the simpler system it promised;
(2) increasing the compliance and cash-flow burden for Australian businesses thereby reducing their competitiveness and increasing the rate of business failures; and
(3) applying one set of tax rules for the Liberal Party and another for small businessesâ.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001 does a number of things. The first is that it clarifies the treatment of religious practitioners under the new tax system. It also amends the income tax law and the superannuation surcharge legislation to facilitate a change in the status of constitutionally protected superannuation funds that elect to become taxed superannuation funds, and it makes a couple of minor amendments.

The first changes relate to religious practitioners. Schedule 1 to this bill amends taxation legislation from 1953 and 1997. It also amends the fringe benefits tax legislation, the GST act and the ABN act to clarify the treatment of religious practitioners under the new tax system. The amendments will broadly ensure that religious practitioners who are not employees are treated in the same way as employees and office holders. The amendments do not affect the legal status of religious practitioners. Those who are not employees continue not to be employees. Under the new rules, an entity will be required to withhold, under the PAYG withholding system, from payments to a religious practitioner for activities done in the pursuit of a vocation as a religious practitioner and as a member of a religious institution. In addition, there will be amendments so that, firstly, religious practitioners will not be eligible for, nor will they need, an Australian Business Number for activities done in pursuit of a vocation as a religious practitioner and as a member of a religious institution; secondly, payments to a religious practitioner for activities done in pursuit of a vocation as a religious practitioner and as a member of a religious institution will not be subject to the `no ABN' withholding arrangements; thirdly, benefits provided by a religious institution to a religious practitioner for pastoral or related duties will continue to be exempt from tax under the FBT law; and, fourthly, activities done in pursuit of a vocation as a religious practitioner and as a member of a religious institution will not be subject to GST.

The need for this comes, in a sense, out of some debate about the question of whether religious practitioners have been employees or not. It has been saidâand, indeed, it has been held in some court judgmentsâthat religious practitioners were not employees but that they are in fact on a mission from God himself and therefore should not be considered to be employees in terms of their legal status. That potentially has some implications in relation to the way in which GST and Australian business numbers work, and this legislation is designed to clarify that issue. Recently I saw trailers for a film about a man who sues God, arising out of the fact that he makes a claim on his insurance company and it is held to be an act of God. Frustrated with that decision, he decides to sue God. I do not know whether this issue calls up the idea of seeking GST, fringe benefits tax and other payments from God. I assume not.

The amendments include a number of minor consequential amendments about the tax treatment of religious practitioners. In terms of date of effect, the withholding obligations apply to payments made on or after 1 July 2002. Amendments to the GST, Australian Business Number and fringe benefits tax law will apply from 1 July last year. The proposal was announced in the Assistant Treasurer's press release of 28 June 2000, and the amendments are expected to have no effect on estimated revenue.

The second area of the legislation I want to refer to is the change in status of constitutionally protected superannuation funds. Schedule 2 to the bill amends the income tax law and the superannuation surcharge legislation to facilitate the change in status of constitutionally protected superannuation funds that elect to become taxed superannuation funds. The amendments will ensure that members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds which have changed status are treated similarly, for income tax and superannuation surcharge purposes, to members who roll over benefits from an untaxed source to a taxed source. This change has effect going back to 1 July last year. It was announced on 16 June last year. Its revenue impact involves revenue of $25 million being brought forward in the 2001-02 year. Consequently, there will be a loss to revenue of $1 million per annum from 2002-03 onwards.

The next area I want to talk about involves capital gains tax and, in particular, capital payment for trust interest. Schedule 3 to this bill amends the income tax legislation of 1997 to ensure that capital gains tax event E4 does not apply to payments of capital gains tax discount amounts made by trustees to beneficiaries, that it does not apply to payments of capital gains tax discount amounts made by trustees to beneficiaries that are trustees of trusts in chains of trusts, and that it applies to payments associated with building allowances made by trustees to beneficiaries. There are a number of minor amendments to facilitate the intended effect.

There is a transitional measure which corrects the chain of trusts deficiencies. That applies to payments made by trustees on or after 11.45 a.m., legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 21 September 1999 and anything before 1 July 2001. The remaining amendments apply to payments made by trustees on or after 1 July 2001.

The part of the proposal relating to payments of capital gains tax discount amounts and payments associated with building allowances was announced by the Treasurer on 22 March this year. The part relating to chains of trusts was announced by the Assistant Treasurer on 31 July. I do not think the technical amendments have previously been announced. The financial impact of this measure as it relates to capital gains tax discount amounts was included in the estimates when we saw the New Business Tax System (Integrity and Other Measures) Bill 1999. This measure, as it relates to payments associated with building allowances, is estimated to raise revenue of $5 million next financial year, rising to $40 million per annum after 10 years.

There is also a set of amendments in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001 concerning gifts or contributions. That is to say, schedule 4 to the bill allows income tax deductions for certain gifts of $2 or more made to a series of organisations: Southcare Helicopter Fund, Breast Cancer Network Australia, Dymocks Literacy Foundation Ltd, Sir Earle Page Memorial Trust, Research Australia Ltd, Reconciliation Australia Ltd, RSL Foundation, Australian Chinese Ex-Services National Reunion War Memorial Fund, Royal Australian Air Force Memorial Trust Fund, Voluntary Services to Indigenous Communities Foundation, Australia for UNHCR, Bradman Memorial Fund, Foundation for Young Australians and Visy Cares Charitable Trust. There are various dates for that tax deductible status to come into effect. The Prime Minister announced, back on 7 December, that income tax deductibility would be provided to Reconciliation Australia Ltd. The other things have been announced by press release by the Assistant Treasurer. It is expected that there will be an insubstantial cost to the revenue as a result of those organisations receiving tax deductible status.

The final schedule to the bill that I want to talk about concerns the information and communications technology area. Schedule 5 exempts from income tax the income of a nonprofit society or association established for the purpose of promoting the development of Australian information and communications technology resources. The bill also amends the fringe benefits tax legislation to provide a rebate of fringe benefits tax to an employer that is a nonprofit society or an association established for the purpose of promoting the development of information and communications technology, aquaculture and fishing resources of Australia. The exemption applies from 1 July 2000. The fringe benefits tax rebate applies from 1 April 2000. The amendments concerning aquaculture and fishing resources apply back to 1 April 1999. They have been previously announced. Once again, there is an unquantifiable, but expected to be insubstantial, cost to the revenue. The opposition is not opposing the bill and regards these amendments as appropriate.

In speaking to the second reading amendment which I have moved, I wish to point out to the House, first, that we are receiving news with each passing day about the adverse effect that the GST is having on our economy. We have seen evidence of this in the shape of the largest corporate collapses that this country has seen. We remember the collapse of HIH and the fact that it had complained bitterly previously about the impact of GST on insurance, the payouts that it was making and the prospective impact on premiums. We have also seen evidence of the impact of GST concerning the tourism industry in relation to Ansett and, most recently, in the retail area. If we go back to last week and the employment figures that were released last Wednesday, we can see that in the last five months 76,400 full-time jobs have been lost, which is the equivalent of nearly five Ansetts, and 87,700 full-time jobs, which is the equivalent of 5Â½ Ansetts, have been lost since the GST was introduced. So, since the GST was introduced, 87,700 full-time jobs have been lost and the growth rate in job creation has more than halved. The growth rate of employment has more than halved since the GST was introduced. The GST is clobbering full-time jobsâa matter of considerable and, I believe, growing concern around the community.

I also make reference to the fact that the GST has been having an adverse impact on the cost of living. It has made it harder to make ends meet. Price rises have been pushing up the cost of living and ordinary Australian families are hurting as a result. John Howard broke his promise that no-one would be worse off under the GST. In fact, millions of Australians are now living under greater financial pressure because the GST has increased the cost of living. We have also seen the GST hurting small business, costing jobs and putting millions of Australian families under financial pressure. The much vaunted tax cuts are effectively gone before you get them. I think Australians can be conscious of the fact that any tax cuts that this Prime Minister promises will be taken away by the GST and increased costs of living, just as the last ones were. If you get a tax cut, it will be taken away through higher GST and higher prices.

Labor believes that we ought to be taking the GST off some essential items to make it fairer and simpler; that that is the real solution to the mess created by the Prime Minister and the Liberal Party's GST. Our priorities are straightforward: we want to improve our schools, improve our hospitals and remove the GST from essential items. The fact is that income tax cuts always get eaten up over time. If you take the GST off an item, that is a tax cut for everyone, for ever. Families, and older Australians in particular, will benefit most from the removal of the GST from essential items. We also propose to compensate charities for the impact of GST on them. Why should charities pay the GST when they are about helping the community and helping the poor? They are not about helping themselves and they deserve some additional support.

I mentioned in my second reading amendment that this House ought to condemn the government for applying one set of tax rules to the Liberal Party and another for small businesses. Leaked documents concerning the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party revealed a scam to defraud the tax office of GST payments, following a fundraising dinner attended by Treasurer Costello and the Minister for Small Business. Back on 23 November last year, the Groom Federal Electorate Council held a fundraising dinner in Toowoomba, with Treasurer Costello as its guest speaker. Tickets for this gala night of political insight and fine dining were $80. The leaked minutes of the Groom Federal Electorate Council executive have in fact revealed an elaborate scheme to defraud the tax office of GST revenue.

At the time of the dinner, the Groom FEC was not registered for GSTâmeaning it could not collect GST, but nor could it claim GST input tax credits; that is, it could not seek a credit or refund from the tax office for GST it paid on any goods or services it purchased. Evidence contained in the minutes and other information leaked from within the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party show that an arrangement was entered into so that the catering bill for the function would be paid by the Queensland Liberal Party headquartersâa registered GST entity which subsequently claimed a GST input credit to the value of $826.41. The catering bill was originally paid, appropriately, by the Groom FEC, but that payment was later retrieved from the caterer to allow the Liberal headquarters to pay the amount, thereby swindling the tax office. The Minister for Small Business was present at meetings at which this contrived mechanism was discussed and imposed on the FEC treasurer against her will. Her objections were recorded in the leaked minutes. The treasurer of the FEC, Ms Margaret Watts, later resigned over the issue.
The minutes also show that the FEC sought advice on the issue from a firm of accountants. That advice concluded that the arrangements should not be used, and it said:

quote.para: ... we further express the view that the Commissioner of Taxation could attack these transactions ...

speech.para: The documents also reveal that the matter was brought to the attention of the federal Treasurer, Peter Costello, and that he `carpeted' the small business minister over the issue. There is, however, no evidence that the Treasurer himself took any action to refer the GST avoidance to the tax officeâ

talk.start.para: âThat is extraordinary.

âIt is extraordinaryâor to arrange for the evaded GST revenue to be paid to the tax office. There is evidence that this scam was used in relation to at least two other Queensland Liberal federal electorate councils. The then Queensland Liberal State Director, Graham Jaeschke, has asserted that this GST scam was put in place on the advice of the federal Liberal secretariat. The actions of the Groom FEC treasurer, Margaret Watts, led in February this year to the federal director of the party, Lynton Crosby, advising that the mechanism was `not feasible' and should be shut down.

speech.para: That was an appalling set of developments. In order to give other speakers some opportunity to speak, I do not intend to canvass it in further detail. But, essentially, we have a situation which the Treasurer and the Minister for Small Business were aware ofâ the Groom Liberal Party FEC executive entering into a scam arrangement with the Queensland Liberal Party to obtain GST input tax credits for the catering of a fundraiser involving those two ministers, without paying the GST, and failing to refer this GST scam by the Groom Liberal FEC executive and other Queensland Liberal Party branches for investigation by the tax office and the Federal Police. That is what they have done. They were complicit in the Liberal Party not paying its fair share of GST, while claiming the GST was going to end the black economy. These are serious breaches of even the Prime Minister's discredited ministerial code of conduct with respect to the obligations of ministers.

We have a situation where a tax audit has been proposed to the Queensland Liberal Party. It, however, will not be able to examine whether ministers misled the parliament, whether the Treasurer failed in his duty to alert the tax office to this scam, whether the small business minister failed in his duty to do the same thing or to take any action to shut down the scam. It cannot investigate whether any Liberal Party officers, federal or state, have acted improperly, or possibly unlawfully, in advising on and arranging the scam, and whether this arrangement has spread beyond Queensland to other Liberal state divisions. It is also the case that the outcome of this audit is only a public matter if the Queensland Liberal Party allows it. It is a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. On that basis, I would urge the House to support my amendment concerning the fact that this government has imposed a cumbersome and complex new tax system on Australian businesses rather than a simpler system and that it has increased the compliance and cash flow burden for Australian businessesâand we have seen evidence that even the government itself understands that cash flow issues can be relevant. We have been talking about the Ansett collapse recently, but this is a government which, through the GST, has increased cash flow problems for small businesses, thereby reducing their competitiveness and increasing the rate of business failures. Finally, it has been applying one set of tax rules for the Liberal Party and another for small businesses. On that basis, I urge the House to support the amendment.

talk.start.para: (Mrs De-Anne Kelly)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

â There is no way that the House should support the amendment moved by the member for Wills, the spokesman for the opposition, to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001. It is beyond all thought that such a stupid thing should be done by responsible people. What the member is proposing is another addition to the process of what I call roll-backâchanges to the goods and services tax, which will make the system more complicated and more difficult to manage.

speech.para: I have looked up the remarks of some of the people who have commented on roll-back, and some of them made some interesting comments about the Labor Party's proposed policy. For instance, Mark Paterson from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, an organisation representing a lot of businesses, said:

quote.para: Further roll-back would only increase complexity.

speech.para: Rob Bastian, head of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australian, said on Sky News on 23 May 2001:

quote.para: Of course, we're frightened about that rollback statement. The Opposition has been trying very hard to convince us that we're talking about rolling back complexity, but, of course, if we're rolling back coverage of the GST, then that will increase the complexity and that will cause a lot of pain.

speech.para: He was also quoted in the Age of 13 July 2000 as follows:

quote.para: Roll-back would âincrease complexity, increase supervision and that means increased fear.â
âThe uncertainty about roll-back has to be addressed because we need clarity.
âMr Beazley's taking the usual political stand to keep his powder dry but that position is not going to help and it is becoming an albatross around his neck.â

speech.para: On the same day he was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:

quote.para: âIt is fundamentally unacceptable to small business to suggest that we should have more exemptions.â

speech.para: That is the situation out there in small business. People do not want roll-back. It is extra complexity, it is extra cost and it is extra difficulty. The definitional problems alone are just unimaginable. Even the Chief Executive of the Institute of Chartered Accountants Australia, Stephen Harrison, said on Sky News on 6 March 2000:

quote.para: If a future government were to introduce even further exemptions, we'll be taking ourselves backwards into the complex environment that we currently face for the wholesale sales tax;â

speech.para: There you areâcomparing it with the ancient, collapsed wholesale sales tax. He continued:

quote.para: we'll be turning back the clock and destroying many of the benefits that can be accrued from a simplified system through the GST.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: If you introduce exemptions, then by doing that you really do take us back into the complex environment of the wholesale sales tax, because people will be constantly looking up which good it is and how it's to be treated, whereas the concept of the wholesale sales tax, or the removal of a wholesale sales tax, was to remove those complexities and have a very simple system.

speech.para: Gordon Cooper, President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, was quoted as saying on ABC Radio National's Australia Talks Back program on 22 February 2000:

quote.para: If more products are GST-free, then it just adds to the complexity and the poor shopkeeper who's selling a mix of GST-free and GST taxed goods is going to find it really difficult.

speech.para: It is very interesting to look at the comments made by Alan McKenzie and Sam Richardson, the national spokesman and Tasmanian spokesman, respectively, of the National Association of Retail Grocers. This is what they said at a press conference in Canberra on 4 April 2001:

quote.para: Journalist: Would a roll back of the GST ease the burden?
Sam Richardson: No.
Alan McKenzie: No.
Sam Richardson: We're not talking roll back. We're talking simplification and compensation ...

Alan McKenzie: So roll back worries us.... And one of those concerns would be if we start seeing a roll back program, for example taking the GST off certain items, all that's going to do to us is add complexity.

speech.para: And I refer to Helen Clark, the Prime Minister of New Zealandâsomebody who ought to have some experience and authority. Helen Clark, commenting on the concept of roll-back on the Channel 9 Sunday program of 27 February 2000, said:

quote.para: ... it is a very well accepted tax at the moment and no one seriously thinks it would ever be changed ...

speech.para: The interviewer asked:

quote.para: And does it apply to things like tampons, for example, and if so, have you ever thought of lifting the tax off items like that?

speech.para: Helen Clark responded:

quote.para: No. ... And I think it is true to say that once you start differentiating between classes of goods, you get into anomalies that can be a bit hard to explain ...

speech.para: That is Helen Clark, the Labor Prime Minister of New Zealand, saying that concepts of exemptions and roll-backs are crazyâthat they create further problems, complications and difficulties in the explanation of it. She is a person that was elected for her political savvy and yet we have the Australian Labor Party saying: `Well, the New Zealanders have had a lot of experience. We've got a Labor Prime Minister there that says, âDon't grant exemptions, don't make changes,â but we're going to ignore that.' There is a lot more wisdom, they claim, on their side of politicsâwithout experience, without knowledgeâthan with the Prime Minister of New Zealand.

Then there is the proposal, for instance, to make books GST free. I am indebted to my colleague the member for La Trobe who, in an article in the Age on 29 June 2001, pointed out that the National Association of Retail Grocers did a survey of over 1,000 businesses and they complained about the complexity in exempting food. He then pointed out the problems with definitions for books and asked:

quote.para: Would magazines and newspapers be exempt?

speech.para: Good question. He continued:

quote.para: What about academic journals, Mills & Boon, periodicals, Readers' Digest, yearbooks, Women's Weekly cookbooks, diaries, atlases and road maps, stationery, pornographic books, booklets, books on tape, books on CD?

speech.para: Where are you going to start drawing the lines? The Australian Labor Party have not got a clue on the exemption of books or any of the other things that they are planning to exempt. It just will not work. Why should a National Geographic, for instance, be considered a book and an educational publication like the Age be considered not to be a book? Tell me where you are going to draw some of the lines. You guys in the Australian Labor Party, with this roll-back program that you have got, have got no idea. You have no idea on the whole of the tax system.
I refer to comments by Simon Crean on the vexed problem of excise on petrol when he was interviewed on 31 March 2000. He was asked:

quote.para: What about fuel excise, Mr Crean? That causes a lot of problems too. Whatâwhat sort of commitment can Labor make regarding fuel excise?

speech.para: Mr Crean said:

quote.para: Well, what we'veâbasically our position has been that there needs to be this mix between indirect taxes and direct taxes. We always had fuel excise in that mix. We were not proposing to make any changes to the fuel excise regime.

speech.para: That was when indexation was on. Are they going back to indexation? Are they going to keep it non-indexed, as it is now? What further changes are they going to make to the tax system? They are reducing revenue. Where are they going to raise the extra revenue from? Mr Crean concluded his comments in relation to changes to the fuel excise regime by saying:

motion.para: That wasn't the issue.

speech.para: In conclusion, I just want to draw to the attention of the House some of the changes that have been made by this government by wiping out a number of taxes and putting in a broad based consumer tax. There have been changes to and simplification of the capital gains tax for business operators and individuals. There have been reductions in income tax rates for companies, including small companies. There is the simplified tax system. Businesses with an annual turnover of less than $1 million can elect to join the simplified tax system from 1 July, which delivers a number of benefits.

Just to give a small example, in 1993 a taxpayer on an income of $38,001 went on to the marginal rate of 43 per cent. If that threshold had been indexed to the CPI, that would have been $43,598 on 1 July 2000. However, the coalition cut taxation and that threshold has been raised to $50,000. Those with an income of between $20,000 and $50,000 now face a top marginal rate of only 30 per cent. Had tax reform not occurred and the then threshold of $38,001 been merely indexed, they would have had a 43 per cent marginal tax rate.

The proposals and the tax management of the Australian Labor Party were crippling the average person. It is all very well for the Australian Labor Party to say, `Those tax cuts soon vanish.' They may be soon forgotten, but they are still there. Because of a regime of low inflation and low interest rates, the benefits continue year after year. They go on for a long time. Young people buying their homes in my electorate realise the benefits of very substantial tax cuts, which allow them to take advantage and to purchase homes. Our district is booming. People are buying into the hills district of New South Wales in huge numbers because they are getting great value for the homes that are being built. They know they can cover their costs. The stability of low inflation and low interest rates are greatly to their advantage, and of course the tax cuts, which are possible because of the simplified tax system, have improved their opportunities as well.

talk.start.para: â The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001 proposes a series of amendments to the so-called streamlined new tax system for a new century, just as yesterday the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2001 sought to amend the streamlined new tax system for a new century. It is for these reasons that the Labor opposition has decided to put forward a second reading amendment which in fact accepts the various proposals in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001 but goes on to say:

quote.para: âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

speech.para: (1) imposing a complex and cumbersome new tax system on Australian businesses rather than delivering the simpler system it promised;
(2) increasing the compliance and cash-flow burden for Australian businesses hereby reducing their competitiveness and increasing the rate of business failures; and
(3) applying one set of tax rules for the Liberal Party and another for small businesses.â

It is to that second reading amendment that I wish to speak tonight. The most systematic way I can do that is to go through a range of promises that the government made in the lead-up to the last election and subsequently in relation to implementing its so-called streamlined new tax system for a new century.
The first promise that the government made that sticks in my mind is a promise to reduce small business red tape. The now defence minister and Leader of the House said on 8 September 1998:

quote.para: We have also taken the opportunity in our new tax plan to significantly reduce red tape for small business.

speech.para: When the government came to power, the Income Tax Act was in the vicinity of 3,000 pages. It has now grown to 8,500 pages as a result of the simplification and the slashing of red tape that the government promised. I have here not the full Income Tax Act but simply the additions to the Income Tax Act. And it is not just this pile; it is this one as well. This is the net result of the streamlined new tax system for a new century in respect of the Income Tax Act.

We as Australians all know that there was another process in train as a result of commitments made by the government before the last election, and that was to introduce the goods and services tax. So, if I add on the legislation and the explanatory memoranda for the goods and services tax, this is the net result of the government's commitment to cutting red tape and simplifying the tax system. I remind you that this is not the entire Income Tax Act but only the additions to it since the government came to power. In the context of the government saying that they would slash red tape for small business by 50 per cent, you can tell with this red tape holding these piles together they have not done that at all; they have massively increased red tape for small business and have massively increased the complexity of the Income Tax Act. And just to make things that much more painful, they have introduced a goods and services tax.

Let us have a look at the goods and services tax. This legislation and explanatory material in fact weighs 7.1 kilograms and, as of yesterday, the legislation itself had already been amended 1,861 times. So much for the commitment by the Treasurer who, when he came back to work after the Christmas holidays this year and was asked on radio whether the GST legislation would be amended again, said:
No. There is in no need for further amendments; we have got it right.

Well, he was out by 1,861 amendments as of yesterday, and there are further amendments in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2001 to the GST act. It is nothing like a streamlined new tax system for a new century; it is a very complex tax system indeed.

We may well ask, if this was supposed to be such a streamlined new tax system for a new century, why would it need so much explanation? Why would the GST itself need so much explanation? I can reveal that in calendar year 2000 alone there were more than 89,000 private binding rulings issued by the Australian Taxation Office. Let us be clear what a private binding ruling is: it is a clarification of the tax. If it is supposed to be so simple, why did the tax office feel obliged to issue 89,000 clarifications to the tax system? Of those, 3,500 were clarifications to the Income Tax Act, and the balanceâmore than 84,000âwere clarifications to the GST. We do not even know how many of these private binding rulings have been issued since the end of calendar year 2000. But at that rate, if I were to pile up the total number of private binding rulings, they would not quite get to the roof of the chamber but they might be touching the bottom of the Australian flag.

The impact of all this complexity has been to place a very heavy burden on business, in particular the small business sector. I draw the attention of the House to a comment that was made by the Treasurer on 18 May last year when he was asked about the impact of the GST on small business. He told Perth radio:

quote.para: I don't think anybody will go to the wall as a consequence of the GST. I don't think that there will be businesses that will founder because of the GST.

speech.para: The fact of the matter is that there has been a huge increase in small business bankruptcies under the GST. In fact, in the June quarter of this year, compared with the same period of the previous year, there was a 78 per cent increase in small business bankruptcies. The government is in a state of denial about this, saying that that has got nothing to do with the GST, that it must be related to the greenhouse effect. One apologist for the government said, `The reason for that would be a reduction in sales, not the GST.' We ask the rhetorical question: what caused the reduction in sales? There are two plausible explanations: the greenhouse effect, or climate change, or the GST. My money is on the GST, but I think the government is still batting on that the greenhouse effect has had such a profound effect on small businesses that that explains a 78 per cent increase in bankruptcies.

In addition, Labor warned that corner stores would be hard hit by the GST. Again, very sadly, those chickens have come home to roost. A recent study has revealed that already almost 1,000 corner stores have closed. That has been directly attributed by the authors of that study to the GST. Let there be no misunderstanding: the GST has had a very heavy impact on the viability of small business in this country. But it is quite clear that the GST has also had quite a severe impact on big business. I do not purport to say that every corporate collapse that has occurred in this country, and an increasing number of them at that, is solely due to the GST. But if you look at some of the difficulties that are being experienced you will see that there is a GST influenceâfor example, Harris Scarfe.

talk.start.para: âHarris Scarfe!

âOf course, there may be other explanations, but the GST imposed a 10 per cent tax on clothing, and there was no wholesale sales tax on clothing. The minister opposite is astounded that there could be any relationship between the GST and the difficulties that Harris Scarfe got into. I am sure he, like other ministers, will be in a state of denial that the GST could have anything to do with the current difficulties been experienced by Coles Myer. What do Coles Myer do? They sell clothes in particular. Again, clothes are an item. Target, a division of Coles Myer, is in very significant difficulty. Again, there is a 10 per cent tax on clothing. The Prime Minister said in the parliament, `Oh yes, but Woolworths is doing very well.' Of course, Woolworths sells a lot of fresh food, one of the few items to which a GST does not apply.

speech.para: In relation to the operation of the GST, this tax is supposed to be a streamlined tax and an efficient way of collecting revenue. I have done some research on that and it transpires that, for every dollar of net GST collected, another $5.60 is collected and then refunded in the form of input tax credits. So $6.60 is collected, of which the government keeps $1 and refunds $5.60 in the form of input tax credits. It has got to be one of the most inefficient taxes you could possibly imagine, when you are collecting $6.60 to keep $1.

Labor have talked about simplifying the GST and we have developed a set of proposals on that which was floated by the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in a Press Club speech. The Minister for Small Business immediately condemned it, saying it was impossible to simplify the GST. Well, I reckon it is pretty easy to simplify the GST when you look at this pile here!

talk.start.para: âHow?

âThe minister opposite asks how. The small business minister's department responded to the minister's request to do a hatchet job on the proposals put forward by the shadow Treasurer in relation to what the department calls a `ratio by turnover' method. I will read from the departmental brief, which he circulated. He must not have read it properly to have circulated such a frank assessment from the department, because it says:

quote.para: A ratio by turnover method is a reasonable option for calculating GST as long as the ratio continues to be an accurate reflection of the net GST position of the business.

speech.para: We have developed proposals to ensure that that is a viable way of going. The minister warned when this was released that the small business community would hate it. In fact, in a statement made not so long ago, on 8 August, Rob Bastian, the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, said he had seen a presentation of Labor's ratio model for GST payments and walked away happy. I made that presentation, and I will quote him:

quote.para: I can say with absolute clarity that the members of the association who were in the room were very impressed with the idea because it was simple.

speech.para: There is Labor putting forward a simple proposal and the government saying, `You cannot make this dog's breakfast of a tax any simpler.' Of course you can make it simpler. The media release of 8 August 2001 goes on to state:

quote.para: Mr Bastian rejected suggestions by Small Business Minister Ian Macfarlane that small business was happy with existing arrangements and did not want Labor's rollback.

speech.para: Mr Bastian is quoted as saying:

quote.para: I do not believe that. The main concern as reported to me is paperwork itself.

speech.para: There you have the peak body of the small business sector in Australia saying that Labor's proposal to simplify the GST is very worth while, and the small business minister, who should be an advocate for small business and who should be sticking up for small business, saying, `No, we've got the GST right.' It is about as complex a tax as you can possibly imagine and it has imposed a big burden on small business. I refer to another promise of the government, and that is that the GST would create more jobs. The Treasurer, at page 155 of the document entitled A New Tax System of 23 August 1998, says:

quote.para: The combination of higher growth and improved work incentives will deliver more jobs and lower unemployment.

speech.para: We know that, since the GST came in, the rate of job growth has halved and the unemployment rate has gone up. I do not quite get it. How would a $24 billion tax create more jobs? It is a simple question that Labor asked at the time. We were told that it was because it was going to replace 10 taxes. We have one very complex taxâa $24 billion taxâ replacing 10 taxes. What happened? It did not replace 10 taxes at all, it replaced four taxes, and one of those taxes was a bed tax that applied in some hotels in Sydney and in the Northern Territory. I do not understand how the people of Victoria, South Australia or Queensland would benefit from the abolition of the bed tax, but that was one of the major taxes that the government said would go under the GST, and it is one of the few taxes that did go. But six of those taxesâ stamp duties, mainlyâdid not go.

That goes to another promise by the government, and that is that the GST would not be a tax on a tax. There is a litany of examples where the GST is a tax on a tax, including the most infamous case of petrol excise, which takes us to a promise by the Prime Minister, in his address to the nation before the last election, that the price of petrol would not rise for the ordinary motorist under the GST. That is yet another broken promise, because the government increased the net tax payable on petrol on 1 July by reducing fuel excise by only 6.7c a litre but imposing an 8.2c a litre GST. The rest, as they say, is history. Finally, the government, after going ahead with a fuel excise increase on 1 February this year, which we said it should not do and which we said it could afford to abandon, said that it would not abandon it; it could not afford to abandon it. We have seen budget surplus figures today that clearly show what we were saying all along: it could be afforded. The government finally back-flipped three weeks later, only because it had lost the state elections in Western Australia and in Queensland and was about to lose the by-election in the federal seat of Ryan. Those are just a few examples of the complexity and the economic impacts of this tax. The commitment of Labor is to simplify the GSTâwe have practical proposals to do thatâand to make the GST fairer.

The government says that this tax systemâI again refer to all the documentsâhas a certain integrity about it, that it is streamlined, and that to take the GST off anything would destroy the integrity of this dog's breakfast of a tax. Again, I have done some rough calculations and it appears that the GST applies to about 70 per cent of consumption. What is the magic in that figure of 70 per cent? There is no magic in that figure of 70 per cent. If the GST were taken off some items, it might fall back to 68, 65, 63 per cent or whatever, depending on what items you took it off. I do not understand the government's thinking that 70 per cent is a magical number, but that 68, 67, 65 or another figure somehow lacks all integrity, whereas this dog's breakfast of a tax, according to the government, is full of integrity. There is a very clear choice for people at the upcoming election: do they want a simpler, fairer GST? If they do, they will vote Labor.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to participate in this debate and in particular to support the Labor Party's amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 2001, which, as the member for Rankin has pointed out, states:

quote.para: âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

speech.para: (1) imposing a complex and cumbersome new tax system on Australian businesses rather than delivering the simpler system it promised;
(2) increasing the compliance and cash-flow burden for Australian businesses hereby reducing their competitiveness and increasing the rate of business failures; and
(3) applying one set of tax rules for the Liberal Party and another for small businessesâ.

I have spoken in this place on a number of occasions about the impact of the GST upon small businesses in my electorate of the Northern Territory. As the member for Rankin pointed out, over a period we have had a 78 per cent increase in bankruptcies. That should be a sufficient indicator to the government of the enormous damage that this tax system has caused to small business across Australia. I live in a remote part of Australia where the cost of living in all circumstances is higher than it is in major capital cities. I am sure that communities in your electorate, Madam Deputy Speaker, share the impact of the GST upon small business and know what it means to those communities. It is worth while contemplating what the impact of the GST would be on small businesses in the Northern Territory, where the economy has taken a real hit over the last 18 months, in the first instance as a result of the GST and, secondly, as a result of the end of some expenditures by the federal government.

A large number of businesses went to the wall. Currently, small business throughout the Northern Territory is feeling the repercussions of the demise of Ansett. We know that, with the increasing impact on those small businesses as a result of the demise of Ansett, for them to meet their obligations under the GST will be enormously difficult. It is already difficult, but if fewer people go through the doors of small businesses as a result of the demise of Ansett, in respect of which around 700 people will be out of work in the Northern Territory, small businesses will feel the direct impact of that exercise. In the face of that, they have to meet their GST compliance costs.

I have visited a small business, a gunsmith, in my electorate over recent months. Like a lot of small businesses of that type, the gunsmith employs himself and, at the very most, only two or three other people. A substantial proportion of the small businesses throughout the Northern Territory are like that; they are literally small businesses. Any increasing impost as a result of GST compliance costs affects them badly. The gunsmith has a sign on his door which says, `Gunsmith and tax collector.' He absolutely resents, as do other businesses in my electorate, the responsibility of having to collect tax on behalf of the government and the costs that that tax collection adds to the running of his small business.

We need to comprehend that even conservative commentators, and even conservative politicians, are understanding the impact of the GST on their communitiesâbelatedly, I might add, but nevertheless they are recognising it. I want to refer to some commentaries that have been made by CLP politicians in the Northern Territory, one of whom is Shane Stone, who was then Northern Territory Chief Minister and who is now Liberal Party President. He stated:

quote.para: Territorians are better off with this package, including the GST, than anything the Labor Party has put on the table. I say to Territorians that you will have more money in your pocket.

speech.para: I am sure that those Territorians in small business and Territory families understand comprehensively that that is not the case. They resent the patronising way in which the then CLP Chief Minister advocated on behalf of the coalition the need for the acceptance of the GST.

Senator Grant Tambling, the CLP senator for the Northern Territory, stated that 99 per cent of Territorians would not be affected by the GST. We all know that that is a fib, and I will refer shortly to a group of Territorians who are most adversely affected by it. I want also to refer to the comments of the then Northern Territory Treasurer, Mike Reed, who is, thankfully, no longer the Treasurer after his recent exercise. As they went into the election, the Northern Territory CLP said that they had a $12 million budget deficit. After the election, the new ALP government had a look at the books and they discovered not a $12 million deficit but a $107 million deficit, such was the honesty of the CLP and the then Treasurer, Mr Mike Reed. He said:

quote.para: The package has been designed to minimise costs faced by business and reduce the administrative and compliance burden of the current multi-tax system.

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: With the expected boost to the economy from the package, construction activity is expected to be better off at least in the medium term.

speech.para: Both of those statements have been revealed to be false. The assertions have been demonstrably false in the case of the Northern Territory and small businesses have suffered. In the period after the introduction of the GST, the construction industry about which the then Northern Territory Treasurer spoke had very difficult times indeed.

However, it does not take long for some people to be liberated. In the case of the Northern Territory, it took no time at all for the previous Northern Territory Chief Minister, Denis Burke, to become liberated, because a headline in the Australian Financial Review of 21 August of this year stated: `NT's Burke lashes out over GST.' You might ask, `Why would he lash out over the GST? After all, he was a conservative leader and an advocate of the GST.' The answer is pretty simple: he had just been done at an election. After he had been done at the election, he pondered why he might have lost that election. One of the reasons he properly surmised for his losing that election was the GST.

The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and every other member of the cheer squad on the government benches are trying to convince Australians that they are somehow better off under the GST. There has been very recent electoral experience which now clearly demonstrates that people do not like the GST and that they know that they are not better off under it. According to the report in the Financial Review of 21 August:

quote.para: Mr Burke's comments on the GST are embarrassing to the federal Coalition, which is hoping to minimise voter backlash to the tax in the lead-up to the election.

speech.para: According to the article, Mr Burke:

quote.para: ... conceded the tax had bred resentment among voters.
Mr Burke said voters felt resentment and hurt over the GST.

speech.para: As well they might. Let me ask the minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, how should voters who live in north-east Arnhem Landâ

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)â Order! The member for the Northern Territory will address his remarks through the chair.

âThrough you, Mr Deputy Speaker, Minister, what might the good voters of the north-east Arnhem Land region of the Northern Territory or the Western Desert communities of the Northern Territory and Western Australia be thinking of the GST right at this moment? The reason I ask that question is that, in the case of the Western Desert communities, 44.3 per cent of families have annual incomes below $15,600. That is family income.

speech.para: I note the Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Ruddock, is at the table. Perhaps he would like to contemplate what the people in the Miwatch area of Nhulunbuy, in the Aboriginal communities of north-east Arnhem Land, might be thinking about this. After all, they are, in a sense, subject to his edicts in his portfolio. I know that he is talking across the table, but he might just contemplate this. The incomes of 36.6 per cent of the families who live in north-east Arnhem Land are less than $15,600 a year. What do you think they might be thinking about the GST? Do you think they would see this as a boon? We know, as a result of work I have done at previous times in this parliament, that the average cost of a basket of goods in north-east Arnhem Landâin addition to the cost in terms of indicesâwas 206 per cent of the average cost of goods in capital cities across Australia.

You have to ask yourself: why would people in these communities say it is really terrific to be paying 10 per cent more for goods and services when they have median incomes of around $15,500 per family and they know they pay costs, in terms of their services, well above what their counterparts in Sydney and Melbourneâor those in the Prime Minister's electorate of Bennelongâ might be paying? They have to be thankful for the GST. What about the people in Darwin? Darwin is a major metropolitan centre. A survey using a straight average on a basket of goods with 55 selected retail items discovered that the cost in Darwin was six per cent higher than the average across Australia. We are the most expensive jurisdiction. The basket of goods in Darwin was $270.52, and the average across Australia was $256. The most expensive city after Darwin was Canberra.

People are not fools and ultimately they will pass their judgment on this GST package, and ultimately people who run small businesses in the Northern Territory will pass their judgment, as they have the right to do and as they did in the recent Northern Territory election. The problem that the government have is that they believe, and they have tried to con the Australian community into believing, that somehow or other people would gain great benefits from this GST package. I know that the Prime Minister took some delight in trying to rubbish the words of Gerry Harvey this afternoonâ

talk.start.para: âHe didn't. He just quoted him.
âIt is worth reminding ourselves of what Gerry Harvey said, Minister McGauran:

quote.para: The GST was a much bigger problem than the terrorist attacks, Ansett, HIH, One.Tel and 10 other disasters you could name.

speech.para: What do you think of that, Minister? What do you think of that? Are you prepared to cop what Gerry Harvey says? Do you accept what he, executive chairman of a major retailer, says? He understands the impact of the GST, and small businesses in my electorate know the impact of the GST. People who live in cities such as Darwin or Alice Springs understand the GST and what its implications have been. Small businesses in those communities know what the implications have been for them. They know what it has added to the costs of running their businesses. We also know that those people who live in the most remote communities in Australiaâthe poorest of all Australians and the most disadvantaged of all Australiansâare hit hardest by this regressive tax. Yet we see no apology from the government, and they try to rubbish the Labor Party when we say that we propose to remove the GST from essential items and from charities.

It is worth noting that we are not alone. I conclude by noting an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday, 10 September 2001. It refers to the survey in the report, `Route trade in Australia 2001-2003', as:

quote.para: ... the first study of the $4 billion corner shop industry. Nearly half of the shops surveyed said the GST was cutting profits and shrinking incomes.

speech.para: We know that, as a result, as this article says:

quote.para: Corner shops, classified as independently owned, fell in number from about 8,000 nationwide three years ago to just over 7,000 last year, with an annual 2 per cent decline forecast.

speech.para: The report's author, Mr Sandro Mangosi, said:

quote.para: The last straw for these small shops has been the GST.

speech.para: I do not think I need to say much more. The judges are the consumers. The judges are those small businesses around Australia. They know. They are not going to be fooled or conned by the untruths coming from the government, whatever the Prime Minister or the Treasurer might like to think.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill implements one of the government's important policy initiatives within the immigration and multicultural affairs portfolio.

The bill gives legislative effect to the government's longstanding commitment to introduce legislation that in migration matters will restrict access to judicial review in all but exceptional circumstances. This commitment was made in light of the extensive merits review rights in the migration legislation and concerns about the growing cost and incidence of migration litigation and the associated delays in removal of non-citizens with no right to remain in Australia.

The bill introduces a new judicial review scheme for decisions made under the Migration Act relating to the entry to, and stay in Australia, of non-citizens of Australia. The key mechanism in the new scheme is the privative clause provision at new section 474.

The privative clause, and the related provisions, will replace the existing judicial review scheme at part 8 of the Migration Act. Unlike the existing scheme, the new judicial review scheme will also apply to the High Court and not just the Federal Court.

The privative clause does not mean that access to the courts is denied, nor that only the High Court can hear migration matters. Both the Federal Court and the High Court can hear migration matters, but the grounds of judicial review before either court have been limited.
One need only look at the history of the existing judicial review scheme and how it is operating today to see what would happen in the future if it were left untouched.

The current judicial review scheme for visa decisions was introduced by the last Labor government through the Migration Reform Act 1992 and commenced on 1 September 1994. It was part of a package of changes, building on an existing scheme where the attributes that a non-citizen needs to be granted a visa are set out in detail in the migration legislation. The changes included:
Â· expanded access to merits review;
Â· a requirement that any review rights must be exhausted prior to seeking judicial review;
Â· statutory codes of procedure for visa decision making; and
Â· some restriction of the grounds of judicial review in light of the access to merits review and statutory codes for visa decision making.
The Labor government intended those changes to reduce Federal Court litigation and to provide greater certainty as to what was required from both decision-makers, visa applicants and visa holders.

That scheme has not reduced the volume of cases before the courts: just the opposite. Recourse to the Federal Court and the High Court is trending upwards, with nearly 400 applications in 1994-95; nearly 600 in 1995-96; 740 in 1996-97; nearly 800 in 1997-98; around 1,130 in 1998-99; nearly 1,300 in 1999-2000; and around 1,640 in 2000-01.
Based on current litigation trends it is anticipated that applications made to the courts will reach at least 2,000 in the current financial year.

And the cost of litigation continues to soar. In 1997-98 the cost of all litigation for the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs was nearly $9.5 million, and that does not include the cost of running the courts. In 1998-99 it was $11.5 million; in 1999-2000 it was nearly $12.3 million; and in 2000-01 the cost to the department exceeded $15 million.

This upward trend in court applications and costs is despite full and open access to heavily subsidised independent merits review by the Migration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal. The high level of litigation, particularly by twice refused refugee claimants, cannot remain unchecked. Increased litigation leads to increased costs and delays, and for those in detention, to a longer period of detention.

From experience we know that a substantial proportion of these cases will be withdrawn by the applicants prior to hearing. The percentage of applicants who withdraw fluctuates between one-third to one-half of applicants. Of the cases that go on to substantive court hearings the merits based decision is currently upheld in around 90 per cent of cases.

It is hard not to conclude that there is a substantial number who are using the legal process primarily in order to extend their stay in Australia, especially given that one-third to one-half of all applicants withdraw from legal proceedings before hearing.

In the migration area, litigation can be an end in itselfâit is an area where delaying the final determination is seen as beneficial by those pursuing the court action. Given the importance they attach to staying in Australia, there is a high incentive for refused applicants to delay removal from Australia for as long as possible.

Faced with the problem I have outlined, I asked the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in early 1996 to explore options for best achieving the government's policy objective of restricting access to judicial review. This was done in conjunction with the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and eminent legal counsel.
The advice received from legal counsel was that the only workable option was a privative clause.

As members are probably aware, section 75 of the Commonwealth Constitution gives the High Court original jurisdiction to consider challenges to the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers. As a result, access to the High Court cannot be legislatively restricted without a constitutional amendment.

However, access to the Federal Court, and the scope of judicial review it can exercise, can be changed by legislation. To simply restrict access to the Federal Court in migration legislation matters, would in practice deflect many cases to the High Court under section 75 of the Constitution. This has the potential to erode the proper role and purpose of the High Court.

Counsels' advice was that a privative clause would have the effect of narrowing the scope of judicial review by the High Court and of course the Federal Court. That advice was largely based on the High Court's own interpretation of such clauses in cases following the seminal High Court case of Hickman in 1945. The privative clause in the bill is based on a very similar clause in Hickman's case.

The High Court has not since, despite opportunities to do so, repudiated the Hickman principle as formulated by Justice Dixon in Hickman's case. Indeed, that principle was described as `classical' in a later High Court case.

Members may be aware that the effect of a privative clause such as that used in Hickman's case is to expand the legal validity of the acts done and the decisions made by decision makers. The result is to give decision makers wider lawful operation for their decisions, and this means that the grounds on which those decisions can be challenged in the Federal and High Courts are narrower than currently.
In practice, the decision is lawful provided:
Â· the decision maker is acting in good faith;

Â· the decision is reasonably capable of reference to the power given to the decision makerâthat is, the decision maker had been given the authority to make the decision concerned, for example, had the authority delegated to him or her by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, or had been properly appointed as a tribunal member;

Â· the decision relates to the subject matter of the legislationâit is highly unlikely that this ground would be transgressed when making decisions about visas since the major purpose of the Migration Act is dealing with visa decisions; and
Â· constitutional limits are not exceededâ given the clear constitutional basis for visa decision making in the Migration Act, this is highly unlikely to arise.

The options available to the government were very much shaped by the Constitution. While the government accepts that the precise limits of privative clauses may need examination by the High Court, there is no other practical option open to the government to achieve its policy objective.

It has been suggested that the introduction of a leave requirement would achieve the government's policy objective of restricting judicial review to `exceptional circumstances'. In the government's view, that is not a viable option. While it is possible to impose a leave requirement on the Federal Court, it is not constitutionally possible to do so with the High Court in its original constitutional jurisdiction. That would leave that court exposed to applicants going straight to the High Court in order to avoid any leave requirement imposed on the Federal Court. In any event, the imposition of a leave requirement could increase the complexity of the litigation and cause consequential delay and cost, and may in practice even double the number of hearings before the Federal Court. That would exacerbate those problems which the government is aiming to rectify.

Under the reforms in this bill, unlike today, there will be no advantage in sidestepping the Federal Court and going straight to the High Court in its original jurisdiction. This is because the same grounds of review will apply in either the Federal Court or the High Court. It will be open to the High Court to remit all matters to the Federal Court if it wishes. It cannot do so today under the current judicial review scheme because of the disparity between the High Court's original jurisdiction and that of the Federal Court.

Although the measures in this bill will limit judicial review, many applicants who consider that they have received a decision from the department which is wrong will of course still have access to independent merits review by the Migration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal. It is the government's intention that all bona fide applicants meeting the criteria for the grant of a particular visa be granted that visaâand that is particularly so in the case of those seeking protection visas. The independent merits review tribunals act as a safeguard in that respect.

As an additional safeguard, under the Migration Act the minister has special public interest powers enabling the minister to grant a visa even where the non-citizen does not meet the prescribed criteria for the grant of that visa set out in the migration regulations.

The government has other legislative reforms of judicial review either in the parliament or about to be introduced to the parliament. Those reforms, such as the bar on class or other representative actions in visa related matters, and the codification of the natural justice or procedural fairness `hearing rule', are complementary to this bill.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 14th report for 2001 of the committee relating to housing redevelopment at Enoggera, Brisbane.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe Defence Housing Authority currently manages a total of 1,124 properties in Brisbane. The proposed housing redevelopment at Enoggera helps to meet this increased need for defence accommodation in Brisbane.

speech.para: The Defence Housing Authority commissioned an independent examination of the site which revealed that naturally occurring arsenic concentrations which were detected were above Queensland Environmental Protection Agency environmental investigation levels. The consultant's report said that the levels of arsenic `appear to be naturally occurring' and they recommended that `it would be prudent for future landowners to be advised of the presence of elevated concentrations of arsenic in the natural soil'. The committee questioned the DHA quite extensively on this issue. As a result, the committee made three recommendations which, if implemented, will ensure that the project proceeds only if favourable environmental assessments are received.

The committee concluded that there is a need for the proposed work and that it should proceedâas I said, subject to those environmental clearancesâat a projected cost of $15.5 million, subject to a positive finding by the Queensland Environmental Protection Agency regarding soil contamination issues.

Before I conclude, I would like to say a few words to highlight the great contribution to the work of the Public Works Committee by the honourable member for Throsby, Mr Colin Hollis. He is retiring at the next election. Colin has served on the Public Works Committee continuously since February 1985 and was chair from October 1987 to January 1996. He has made a very good contribution to this committee. He has never been afraid to subject witnesses to searching examination and always expected the witnesses to be well briefed and insisted that they be able to substantiate their evidence. He was able to bring to his questioning a dry sense of humour, which on many occasions lightened an otherwise tense situation. Amongst the members and staff of the PWC, Colin was famous for his punctuality. He has made a terrific contribution to the PWC, and we would like to acknowledge that on this occasion because we may not have another opportunity to do so. I would also like to thank the secretariat for their tremendous work in getting the report done so quickly. I commend the report to the House.
