talk.start.para: âOn 30 August, 2001, the East Timorese people elected the members of their first Constituent Assembly, which has the task of preparing a constitution for an independent and democratic East Timor. This election was the fundamental and defining act of transferring power to the people of East Timor. It marked the beginning of the final step in the transition to independence, and in implementing the decision of the people of East Timor in the popular consultation of 30 August 1999. For the first time, East Timor now has an elected representative body capable of making legitimate decisions in the name of the people in East Timor.

speech.para: The Constituent Assembly has a single chamber consisting of 88 elected representatives, one from each of the 13 districts who were elected in a direct district ballot and 75 national representatives who were elected proportionally on the basis of lists of party and independent candidates. On 15 September 2001, the Constituent Assembly was sworn in and, after the swearing in, the Constituent Assembly will have 90 days to draft and adopt a constitution for a democratic and independent East Timor. In order to be adopted the constitution must have the support of at least 60 of the 88 members. The people of East Timor have expressed their hopes and concerns to constitutional commissions which held hearings across the country. They are now counting on the 88 members of this assembly to translate those aspirations into a document which all East Timorese will recognise as their own.

I was privileged to be at the swearing in of these members of the Constituent Assembly. I was present with the new Chief Minister for the Northern Territory, the Hon. Clare Martin, and the Northern Territory Minister for Industry, Business, Resource Development, Asian Relations and Trade, Territory Insurance, Australasian Railway and Racing and Gaming, the Hon. Paul Henderson. We were honoured guests on the floor of the chamber at that swearing in and we were also present at the opening of the refurbished Constituent Assembly building, which was refurbished by the Australian community through aid funds to the tune of some $3 million. The handover was undertaken by the head of the Australian mission in Dili, Mr James Batley.

What astounded me about this process, apart from the privilege and honour that was accorded to us as VIP guests on the floor of this new assembly, was that there was no Australian government representative present. It seemed to me that this was such an important occasion. We had sent Australian troops across to East Timor in 1999, on behalf of the Australian community, to help bring about this popular consultation of 30 August 1999 and, after that, to secure peace. The whole objective of that exercise was this occasion: to have a democratically elected people's assembly, a constituent assembly elected by the people of East Timor. The Australian community, through its contribution in aid funds and through our defence forces, made an enormous contribution to that process. As an Australian and as someone who has been associated with the East Timorese, certainly since 1975, I am very proud of that.

As I said in my first speech in this parliament, because of the role that the Australian government historically has had to assist the people of East Timor it was a particularly proud occasion for me; yet, there was no-one present from the Australian government. There was no-one to represent the Australian community, the Australian people, on that occasion. I think that speaks volumes as to how seriously the Australian government has taken its obligations.

I might say that, last week, we saw the swearing in of the second transitional government of East Timor and I want to recognise in particular those people who have been put into ministries, particularly Dr Mari Bim Amude Alkatiri, from Fretilin, who is the first Chief Minister and Minister of Economy and Development for East Timor. It is an enormous accolade for these people. It is worth while pointing out that Fretilin, which of course formed a government in 1975, received almost 60 per cent of the popular vote. It seems to me that we have a very resilient group of people and Mari Alkatiri, as the Chief Minister, has an enormous responsibility on behalf of his own party and the people of East Timor. I know he will do the job well. But I say again that I was shocked and amazed that we did not have a representative from the Australian government present at that swearing in. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to recount to honourable members a very interesting incident that occurred in my electorate on 24 August. My Labor opponent, Cheryl Dorron, invited me to sign the Leader of the Opposition's phoney Telstra pledge in front of my office. Without committing myself to signing the objectionable thing, I readily agreed to meet her there at 1.30 p.m. on that day. She duly arrived with a cheer squad of 20 or 30 of the usual suspectsâLabor supporters and local agitators. While she feigned sincerity and concern, the incident had `stunt' written all over it. I politely listened to her and then told her I would not be signing the pledge, because it was phoney and because its author, the Leader of the Opposition, was a serial pledge breaker. To illustrate the point, I had my own corflute signs in the laneway beside my office. On one of the signs I had a lovely logo of the Commonwealth Bank. I said, `How about signing this pledge that says, âI'm sorry for its saleâ?' Then I brought out another one with `Qantas' on it and I said, `How about saying this is the Qantas that you weren't going to sell? How about signing, âI'm sorryâ?' Because you guys really likeâ
âDo you have a GST one with `never, ever'?
âMember for Batman! The member for Hinkler has the call.
âThrough you, Mr Speaker, when I said `you guys' I meant that the Labor Party are very good at asking people to say they are sorry, but they were not really quick to say they were sorry about that.

speech.para: Then, in the words of the TV ad, I said, `And there's more!' So out came the third corflute, and on that I had listed $5.2 billion worth of other things that the Labor Party had sold in office, including the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I pointed out that none of these asset sales went to reducing debt and none of them went to building new Australian infrastructure; they all went to the bottom line of dodgy budgets.

At this point, her supporters became very agitated. In a way, I was sorry for them, because I sensed their genuine discomfort. Here were true blue Labor people seeing the pathetic results of the Keating years. They were silent, and then they started to become abusive. I pointed out to her that I had no need to sign the 49.9 per cent pledge, because I take some pride in being the one who convinced the government to hold it at 49.9 per cent. Those who were in the party room will remember the day when I brought that matter up. On top of that, I pledged myself to the 49.9 per cent long before the Leader of the Opposition picked it up as a populist cause.

talk.start.para: âBut you never voted for it!
âI take pride in the fact that I took a stance on this, with my National Party colleagues, to not only stop thatâ
âSign the pledge, then.

âThe member for Batman and the member for Rankin! The member for Hinkler has the call. I have been very tolerant. He is entitled to be heard in silence. He is not being assisted by the member for Corangamite or by the member for Rankin. It would be quite out of character for me to have to take action during the adjournment debate.

âThe Besley inquiry, we know, benchmarked a lot of things that are going to have to happen in the regional development of Telstra's performance. In addition, I take some pride in being the one who moved what is now known euphemistically in telecommunications circles as the `Bundaberg resolution'. It was moved in March 1998 in my electorate, at a National Party conference, and we said we wanted seven things. Those seven things benchmarked telecommunications, blackspot programsâin fact, $762 million worth, most of which have been delivered or are in the process of being delivered.

speech.para: If you run around the countryside with dodgy pledges on corflute signs, inviting people to sign them, you are devoid of policy and you are flip-flopping from one thing to another. And that is what happened outside my office on 24 August at 1.30 p.m.âALP cheer squad and all.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Committee Report

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to speak to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. It is titled We can do it! and it was the inquiry into the needs of urban-dwelling Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. The Deputy Chair of the committee, the member for Franklin, tabled the report on Monday on behalf of the Chair, the member for Indi, who is currently representing the government at the United Nations.
âHe is representing the parliament.

âHe is representing the parliament; I am corrected. In speaking to the report, I would first like to thank the secretariat of the committee. They included Catherine Cornish, James Catchpole, Jenny Cochran and Fran Wilson. As all members of committees in this place understand, the secretariat performs a very important role. They do a lot of good work. This committee always remained in good humour, and it has been a great pleasure, over the past three years, to work with them. I would also like to thank the Chair, the member for Indi, who I understand is retiring at the coming election. As a first-term member of parliament, and this being my first House of Representatives standing committee, both the member for Indi and the member for Franklin provided good, strong leadership and guidance. This is the second report that the committee has produced in the life of this parliament, and both of those reports have been unanimous reports.
âIn a spirit of bipartisanship.

âYes. At the beginning of the inquiry, we agreed to a set of core principles which assisted us in assessing the evidence and formulating our recommendations. Those core principles included equal access to government services for all Australians, community focus, partnerships, rights and responsibilities, and a focus on mainstream services.

speech.para: The report is made up of nine chapters: (1) Introduction, (2) Setting the Context, (3) More Effective Service Delivery, (4) Local Decision Making, (5) The Needs of Youthâ which we found needed to be addressed urgently, (6) Maintenance of Culture, (7) Economic Independence, (8) Housing, and (9) The Future. The committee made 40 recommendations to the government to address the needs of urban-dwelling Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. There were eight recommendations on economic independence, eight recommendations on more effective service delivery and 12 recommendations on the needs of youthâa very important area, as I said, which needs to be addressed.

We were aware that other parliamentary inquiries had been held, and we had been waiting for the Commonwealth Grants Commission report, which was released only on Friday. I hasten to say that we were actually considering deferring the tabling of our report to wait for it. It had been with the minister since March this year, and it was finally released on Friday. I must say that the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission do align with the recommendations that we have made in our report.

Finally, I would like to take the opportunity to wish the Newcastle Knights all the best for Sunday evening's grand final. They have been ably coached by Michael Hagan, who in his first year as a first grade coach has led the side to the grand final. I wish Andrew Johns and all the boys well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to confirm my opposition to the recent announcement by the Rocla Corporation that they will be seeking the right to extend their mining rights to below street level. At present, Rocla hold permission to mine sand from the dunes on the Kurnell Peninsula in my electorateâthe only proviso being that they must remain above street level. It is an understatement to say that I was dismayed last Friday when I heard that Rocla had announced that they were applying to the New South Wales Department of Urban Affairs and Planning to have their rights extended. It is not as if sandmining on Kurnell Peninsula has not gone too far alreadyâclearly it has. One only has to drive out to where the huge dunes, made famous by the early Mad Max movies, used to be to see how this activity has decimated the peninsula. Other people comment to me that, when they fly over Kurnell, it looks like it is slowly being cut off from the rest of the mainland by mining.

speech.para: Many local residents, including me and past school students from around Sydney, have memories of school excursions to study the unique environment of the Kurnell sandhills. For the most part, this environment no longer exists. For too many years the Kurnell Peninsula has been pillaged for its resources, with scant regard for its wellbeing. It is time this stopped. I find it hard to believe that an area of such historical significance to Australia now finds itself under threat from two sources: Australand, which are trying to press ahead with their plan to build 500 dwellings under a major flight path, and now Rocla's move. There is a clear desire from our community and from wider afield to see this site being improved, not further damaged. We should be looking to promote the obvious tourist credentials of the area, not digging it up or developing on it. I believe that Captain Cook's landing site could have a monument or area of national significance where Australians can go to visit and learn more about Cook's landing and its significance to modern Australia.

On Monday, Rocla issued a further statement that they would be commencing a community consultation program, including random telephone sampling and one on one consultations with adjoining property owners. While I welcome this move by the company, I feel it is a waste of time. I can inform Rocla that the sentiment of Kurnell, North Cronulla, Cronulla and Woolooware residents will be strongly against any extension of mining rights. The community has already expressed strong opposition to further developments on the peninsula, both through surveys sent out from my office and at a rally held several weeks ago near the last remaining sand dune. There is a clear desire to see the site ecologically restored and returned to public use.

The state government and the Department of Urban Affairs and Planning must reject Rocla's application and send a clear message that they support keeping Kurnell as an area of recreation for all Australians. It is an outstanding area within Australia. It adjoins the Ramsar site at Kurnell, where there are migratory birds from both Siberia and Japan. It is alongside the site of the landing of Captain Cook and all the monuments that exist at that place. This area has long been decimated by sandminers and developers alike. It is a unique environment. It has many fine sand dunes, many of which have disappeared, and is home to some unique flora and fauna. We should be looking at the whole biodiversity of the area and what can be done to preserve it. It adjoins Bate Bay, with its wonderful beaches and unique seascape, and it is a great pity that sandmining has been allowed to go on for so long.

There was a plan in the fifties to terminate sandmining in the area but, because of the neglect of the local council, it was allowed to continue. Now we have a situation where Australand are planning to put 500 housing sites in the area. The responsibility for that has been taken away from the council by the state government, and they have yet to make a decision on the matter. This proposal is a great threat to the ecological significance of the area. I, for one, totally oppose the proposal to expand and extend sandmining on the peninsula and join the residents of Woolooware, Cronulla, North Cronulla and Kurnell in saying, `Enough is enough. This should not be allowed to happen.' I certainly call on the state government to not provide the approvals that are necessary for this to go ahead.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight, one month before my 21st anniversary as a member of this parliament. Since 1980, I have represented the needs and interests of the people of the north-western suburbs of Melbourne. I have a very strong affection and affinity with the people of this fast developing and industrially important area. I grew up in this area, have lived there for most of my life and have achieved a great deal for the people of this region.

speech.para: I have announced to the people of my electorate that I shall be standing as an Independent in the upcoming election. My constituents are keenly aware of my work in this House, including the presentation of an Australian bill of rights and my position as the only member of parliament opposing draconian laws pushed through this House over the past few weeks with bipartisan support. They are also aware of the battles I have fought with the state Labor government in order to meet the infrastructure needs and employment opportunities of the people of this region. It is for these reasons that the people of Calwell have urged me to stand again as their representative. I promise to continue to fight fearlessly for better services, better resources and better opportunities for education, training and employment for all constituents and their families.

In my earlier work as Parliamentary Secretary to Prime Minister Keating and to several cabinet ministers, I worked tirelessly to implement positive agendas for my constituents and the people of Australia. In my electorate of Calwell, I have worked hard to achieve a balance between the various ethnic communities and to ensure that they work together in the cause of multiculturalism. Unfortunately, all this good work is now under severe threat. This is because there is a small group in the Labor Party who, far from pursuing Labor ideals, are totally obsessed with thuggery and dirty tactics. The leader of this group is the fanatical Senator Kim Carr. He is well known for being at the centre of many of the low points within the party, including the stacking of branches and the manipulation of preselections. One such manipulative process resulted in the imposition of an entirely unsuitable person from outside my electorate as the ALP candidate for Calwell.

This person, Maria Vamvakinou, is well known for her support of every single strategy and policy of Kim Carr. Over the last decade, she has acted in concert with Kim Carr to pursue agendas which have created great anxiety in some of the ethnic communities in Calwell. For example, in order to gain support for the stacking of branches from people of Kurdish background, Kim Carr adopted the cynical and outrageous agenda of actively supporting one of the world's worst terroristsâKurdish rebel fanatic Abdullah Ocalan. Many in this place would know that Ocalan is responsible for the deaths of thousands of innocent peopleâ a charge for which he has been arrested and sentenced. Kim Carr not only expressed this support in private but also presented petitions to the Senate and even pressured a number of members and senators to sign a letter in support of Ocalan. I refused to sign this outrageous petition. Carr's actions created enormous angst in the Turkish community in my electorate and heightened tensions between Turkish and other communities.

This was not an isolated situation. During the time of the break-up of the former Yugoslavia, Kim Carr was one of the few prominent people to actively support then President Milosevic in his terror campaign against the Croatian and Bosnian peopleâwhereas I actively worked for a just solution based on the recognition of the sovereign republics of the former Yugoslavia, a matter for which he attacked me. Carr's actions also created tensions in my electorate between Croatian, Bosnian and other communities of the former Yugoslavia. In this, he was again actively supported by Maria Vamvakinou.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, on a point of order: I would have thought that the standing orders would prevent a member of this House reflecting on a member of another house. Dr Theophanous is seeking to cast aspersions without foundation at this time.

âI have been listening closely to the member for Calwell's speech, and he has not as yet said anything that I would have thought was outside the standing orders. If he does so, I will interrupt him.

âI have plenty of evidence for what I am saying here. In fact, it is on the Hansard record. During these times of international uncertainty, and with a majority of nations supporting an international attack on terrorism, it must be kept in mind that Senator Carr has persistently supported these two individuals: Milosevic and Ocalan. It has become clear from these and many other actions that Kim Carr has priorities which contradict those of the people of my electorate and of the multicultural needs of this nation. Maria Vamvakinou is the total puppet of Senator Carr.
âDid you sign her into the Labor Party?

âI did not. She is currently employed in his office, and in a recent dubiously funded letter to the people of Calwell, Senator Carr referred to her as `my personal representative'. We believe that she represents him in every way, including in the well-known dirty tactics that I spoke about on another occasion.

speech.para: The Labor Party of my electorate is highly resentful of the imposition of this person as their candidate. She is well known for her constant attacks on individuals inside the Labor Party who do not agree with Kim Carr's views. Recently, she launched into an outrageous personal attack on me on a Greek radio program. Kim Carr has also been obsessed with spreading lies about me for a number of years. He used the basest tactics in Calwell and throughout the state of Victoria against me and my supporters when I was in the Labor Party. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

to move:

motion.para: That this House:

interjection.para: (1) recognises that:
(a) Australia has an international reputation as a successful multicultural society;
(b) freedom and respect for diversity, particularly religious diversity, has underpinned that success;

(c) Australia has had a peaceful transition from a time where one religious group dominated religious culture to the current situation where religious legitimacy is shared by all religious groups; and
(d) such success has been based on religious settlement involving highly diverse religious groups;

(2) further recognises that the framework provided by Australia's civic values of tolerance, equality, our âfair goâ culture, and freedom of speech and religion, together with the structures of constitutional parliamentary democracy and the rule of law have worked together to enable this transition;
(3) notes that:
(a) Muslims are the largest non Christian religious group in Australia, with migrants from Turkey, Lebanon, and other Middle East and Asian cultures;
(b) at least 35% of Australian Muslims were born in Australia; and
(c) Muslim migrants have been part of Australian society for over a century, with the first mosques built in Adelaide, Coolgardie, Maree, Broken Hill and Perth by the end of the nineteenth century;

(4) Appreciates that Islam is a peaceful religion and that in over 100 years of immigration, Australia has never experienced acts of terrorism arising from our migrant Muslim communities, but that Australia has benefited enormously from the successful immigration of such communities;
(5) notes also the commitment expressed by Muslims and Australian Arabs in the weekend press, to condemning terrorism;
(6) is concerned at the current unhealthy level of physical and verbal attacks on these communities, especially their mosques, schools, women and children; and
(7) calls on the Australian community, at all levels, to give Australia's migrant Muslim community the respect we give to all other religious groups.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âI want to raise an important matter to do with the granting of an MRI machine licence to a company purporting to be servicing the Gippsland region. The government made an announcement this week that an MRI machine licence would be granted to Dandenong to service, supposedly, all of the Gippsland region. We are incredibly disappointed by this decision because many of us had put our support behind a proposal which would have seen a licence for an MRI machine granted to a company that would place that machine at Latrobe Regional Hospital in Traralgon, in the centre of Gippsland.

speech.para: As it has turned out, the government has seen fit to make this announcement to provide for a third MRI machine to go into the Dandenong Hospital, supposedly to service the people of the Gippsland region. On behalf of the people of the Gippsland region, can I just state very plainly that we would like to see a service which is supposed to be servicing us actually in our region and not in a suburb of Melbourne. There is a lot of anger and disappointment in my area about this. All of the local members of parliament in our district, the local councils, local medical specialists and general practitioners had put their support behind the proposal which would have seen the MRI machine licence granted to this company and placed at Latrobe Regional Hospital. In a letter to me, Dr K.V. Stribley, a consultant radiologist, said:

quote.para: The principle reason given to us in our failure to be granted the license is lack of population density. It would therefore appear likely to us that if these criteria continue to be enforced most regional areas in Australia and particularly Gippsland will never obtain a licensed machine.

speech.para: He is dead right, Mr Deputy Speaker. He goes on:

quote.para: We believe this decision will have long term negative ramifications upon the delivery of health service to this region in that it will make it almost impossible to attract suitably qualified young radiologists to the region and make it increasingly difficult to attract and retain suitably qualified technical staff to the region all of whom expect exposure to a MR machine.

speech.para: We want to see these services in our district. We want to see these services made available to the people who live and reside in country towns. We do not want to see our people being made to travel all the way to Dandenong just to have access to the same technology and medical advances which people in large urban areas and in the capital cities have access to. I think this is a shameful decision by the federal government. I think they should act quickly to reverse the decision and, instead of granting a third MRI machine licence to the Dandenong district, they should grant that licence to Traralgon, which is in the middle of Gippsland and will provide an enormous boost in terms of medical advances and availability of medical technology to people living right across Gippsland.

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
Mr ENTSCH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI would like to share with this place a remarkable contribution which has been made by a group of dedicated volunteers made up of people from the Far North Queensland veteran community. Last week I had the immense pleasure of opening the Far North Queensland Veterans and Ex-Service Support Centre on behalf of Minister Scott. The centre was established through the very hard work of a small group of volunteers who clearly had very strong community spirit and they received some very strong support from the Commonwealth government.

speech.para: The centre will play a very vital role in supporting veterans, war widows and widowers through claims applications and the appeals process. The whole concept was to create a centre that was actually run by veteransâa lot of these people are TPI pensionersâand to take it away from the bureaucracy so that veterans can deal with veterans, and so that those areas of need that fall through the cracks can be identified.

The idea to set this centre up originally came from a small group of individuals. I would like to acknowledge Peter Weeden, Kevin Paterson, Mick Foster, John Moodie, John Chandler, John Vickery and Vi Young for their efforts. A number of those people came to my office and met with Minister Scott, and they put forward this concept of what they would like to achieve. We were able to arrange a $25,000 funding grant for them, which was initially to cover the cost of accommodation. Westcourt Plaza shopping centre in Cairns then came on board and offered them an absolutely phenomenal deal on office space located near a taxi rank. It was absolutely perfect; it was ideal. As a consequence, we found that quite a significant amount of that $25,000 was still available. So we sought a variation of that grant to be able to supply office equipment such as desks. Again, the minister was able to accommodate those needs.

We now have this magnificent veterans and ex-service support centre operating out of Westcourt Plaza shopping centre, which is manned by a group of very enthusiastic and very committed veteran volunteers and their supporters. The success has been outstanding. You see a continual stream of people from the veteran community going into that centre, seeking that support. I congratulate each and every one of the people who have been involved in that. Peter Weeden, Mick Foster and John Moodie will be acknowledged further for their commitment this weekend, with special awards that will be given at the International Year of the Volunteer presentation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs Four Corners showed on Monday night, hundreds of thousands of mum and dad investors have been defrauded by the Brinton Group, which sells shares from boiler rooms based in Bangkok to thousands of Australian investors. Australian investors' money has been taken and no share certificates have been received. These companies, operating out of boiler rooms ostensibly based in Tokyo but in fact operating out of Bangkok, have been selling Australians shares in non-existent companies or selling shares in existing companies but giving the investors no share certificates. The Brinton Group (International) said that Gary Player Golf Inc. shares were listed on the Nasdaq. In fact, this was not the case. This companyâknown as Gary Player Direct.com or Gary Player Inc.âwas in fact listed on the much lesser known OTC Bulletin Board or something even less well known called the Pink Sheets.

speech.para: The Brinton Group staffed its offices in Bangkok boiler rooms with unlicensed brokers, who were found by the Thai authorities to be involved in illegal brokerage and were there without work permits. A few weeks ago the Thai Securities Commission, the Australian Federal Police and the FBI helped to break up Brinton's operations principally organised to defraud Australian investors. Bangkok has other boiler rooms involved in similar activities. Four Corners noted ASIC have listed International Asset Management, the Dreyfus Group and the Kingston Group as things about which Australian investors should beware. CEO Scott Fisher of the Brinton Group, an Australian, controls numerous Hong Kong bank accounts where Australian investors' funds have been funnelled. Australian investors think they are buying shares directly in these US companies and are, in fact, buying into this fraudulent operation.

There is a loophole in the US law that prevents stocks that have been bought being sold for 12 months. It appears that the Brinton Group are selling shares on the OTC Bulletin Board and Pink Sheets simply quoting from traders and selling the stock they do not hold. Traders have to reimburse people for only a couple of hundred stocks listed on these minor exchanges. If people have bought thousands of sharesâas many in this country have in Gary Player Inc., a private companyâwhich are not listed, they are not able to get their share certificates or, indeed, sell their shares and redeem their money.

Gary Player Inc. claims to have sold hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of golf equipment directly. In fact, its first six months worth of sales, as Four Corners showed, amounted to only $100,000, with losses of $950,000. I am sure the US regulatory authorities will look into this. Australians have been defrauded by a deliberate plan that I think Gary Player, Ed Tracey and Scott Fisher have been involved in. I will be writing to the US commerce department on behalf of Australian investors and asking them to look into this disgraceful scam of Australians, America's close ally and friend.

talk.start.para: âRepresenting Townsville and Thuringowa in the national parliament, I am privileged to also represent Australia's largest and most important defence base. I want to say that I remain continually impressed with the professionalism of the members of the ADF, our men and women who are there when Australia needs them. I can assure you, from six years of working with the members of the ADF in my electorate, both at Lavarack Barracks and at RAAF Townsville, that those people are certainly the most professional, the most well-prepared people that we have seen for quite some time.

speech.para: I remind the parliament that when we came to government in 1996 we saw funding for the defence forces as a priority. It had been run down and down and down. The government at that time took the decision to isolate defence from any spending cuts that were necessary to cover that terrible Bankcard deficit that the Labor Party had left us. We commenced a major program to re-equip the Defence Force to bring it back to the standard that is needed for Australia. We have certainly improved, for example, Defence's teeth-to-tail ratio. We found that it was something like 42 per cent. It has now come up to 62 per cent with the men and women in the ADF serving in the real positions that they should be serving in in the interests of our country. We have also completed a comprehensive review of defence through the white paper process.

There have been some very significant changes in my city. In the last four years something like half a billion dollars has been spent improving the accommodation and working facilities for the men and women at RAAF Townsville and Lavarack Barracks. These improvements were long overdue. They will allow the members of our Defence Force to perform their duties in the most efficient manner possible. I want that to continue; there are further upgrades to be done. Probably another $100 million needs to be spent in the region before I am satisfied that the facilities provided at RAAF Townsville and Lavarack Barracks are up to speed. With Townsville being the jump-off point, or the mounting point, for virtually all of the major operations overseas in the last 10 years, it is vitally important that we have the best facilities that we can have. The government and I are determined to make sure that those facilities are provided for the men and women of the ADF in the Townsville and Thuringowa region.

subdebateinfo.title: United States of America: Terrorist Attacks

talk.start.para: âThe day of 11 September 2001 will live in infamy. The terrorism in the United States, which we saw so graphically illustrated on our TV screens, has shocked the world and is something that will remain in our memory forever. Over 6,000 fatalities, including many Australians, have shown us that terrorism is something that is hard to fight against with conventional means. This was an attack on democratic values and an attack on humanity. I believe that the perpetrators of this cowardly act must be brought to justice. The international community must ensure that the international response discriminates and punishes those responsible, but we must also ensure that no more innocent lives are lost to add to the count of murders conducted by the terrorists.

speech.para: Terrorism is wrong whether it is conducted by individuals or by states. Like terrorism, in my view fundamentalism of any variety is also evil and wrong. Osama bin Laden and his fundamentalist supporters in the Taliban have also terrorised the people of Afghanistan. William Maley from the Australian Defence Force Academy, who is Australia's leading authority on Afghanistan, has reported that in 1998 some 2,000 Hazaras, a very conservative figure, were massacred over three days in northern Afghanistan. Further massacres have occurred over the last two years. William Maley, in speaking about the plight of refugees, has said that the characterisation of Afghans coming by boat as queue jumpers is comprehensively spurious. What the offshore program offers, he has argued, is not a place in a queue but a ticket in a lottery.

If we are to defeat terrorism truly, we must support its antithesisâtolerance and humanity; humanity and compassion in our nation's domestic policy as well as in our attitude to international affairs. Australians of Arab descent have been unjustly targeted as a result of recent events. The attacks on a mosque in Brisbaneâand I have received letters from individual constituents who have been spat on and vilified in the streets due to their religionâhave no place whatsoever in Australian society and simply give victory to the aims of those people who seek to divide us, such as those terrorists and their actions on the international stage.

talk.start.para: âIt is my view that the objective of those who acted in Washington and New York was to provoke a war between the West and Islam. The act itself was intended to foment Western hostility to Islam and, by the magnitude of the US response, to consolidate Islamic hostility to the West. This is Osama bin Laden's agenda. Whoever was responsible for the bombing of the mosque in Brisbane is acting as a pawn of bin Laden and his ilk. It is his objective to promote acts of hostility against Muslims in the communities in which they live around the world. We will not play his game. This is not a war between the West and Islam; this is a war between citizens of freedom and good faithâwhatever their religionâand the evil of terrorism. I appeal to the Muslims of Brisbane not to attribute the actions of a few bigots to the vast mass of the Australian people. I appeal to the mass of the Australian people not to attribute the actions of a few terrorists to all Muslims. I want to read onto the record a statement funded and published in Australian newspapers by a group of Australian Muslims of Palestinian descent in the last week. It says:

para.inline: A Message from Australians of Arab Descent

quote.para: We condemn the horrific terrorist events that occurred in the United States of America last week, on 11 September 2001.

There is no reason or justification for the murder of the innocent anywhere or at anytime. We, like the entire world, are greatly saddened and distressed at how families have been destroyed, lives have been shattered and fundamental values, such as freedom and tolerance for all, have been attacked.
We stand prepared to take appropriate action to assist our country to eliminate all terrorism, to bring all terrorists to justice, and justice to the victims of terrorism.

In particular, we wish to see justice implemented in all its forms, and that those people responsible for the September 11 actions in the USA are held fully accountable for their acts of cowardice. All Australians, regardless of race, colour or religion should defend any and all nations and peoples against any acts of violence.

We Australians of Arab descent stand shoulder to shoulder with our fellow Australians to protect the innocent, to defend the helpless and to preserve liberty, democracy, tolerance and harmony within our great Nation of Australia.

speech.para: At this time we need to blow on the spark of good faith, of reconciliation and of tolerance wherever it may be found and at the same time to deny oxygen to the furnace of bigotry wherever it may be found. I want to acknowledge the outstanding contribution, in my electorate of Parramatta, of Muslim Australian citizens who are making an extraordinary contribution in the professions, in medical science, in research and in education. This is a test for our nation. Let us rise to the occasion.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âIn accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded. The committee will now consider government business but, before I call the Clerk, I would like to make an observation for the benefit of all members of the House and direct their attention to standing order 56. The lack of attention to standing order 56 is something that concerns all members of the Speaker's panel, but there is a general diffidence about mentioning it because it could be conceived as the individual member sitting in the chair wanting some sort of personal acknowledgment for himself or herself. That is far from the case. The institution of parliament, forged in the battles for Magna Carta and since, deserves the respect of all members. I remind members that standing order 56 requires them to acknowledge the chair when passing to or from their seatsâthat means when entering or leaving the chamber or passing from side to side. Because this is widely believed to be the last week we will be sitting, and I will not be standing and will not be here again, I thought I would be bold enough to make the comment for the benefit of all members because those others who might be back may prefer not to comment. To sum up, it is important that members treat both chambers with respect and with dignity and should not wander in and out like Brown's cows, as frequently happens.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 June, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe Cybercrime Bill 2001 introduces a number of new computer based offences and extends powers relating to the search for and seizure of electronic evidence for law enforcement. The bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, and that committee tabled its report on Tuesday, 21 August. The report contained a dissenting comment from Labor senators, who criticised the government for its failure to consult widely with the community before introducing the bill and recommended further scrutiny before passing the bill through parliament. Since then, sensitivity to criminal activity and national security has substantially heightened. As this bill applies to the criminal misuse of computersâan activity which can cause considerable damage and which has plausibly been linked to possible terrorist activitiesâthe imperative for supporting the bill has also increased substantially.

speech.para: In these circumstances, the opposition entered into a dialogue with the government to ensure that the bill, in a form acceptable to both government and opposition, could be passed as soon as possible. Although the bill will not be amended in the House today, agreement has been reached between the opposition and the government on a number of amendments, which will be moved by the government and adopted in the Senate. We believe that, with these government and opposition amendments, this bill will be passed by the parliament in an acceptable form. However, Labor's broader concerns about legislating in this area remain and we intend to vigilantly monitor the use of the new offences and powers. Might I say, just by way of a general comment, that I would urge upon future governments, whether they be of my persuasion or otherwise, that measures of this nature do require very substantial consultation with affected interest groups before they come before this House.

Of course, the issue of cybercrime is one which has assumed real importance in recent times. That arises because of our increasing reliance on technology, but with that comes a challenge to protect the computer networks, the information they transmit and the rights and interests of the people who use them. As a result of Australia's increasing adoption of information technology, cybercrimeâwhich can be roughly defined as any unauthorised activity which involves or uses computers, digital technology, the Internet, communications systems or networksâposes a threat to Australia's security, business and citizens.

Before I talk about the specifics of this legislation, I want to talk briefly on the Howard government's underwhelming approach to protecting Australia's critical cyberinfrastructure. Almost all of Australia's critical cyberinfrastructure is reliant on information and communications technology and is therefore vulnerable to cyberattack. Water, electricity, gas and telephone systems all rely on computer networks; so do Australia's banks and financial institutions, emergency services, air traffic control, hospitals, police and defence forces. This critical infrastructure is poorly protected. The Howard government's program for protection of our national information infrastructure is flawed. It commenced only after a substantial period of prodding by the opposition and, notwithstanding the obvious significance of improving our capacity in this area, what was introduced was a paltry two-year program which would not be capable of achieving real outcomes. The funding is a one-off allocation spread across the Australian Federal Police, ASIO, the Defence Signals Directorate and the Attorney-General's Department. It is hardly enough to conduct a thorough review of the elements of national information infrastructure which are in public ownership, let alone to establish an ongoing public-private partnership. That is simply not good enough, given the circumstances that exist currently.

There are a number of working groups and action committees across the public sector organisations, but to date we have seen little action. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee recently conducted two relevant inquiries, the first into the resources and capabilities of the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority, and the second into the provisions of this bill. One of the things which was clear from the evidence which the committee received in both inquiries is that, although our law enforcement agencies are actively trying to remedy the situation, currently they have neither the resources nor the skills needed to combat criminal use of information technology. To some extent, I can see this must be inevitable. The information technology world changes so rapidly and is so resource intensive that it is difficult for any regulatory or policing organisation to keep up to date. Nevertheless, a significant commitment from government is needed to ensure that our law enforcement agencies have adequate personnel numbers, IT capability and access to ongoing IT training. That commitment is seriously lacking under the Howard government. For example, in May 1999 the Research Group into the Law Enforcement Implications of Electronic Commerce, now known as the Action Group into Law Enforcement Implications of Electronic Commerce, delivered a report which concluded:

quote.para: Many of the countermeasures to crime which exploit the characteristics of the Internet call for law enforcement and revenue agencies to use sophisticated tracing and other tools. They also call for these tools to be used by well trained specialists who retain their skills and maintain contact with industry. This would be a significant ongoing expense for government. To ensure such an investment is used effectively and as widely as is needed Australian governments should address the provision of a central computer and Internet forensic capability, available to all Commonwealth, State and Territory jurisdictions to support the investigation of computer and Internet-related crime.

speech.para: Well over two years later the Howard government has not responded to that recommendation. Despite this lack of interest from government, the law enforcement agencies themselves have kept the concept alive. The Australasian Centre for Policing Research and AUSTRAC have prepared an issues paper with options to be considered by the heads of Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. Additionally, the Police Commissioners Conference Electronic Crime Project is examining the issue of a national forensic computing capacity in conjunction with an assessment of options for a broader national centre for cybercrime. But, for the present, the Australian Federal Police has only 10 agents possessing what could be described as high level computer skills.

The Australian Federal Police lost its Melbourne computer office twice within as many years to private companies which poached its staff by offering AFP agents considerably more money. Despite this, there has been no acknowledgment by government of the need to assist the AFP to retain and recruit computer specialists. The cuts in AFP core funding in the early years of the Howard government and the resulting impact on staff morale within the organisation are problems that are only now beginning to be overcome. I note that in an attempt to improve the agency's IT capabilities, the AFP has recently instituted training programs for its agents. I sincerely hope that this is a successful initiative, because it is becoming more and more apparent that we must get specialised capacity back into law enforcement. I make the obvious point to all members that 10 agents having high level computer skills to service the whole of Australia within the Australian Federal Police plainly represents an inadequateâand now lamentably inadequateâcapability should the worst happen that we fear in relation to recent events.

The National Crime Authority, Australia's only national law enforcement agency, is also seeking to address the cybercrime issue and, it must be said, attempting to address the issue without a great deal of government focus or support. The National Crime Authority agency has claimed that it needs another $6 million over three years to address its IT capability issues. Although it put this argument to the government in the last budget round, it did not receive any money for this purpose. As a result, the NCA has had to set aside $1.5 million from its existing budget to upgrade its IT systems in the financial year.

In the absence of increased funding, the National Crime Authority has instituted programs focused on training investigators accessing the training packing being put together by the Australian Federal Police. Somewhat worryingly, the National Crime Authority has also started to talk about `importing cybercrime investigation experience into the authority and finding a source of higher level assistance.' Apparently the National Crime Authority is hopeful of finding another body with higher level expertise in this area to which it could subscribe for provision of assistance to the NCA. I have no idea what, or where, this agency might possibly be.

As I mentioned, the AFP no longer has a specialised computer crime unit as such and currently has only 10 agents with high level computer skills. So the agency in question cannot be the AFP. Yet there is no other Commonwealth law enforcement agency to look to. Does this mean that the NCA is considering a private organisation? If so, a question that must be answered is to what extent the NCA is envisaging developing partnerships and to what extent it is envisaging contracting out or privatising part of its core law enforcement functions. I might also indicate that there seems now to be a wide recognition that the contracting out of significant elements of the responsibilities within the national security framework in overseas agencies has weakened its capacity in terms of effectiveness and internal security. These again must be concerns that are heightened in the present circumstances.

I turn to the specific provisions of the bill and the law enforcement powers contained in it. Law enforcement agencies point to what they consider is a substantial obstacle to investigating computer crimes, their capacity under law to carry out those investigations. The Model Criminal Code committee report into computer crime offences stated:

quote.para: There appears to be a need for specialised enforcement provisions. The issues involved are both difficult on a technical level and controversial in relation to the protection of individual human rights and the rights of corporate entities.

speech.para: Following that report, the Cybercrime Bill 2001 contains new law enforcement powers relating to the search and seizure of electronically stored data. This is designed to enhance the ability of law enforcement agencies to detect and investigate crime involving the use of computers. The new powers provide that, firstly, an officer will be able to take a thing away from the search premises, where it is significantly more practicable than processing the thing at the search premises and where there are reasonable grounds to believe that the thing contains or constitutes evidential material. The `thing' we are talking about is a computer or a component of a computer. The `thing' is defined in this loose way because it may also include software or a whole range of objects, given the difficulty of forecasting exactly what the shape of technology in the rapidly changing environment will be.

Secondly, the powers in the bill allow an officer to use a computer on search premises to access data held on computers situated elsewhere on the belief, on reasonable grounds, that data held on other computers may contain evidential material of a kind covered by the search warrant. An amendment will be moved following discussions between the government and opposition to remedy a defect in the legislation. In the legislation presently before the House, the searching officer would not be required to notify operators of computers not on search premises if data held on those computers was accessed under the warrant. In other words, it would require a warrant to be issued to search the computer of the person who was suspected of having access to unauthorised materials or being involved in a crime, but if that search then was extended to people who were not the subject of a warrant they would not need to be notified. The perverse outcome would be essentially that those most interested in knowingâthe people against whom warrants were being sought, those involved in criminal activityâwould be notified but many third parties whose equipment was networked would not otherwise become aware of the fact that their equipment was being accessed in this way.

Thirdly, an officer will be able to copy data held on any electronic equipment or associated devices at search premises to a storage device if there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the data contains evidential material. In other words, you can go in, search the network system and download the material to the law enforcement's storage capacity so that the material can be assessed later. Fourthly, an officer executing a search warrant will be able to apply to a magistrate for an `assistance order' to be directed towards any person. The person to whom the order is directed will be required to provide the officer with such information or assistance as is necessary to enable the officer to access the data on the computer system, copy it to a storage device or convert it to documentary form.

In very simple language, the powers will essentially involve the capacity of officers to come onto premises to take things away. They will also enable a person to come onto premises to log onto a computer network and search other computers on the network. If that is difficult to do because of password or encryption devices, orders will be able to be sought to require those who have the supervision of that equipment to provide the information necessary to have access to the material. Material that is so accessed can then be downloaded onto storage devices to enable assessment of the material to take place off the premises.

Law enforcement agencies argue persuasively that there is a pressing need for specialised enforcement provisions along these lines. The opposition agrees that there is a pressing need, given the technical and practical barriers which technology presents to law enforcement agencies and, of course, given the general lack of expertise within law enforcement, which we have mentioned before. It would not be possible to have an effective system in place if we did not have powers which enabled people to take things away for later assessment or to require those who have the supervision of computer equipment to lend assistance. It simply would have defeated the object of the law enforcement powers. Even so, here we are entering a new realm of law enforcement. In doing so, we must consider whether we are going to continue to attempt to operate under the traditional framework of what is considered to be acceptable in the pursuit of criminals or whether we are designing a new framework. If we are designing a new framework, it is imperative that the process involves public debate.

These new law enforcement powers were not canvassed in the Model Criminal Code report, although the report did identify, in general terms, a need for extended law enforcement powers. None of these new measures was subject to scrutiny and discussion; other provisions of the bill were. The government has cited the Council of Europe's draft cybercrime convention as both the source of and justification for these increased law enforcement powers. Yet the cybercrime convention is only a draft which, although in its 25th version, has not been finalised or signed by the member countries of the Council of Europe. Further, Australia is not a member country of, and does not even have observer status with, the Council of Europe. Therefore Australia and Australians have not been involved in the development of the convention or the drafting of these increased powers, nor have we participated in debates about the appropriateness of the provisions in the draft.

With this legislation, we are entering new territory for law enforcement and, I repeat, this is not a decision which ought to be taken lightly. We are moving to accommodate this, as I think we should, in the national interest. Had the circumstances not been as they currently are, we would have thought the better course would have been to allow more extended debate so that these issues could have been canvassed at great length. But indeed, it was our initiative to say to the government that, notwithstanding the concerns that have been expressed, we thought the wisest course in these circumstances was to facilitate rapid passage of this legislation through the parliamentâlest any of us be thought responsible for hesitation in the face of circumstances which require a more rapid response.

Deciding what are appropriate law enforcement powers in this area involves making what are sometimes described as controversial trade-offs, and at other times necessary balances, between often competing concerns: the individual's right to privacy, the state's responsibility to combat crime, the society's need for secure communication networks, and corporate interests. The opposition has, in discussions with the government, drafted amendments to the law enforcement powers which address one of the more serious concerns. Under the bill, if law enforcement officers obtain a search warrant for a particular computer, they will be able to access information on any other linked computer without notifying third parties not named in the search warrant that their system has been entered into or that their data has been seized or copied.

The opposition's amendment, which the government has undertaken to support when it is moved in the Senate, provides that, where data is held on premises other than the warrant premises and that information is accessed and it is practicable to notify the occupier of the other premises that the data has been accessed under a warrant, the executing officer must give that notice as soon as practicable and inform that person if there will be continued access. The explanatory memorandum will be amended to make it clear that new section 3LB will be underpinned by the guidelines that are to be developed with the Privacy Commissioner. The guidelines will ensure that there is accountability in relation to decisions made under section 3LB in relation to these notifications.

The offences under the bill replace the existing offences in the Crimes Act, which are already seriously outdated, notwithstanding they were passed only 10 years ago. There are substantial new penalties relating to accessing or modifying computer data without authorisation. If you intend to commit a serious offence punishable for five years or more then you get the penalty that would have been attracted by that more serious offence. There are then specific offences: of causing any unauthorised modification of data in a computer where the person is reckless as to whether that modification will impair data, which attracts a penalty of 10 years imprisonment; of causing unauthorised impairment of electronic communications to or from a computer, which again attracts a penalty of 10 years imprisonment; of causing unauthorised access to, or modification of, restricted data held in a Commonwealth computerâthat is, data which is protected by a password or other security feature, as most members of parliaments areâwhich attracts a penalty of two years imprisonment; of causing unauthorised impairment of the reliability, security or operation of any data held on a Commonwealth computer disk, credit card or other device, which again attracts two years imprisonment; and the general offence of possessing or supplying data or programs which are intended for use in the commission of a computer offence, which attracts a penalty of three years imprisonment. Those offences were based on the Model Criminal Code committee report Damage and computer offences, which drew heavily on the UK Crimes Act, which itself is 10 years old.

Particular concerns have been expressed by many in the industry regarding the offence of possessing or supplying data or programs intended for use in the commission of computer offences. They have argued that those charged with the responsibility of maintaining systems must have quite a deal of software in order to fireproof computer systems from unauthorised entry. The plain fact is that these offences do require the intent of holding those devices for use in the commission of a computer related offence. So for an innocent useâthat is, a use directed towards properly servicing computer networksâyou may need to hold such equipment and no criminal liability would attach. I think there has been some misunderstanding of the operation of the Criminal Code and the way in which criminal prosecutions proceed. That said, it is not unreasonable that those concerns have been voiced; in fact, it is important that they are and that this type of legislation is subjected to full scrutiny.

One of the concerns expressed was with the terms and definitions used in the bill. They do introduce new concepts of law and they do also introduce what we believe, after great reflection, to be unavoidable ambiguity. It is always preferable, particularly in laws that establish serious criminal offences, to be as specific as possible. The citizen ought to be entitled to read a piece of legislationâparticularly one which imposes a potential liability of 10 years imprisonmentâand know clearly whether or not an act is criminalised. Some of the terms in this legislation are not defined. For example, the term `computer' is not defined and nor is the term `computer network'. In this instance, we believe that ambiguity is unavoidable. The absence was a conscious decision made to avoid the risk of over- or underinclusion of items in the definition of computer offence. Definitional issues were something with which the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee struggled. Although some of the outcomes in the bill are less than ideal, it is certainly not clear that any suggested alternatives would be any better.

The minister's office has indicated the government will move a number of specific amendments in response to the majority recommendations in the Senate. The EM will be amended to make it clear that offences under the bill do not apply to persons using an internal computer network. It will make clear that the definition of `restricted data' in section 478.1 is to be amended by deleting the words `to which access' and substituting the words `where access to the data'. Amendments will provide for the destruction of all personal information collected by law enforcement agencies which is not relevant to an investigation after a period of three months but subject to this time frame being extended on the authorisation of a senior officer. Items 12 and 28 of schedule 2 are to be amended by inserting `relevant' before `knowledge' in paragraph 3LA(2)(c) of the Crimes Act and 201A(2)(c) of the Customs Act. The Senate majority committee shared the view of many in the community that, if you have the power to take material away from a site where access has been granted and then assess it, there has to be some power at some future date to destroy what is often going to be very substantially personal information or business information if it is no longer material to the investigation of an offence.

What is clear is that there is significant disquiet in the IT industry as a result of the lack of prior consultation. We believe that there now needs to be further assessment in the future. I believe that our concerns expressed publicly prior to this legislation being passedâthat there ought to be more public consultationâare now superseded. There needs to be further public consultation to make certain that the legislation that will now pass the parliament is adapted most appropriately to the needs it will serve and that those who are the subject of the new legislation can have a forum to bring their concerns forward. This is so that, if there are any deficiencies or defects in the working through of this legislation, they can be ironed out as quickly and as practically as possible.

The government has acted wisely in obtaining a parliamentary slot for this legislation in what increasingly seems possibly to be the last week of sittings this year, notwithstanding the scheduled sittings later in the year. Given that valedictories are being timetabled for Thursday, it does seem highly likely that this may be the last week of the parliament. We have a government recklessly surging to the polls when the parliament can still sit, but there we are.

We think the government was wise to seek a slot in the House and in the Senateâthe processes of that place willingâso that we can have this legislation in place. The government has undertaken to accede to the amendments that have been proposed by the opposition and is itself putting forward a number of amendments. In that context, we certainly believe that this is responsible of both major parities. We hope it is also supported by the minor parties in the Senate so that there be no delay in relation to these matters. In conclusion, I go back to that fundamental point that we have a significantly underdone capacity when it comes to protection of our critical national infrastructure. We hope it costs the country nothing, but it risks doing so.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the Cybercrime Bill 2001. I would like to thank the Member for Denison for his extensive coverage of the bill and the amendments, and the opposition for their support of the bill and for the sense of urgency that is required to bring this bill before the House.

speech.para: I intend to cover more examples of the problems of cybercrime. It will come certainly as no surprise to the Australian people that we are well and truly in the information age. It is imperative that we give our law enforcement agencies the powers they need to combat the new form of criminal, the cybercriminal. I say `criminal' with the full meaning of the word. Just because technology is new or requires a high level of skill to operate, that does not excuse the perpetrators of these acts from the consequences of their actions.

Many well-publicised cases of cybercrime may have involved minors, and this new legislation will help by laying down stiff penalties for these sorts of crimes. There have been many cases of cybercriminals targeting businesses on the Internet and causing disruption that has led directly to loss of income. This of course is akin to theft. Early last year, for example, there was a concerted attempt to perform service attacks on eBay and Buy.com, resulting in the sites becoming almost inaccessible.

Another disturbing trend is the rising cases of cybervandalism. Cybervandalism is the deliberate exploiting of security holes in web servers to replace the usual pages found on a web site with ones that have the graphics defaced and altered or with other pages all together, sometimes expressing a political or social viewpoint. We do not tolerate people with spray cans daubing our shops and businesses with slogans; thus we should not tolerate cyber criminals performing the same action. Many businesses in my electorate have web sites and rely on these for contact with their customers as well as business promotion. Defacing a web site for kicks or for any other reason is a criminal act and should most certainly be treated as such.

Australians are well known to be early adopters of new technologies. When it comes to e-commerce and e-banking this has again proved to be the case. Many Australians now prefer the convenience of Internet banking. It offers many advantages over traditional banking and even offers many advantages over telephone banking, not the least of which is the integration with personal financial programs which are widely used in many Australian homes and businesses. With the majority of e-banking services using secure, socket layer based encryption, the data is for all intents and purposes secure as it travels over the Internet. But with many users storing the data in all manner of formats on their home or office PC, the dangers of it being somehow compromised remain relatively high. E-business has become a huge revenue earner for many Australian companies, many of which allow the purchase of goods via credit card on line. There have been a number of well-publicised thefts in the US of credit card numbers from servers. This undermines the public confidence in new technologies, thus downgrading the investment that businesses have placed in e-commerce. This legislation will help to address these factors in Australia by stiffening the penalties for these sorts of crimes.

Broadband services of all forms are becoming more prevalent in Australia, and pose a particularly tempting target for cybercriminals. Many home users and small businesses lack the technical skill to successfully install and configure fire walls to protect themselves from the wider Internet, and often neglect to install or update their antivirus software. Thus they are particularly vulnerable to attack. The recent spate of trojan horse attacks such as `Subseven' provide a cybercriminal with access to the data on a compromised computer with only an infected email attachment. Many of these new styles of trojan horse like `Phone Home' let the attacker know of the compromise, generally through anonymous email addresses or private interrelay chat channels.

I have spoken to industry professionals who claim that there are hundreds of scans each week looking for `trojaned' machines to steal information from or to simply use as a basis for other attacksâin particular, distributed denial of service attacks. The recent outbreak of the Sircam virus puts an entirely new perspective into the computer security equation. Like the I Love You and Melissa viruses, Sircam relies on the user opening an infected attachmentâwhich normally has a message body of, `I send you this file in order to have your advice,' or something along a similar veinâwhich many users will open. Also, like the above viruses, Sircam spreads by emailing itself to people in your address book as well as searching your hard drive for email addresses.

However, what makes Sircam particularly insidious is that it emails out potentially confidential files from your system to the recipients. These attachments are infected with the Sircam virus but, if the recipient does not have sufficient virus protection, the virus will infect the machine silently and then open the attachment as normal, thus revealing potentially confidential data to an unintended recipient.

The latest virus to hit the Internet is Nimda. As reported in the Financial Review on 20 September, Nimda created vulnerabilities of its own. Its name spells `admin' backwards, because the back door it creates on infected machines gives hackers `administrator' access to a network, according to the Australian computer emergency response team AusCERT. It seems that Nimda does have a payload. If you are infected, the network is vulnerable to a confidentiality attack at a later stage. Unlike Code Red, which only attacked web serversâbut which still had an estimated clean-up bill of $5.2 billionâNimda infected a variety of services and clients, multiplying the financial ramifications. Code Red largely attacked business systems. Consumers were also vulnerable to Nimda because of its ability to propagate through email.

The virus which attacked thousands of overseas users last Tuesday evening, 18 September, has struck at a time when companies have been on alert for a wave of cyberterrorist attacks following the previous week's US bombings. Most larger companies and organisations have server-side email scanning which keeps many of the viruses and trojans at bay. However, virus scanning can only ever be reactionary, for the virus has to be `in the wild' for at least a few hours before the antivirus companies can respond.

My last point is particularly relevant to schedule 1 of the bill, in relation to the amending of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979. I want to touch on something I mentioned earlier about empowering our law enforcement agencies to tackle cybercrime. With this provision exempting ASIO from the criminal sanctions of the bill, we are empowering our law enforcement agencies to tackle not only those who attack and steal on the Internet but also those who attempt to use the Internet as a safe haven from the law. To those people I say: if you are about to perform a criminal act in this country using the Internet, think again, as the penalties are stiff and our law enforcement agencies have the means, the backing and the resources to track you down and prosecute you. I commend the bill to House.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank the members who participated in this debate on the Cybercrime Bill 2001. They have made contributions of quality, if not in great number. There are a couple of points raised in the debate that I would like to respond to, but before I do that let me offer some general comments. The Cybercrime Bill 2001 is a very timely and very necessary piece of legislation. Computer related attacks have multiplied dramatically in the last couple of years and are becoming increasingly sophisticated. Just last week the Nimda virus infected Australian government networks, including those used by members of this parliament. Its predecessors, the Melissa, Love Bug, Anna Kournikova and Code Red viruses, also caused widespread disruption and damage. Earlier this year, denial of service attacks launched against Internet companies Amazon.com, Yahoo, eBay and Buy.com shut down their web sites for hours. There is potential for terrorist groups to direct similar attacks at our national information infrastructure and cause serious interference to government, the financial sector and industry. This bill contains new offences targeted at these activities and enhanced law enforcement powers to enable police to operate effectively in the electronic environment.

speech.para: The new unauthorised impairment of electronic communications offence is a significant improvement on the existing offences. The offence targets tactics such as denial of service attacks where an email address or web site is overloaded with a large volume of unwanted messages, thus crashing the computer system. Government and business networks are all vulnerable to such attacks. The 10-year maximum penalty for the offence recognises the importance of computer facilitated communication and the considerable damage and financial loss that can result if that communication is impaired. Another important offence in the bill is directed at those who use computer technology in an unauthorised manner to facilitate serious criminal activities. Under this new offence a person who causes unauthorised access, modification or impairment of data with intent to commit a serious offence will be subject to the same maximum penalty as the serious offence he or she intends to commit. For example, if a person uses the Internet to hack into or impair computer data with the intention of committing sabotage he or she will face up to 15 years in prison.

New investigation powers will provide law enforcement agencies with the necessary capability to search for evidential material in cyberspace. The increased use of encryption and passwords to prevent access to data can seriously hamper the progress of investigations. The bill will enable law enforcement officers to compel a person with knowledge of a computer system, including a suspect, to provide the key to encrypted data. Many computer networks now extend across different physical locations. A computer on search premises may be linked to other computers in a different building or even a different state. This bill gives law enforcement officers clear authority to search the entire computer network for evidential material. Information technology is a vital part of our social and economic infrastructure and this bill demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that that technology is not used for criminal or destructive ends.

The member for Denison asserted that the government has failed to consult on the bill. That is not in fact true at all. The offences were the subject of wide consultation through the Model Criminal Code process involving the Commonwealth, states and territories. The Model Criminal Code discussion paper and final report on the computer offences were each distributed to over 1,000 individuals and organisations, including peak IT bodies, and were also made available on the Internet.
