Consultation commenced in February 2000. Submissions from interested parties were taken into account in preparing the final Model Criminal Code report. The offences were also discussed at a number of conferences by officers of the Attorney-General's Department. The offences have also been publicly debated prior to enactment by New South Wales. Earlier this year the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and I announced the creation of two groups to coordinate Commonwealth efforts in this area. The e-security coordination group, chaired by the National Office for the Information Economy, ensures that these security issues are addressed strategically. The group is examining issues such as security standards, incident reporting, awareness raising and skills shortages, while the critical infrastructure protection group chaired by my department focuses on identifying and protecting those elements of the national information infrastructure critical to the national interest. It is through these groups that Australian agencies are working in cooperation with their overseas counterparts.

The importance of the need to better coordinate the protection, detection and response to any attacks directed against the national information infrastructure was recognised by the government by additional funding to key agencies in the 2000-01 budget. These efforts will help ensure that Australia remains at the forefront of e-security issues internationally and are among a range of steps the government is taking to give Australians confidence in doing business in the electronic operating environment.

The member for Denison also churlishly asserted that the government has poorly protected computer infrastructure. I have just explained what the e-security group has been doing and what the critical infrastructure protection group is doing. The bill itself shows that the government anticipated the need for an appropriate response. Law enforcement resources strategy focuses on an AFP-wide skilling process. The AFP is currently conducting an e-crime training program for all officers on gathering evidence in the electronic environment and it is not correct to say that the AFPâand this is what the member for Denison saidârelies on 10 people alone. It is not wise to rely solely on specialist squads. The AFP is no longer organised in specialist squads. It is a very modern investigation agency that is organised on a task force basis, and task forces are formed and reformed as there is a need to investigate a particular set of allegations.

As far as the resources available to the AFP are concerned, the government has a policy that the AFP will have the resources to be among the best investigation agencies in the world, and that is a policy that is being achieved. By contrast, in the last five years of the Labor government, the resources were so reduced that the AFP manpower was reduced by 400 officers. Since the Howard government came into office that figure was reduced by a further 100 as a result of necessary budget cuts to fill in the Beazley black hole. But since the 1996-97 budget, the AFP funding has been very extensively increased to provide the resources necessary to achieve the policy of it being among the best forces of its kind in the world. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY AGE RETIREMENT (STATUTORY OFFICEHOLDERS) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports the Abolition of Compulsory Age Retirement (Statutory Officeholders) Bill 2001. The bill amends acts which specify compulsory retirement limits for statutory office holders by repealing provisions that prevent the appointment of a person over a certain age for a term that would continue beyond a certain age. The opposition notes that the amendments will not affect the existing term of statutory office holders appointed before the bill commences; nor do the amendments affect federal judicial appointments or Australian Defence Force personnel. The opposition supported the Public Service Act 1999, which had the effect of removing compulsory age retirement in the Australian Public Service. We see the changes that are proposed by the government in this legislation as complementing the changes that were made in that legislation. It is, in fact, an overdue and welcome recognition that age is often an artificial barrier and that older people can make as valuable a contribution as anyone else in a variety of statutory positions. I commend the bill to the chamber.

âThe Abolition of Compulsory Age Retirement (Statutory Officeholders) Bill 2001 amends various acts which specify the compulsory age retirement limits for statutory office holders. At the moment, the government is hamstrung in regard to who it can appoint to statutory office holder positions because of the age limit of 65 years under the provisions of the acts. This bill will allow the government flexibility to continue to appoint people past the age of 65, and there are a lot of good reasons for that. The amendments do not propose changes to federal judicial appointments because they are governed by the Australian Constitution and as such are untouchable except by a referendum. They do not propose changes to the provisions that cover Australian Defence Force personnel because there are operational reasons why there are limits imposed within the Australian Defence Force, and most members of the House would see the merit in those provisions. It also does not propose changes to tenured positions where a person is appointed until a specified age.

speech.para: The coalition has focused during the past 5Â½ years on recognising the contribution that older people can make and their value to the community and to the workplace and, in this case, to the statutory office holder positions to which they may have been appointed. We believe very strongly that older people should be able to make their own decisions about when they wish to retire and when they wish to stop working.

This bill reflects our commitment to introduce choice into the workplace. This choice will now be extended to the government, who will be able to reappoint people after the age of 65 who are currently in positions that require them to retire at that age. In the future, new appointments of people over the age of 65 will be able to be made. It is very clear in our community and society that there are many people over the age of 65 who could continue to make a very useful contribution to boards and positions of responsibility but have been forced out of the work force because of archaic views and stereotyping which have no place in our society. The choice is also there now for people to choose the age at which they retire from statutory office holder positions, rather than being forced out at a time when they may be just starting to reach their peak. I support the bill and I am glad that the opposition is supporting it. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank the member for Melbourne and the member for Sturt for their contributions to the debate on the Abolition of Compulsory Age Retirement (Statutory Officeholders) Bill 2001 and I thank the opposition for supporting it. As I outlined in my second reading speech to the House, the bill if passed will abolish provisions in various acts that specify compulsory age retirement limits for statutory office holders. At the moment, these provisions prevent the appointment of a person over a certain age, commonly 65 years, or for a term that would continue beyond a certain age. These are important amendments that will greatly enhance the ability of a wide variety of statutory appointees to serve the Australian community beyond the usual retirement age. They will also widen the pool of people that the government can consider for appointment to statutory positions.

speech.para: The bill will assist in combating negative stereotypes about the ability of older Australians to contribute to the work force and the community. It will also remove archaic and artificial boundaries between work and retirement. It will provide greater flexibility and choice not only to the government in selecting potential appointees to statutory positions but also to office holders themselves by allowing them to choose their own retirement age. The amendments complement the removal of compulsory age retirement in the Australian Public Service made by this government when it enacted the Public Service Act 1999.

It will also remove differences between statutory office holders and provide greater consistency in the appointment process. As the bill makes clear, it will not affect the existing term of statutory office holders appointed before the bill commences. It will, however, remove any restrictions on their reappointment based on their age when their current term expires. Furthermore, the bill does not propose to amend arrangements relating to federal judicial appointments, Australian Defence Force personnel or tenured positions where a person is appointed until a specified age. The bill is an indication of the importance that the government places on the contribution that older Australians can offer beyond their usual retirement age. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: TRANSPORT AND REGIONAL SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (APPLICATION OF CRIMINAL CODE) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Mr Anthony:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe Transport and Regional Services Legislation Amendment (Application of Criminal Code) Bill 2001 amends certain offence provisions in transport legislation with a view to harmonising such legislation with the Criminal Code. As the Main Committee would appreciate, what is occurring with respect to this portfolio has occurred across a wide range of portfolios, the intention being to ensure that all Commonwealth criminal offences have standard formulation of the elements of intent, fault, burden of proof and penalty.

speech.para: The purpose of this bill is therefore to amend 33 portfolio statutes to ensure that they are in accord with chapter 2 of the Criminal Code Act 1995. The bill provides for amendments that specify whether an offence is one of strict liability. I clearly indicate, as we have in a range of other portfolios, that Labor support this bill.

Having said that, the bill also presents me with an opportunity to speak about a range of issues that go to the Department of Transport and Regional Services. In doing so, I think it is timely to examine what has gone on or, perhaps more to the point, what has not gone on under the current Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, especially after his recent comments in the Land that `something has got to give'. When he made those comments in the Land newspaper, the minister was referring to the fact that he could not cope with the demands of being National Party leader, Deputy Prime Minister, the member for Gwydirâalthough I understand he is rather relieved that Mr Tony Windsor is not running against him at the next federal electionâand the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. It is exceptionally important that we consider that comment that was reported in the Land recently, having regard to the portfolio responsibilities, which I do not consider to be onerous if you are prepared to do your work and take a little bit of interest in your portfolio.

That takes me to the record of the current Minister for Transport and Regional Services. As the shadow minister, I state clearly to the House today that I am not surprised that he wants to walk away from his responsibilitiesâresponsibilities for which he has drawn a considerable salary over the last couple of years, paid for by Australian taxpayers. I was brought up in a world in which you were entitled to expect a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. I was not brought up in a world in which you were paid a salary under false pretences. If you accept a salary or wage, then you are expected to return a dividend to the person or organisation that is paying that salary or wage.

That applies equally whether you are an attendant in this House, someone who looks after the gardens around Parliament House, the people who work in the cafeterias, the people who assist in preparing the Hansard or, perhaps importantly, those who are expected to show a bit of leadershipâthose who accept ministerial responsibility and swear an oath of office. When you swear an oath of office, you accept the responsibility to assist in the government of this country and a responsibility to lead; and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is paid a very handsome salary for this responsibility.

It is against that backdrop that I say the performance of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has been nothing short of a disgrace. Let us state, therefore, the most recent disgrace: the government's handling of the Ansett debacle, the collapse of an Australian icon which later this year would have celebrated its 70th birthday. Commenced by Reg Ansett, then a small business personâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Whilst a member may speak on this bill and its `related purposes', which gives some scope, as you understand, to what a speaker can say, my opinion is that the honourable member for Batman has now strayed completely away from anything related to the substance of this bill, and I submit that he should be brought back to it.
(Mr Mossfield)âOrder! There is no point of order, but I will ask the member to stick to the bill before the Main Committee and confine his remarks to the bill and its related purposes.

âYes, Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill and related purposesâAnsett, a transport company, and the Department of Transport and Regional Services. I think it is related to the issue before the House. I can understand the sensitivity of my colleague, who actually lives close to me. In some ways he is a friend, but then again he has the job of protecting a non-performer on his side of the House. Let us take the collapse of Ansett. It is an issue that goes to the operation of the Transport portfolio. It is about employment. It is about the movement of Australian passengers and international tourists. It is also about the movement of goods and servicesâgoods and services which as exports create jobs and prosperity for Australia. We have seen the collapse of a major employer, one offering direct employment and one indirectly creating tens of thousands of jobs in Australia.

speech.para: I suggest to the House today that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services displayed rank hypocrisy and callousness by abandoning Ansett workers and denying all responsibility for the demise of Ansett. Ansett staff, passengers and families were abandoned just over a week ago by Air New Zealand and the New Zealand government. I do not carry a candle for, nor will I seek to defend, Air New Zealand and the New Zealand government. They stand condemned in the same way in which the Australian government stands condemned. I actually believe that, in the same way in which the finger can be pointed at Air New Zealand and the New Zealand government, more importantly the finger can be pointed at the Howard-Costello government. Even more importantly, the finger can be pointed at the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The minister has often boasted about Australia's competitive aviation industry but he cannot admit that the same competition has been unsustainable and has contributed to the debacle surrounding the collapse of Ansett. I will tell you why: it goes to the failure of the minister to develop a sustainable aviation policy that does not simply allow airlines to cherry pick the lucrative ex-Ansett routes and assets.

It also goes to the failure of the minister to deliver what I would have thought was exceptionally important to the Leader of the National Party: regional aviation services. But, then again, I am not surprised. The National Party in the old daysâbetter known as the Country Partyâwas actually a party that prided itself on looking after the interests of rural, remote and regional communities. The truth of the matter is that the National Partyâas it is now the successor to the Country Partyâno longer strives to represent its traditional base. It has merely become the tail on the coalition dog. Mr Anderson is more at home walking around the suburban playing fields of the King's School in Sydney than he is representing regional Australia. The only reason he goes to regional Australia on a regular basis is to hide on the farm, to hide from his responsibilities. He is more a part of a Sydney-centric government than some members of the Liberal Party who now represent regional seats around Australia. The regional community has seen the National Party for what it is. It has been found wanting time and time again when it comes to standing up for the best interests, job opportunities, health, education and all the associated bread-and-butter living standards issues of people in regional Australia and their needs, aspirations and opportunities.

It also takes me to the failure of the minister to pursue all avenues to hold Air New Zealand, its company and executives, accountable for their mismanagement in the Ansett collapse. What worries me is that the minister knew how dire the situation was and he took no action to ensure that was avoided. He was in denial, as we have come to expect from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. I say that because he prides himself as a farmer and a businessperson. I would have thought that when you saw a company losing substantial amounts of money an alarm bell would have rung, that you would start to get a little bit worried about, `Well, is this company going to go down the chute?'

That is what the government thinks it represents: business people in Australia. It does not represent business people in Australia, because all it is succeeding at at the moment is turning big businesses into small businesses and destroying jobs and job security in Australia. I will dwell on this point because I want to remind the House that the minister received a document detailing the parlous state of Ansett's financial position when his office was given a copy of that document at a meeting with Ansett executives on 27 June this year. When asked what he knew about the document, the minister unfortunately informed the House that it did not exist. So much for the Prime Minister's code of conduct when it comes to being truthful with respect to answering questions without notice in the House!

I suggested to the House that the minister misled the House and that he has consistently misled the Australian public by claiming that he knew nothing about the financial state of Ansett. As usual, as is the nature of the Howard government, he then sought to blame everyone but himself for the Ansett mess, and he has consistently since then tried to cover up all knowledge about Ansett's financial meltdown. I suppose on this occasion at least his staff can be thankful that none of them have got the bullet, as occurred with the debacle of the Land Transport Act when the minister was again caught for not doing his job. On that occasion, two of his ministerial staff copped the rap, while the minister walked away from his responsibilities yet again. At least on this occasion two workers, even if they work for the coalition, have not been sacked because of the nonperformance of the minister.

The minister has also failed to protect Australian jobs in regional services because he has failed to live up to his ministerial responsibilities, but this reflects on the whole nature of the Howard government. The minister and his miserable, mean and desperate Howard-Costello government are to be rightly condemned for their role in the Ansett collapse. I will tell you why the Australian people, and more importantly a lot of the employers big and small, are condemning the Howard government for their nonperformance with respect to the collapse of Ansett.

Firstly, what is the solution? Never ever accept responsibility yourself, but apportion blame and responsibility to sort out the mess to others, some who are struggling to make ends meet in the Australian community at the moment. So what is the solution? Another taxâthat is the solution. The government creates a mess, and the travelling public is slugged with another tax to help clean up the mess. So last night in the House of Representatives we approved yet another new tax on the Australian community that will not only represent a serious cost impost on ordinary taxpayers but, in the end, also hurt jobs and job security in Australia because it will hurt the tourist industryâin which many businesses operate in regional communitiesâand therefore the economy and cost jobs.

But they are only little people; do not worry about that. A few of them might lose their jobs, a few of them might have to sell their homes because they cannot meet their mortgage payments, but they are only little people. That is not of concern to the Howard government because it spends most of its time around Collins Street in Melbourne looking after the needs of the big end of town. `We do not argue and think about little business people operating in areas such as the seat of Gwydir, because they can come and go. As long as we continue to have those secret trusts and to be given the quiet and secret donations from the big end of town, we are all right.' That is the nature of the operation of the Howard government.

I now go to the Howard government's incompetence and mismanagement of the Ansett ownership issue, arising from which we have an employee entitlement scheme that does not meet 100 per cent of workers' entitlements. We have the Prime Minister, in denying those workers 100 per cent of their entitlements, giving a lecture about what are statutory or community standards and what workers are entitled to receive when they get the bullet without receiving their full responsibilities. He says, `Yes, I will give you your accumulated annual leave, long service leave and outstanding payments but you will not get your severance pay. Eight weeks is acceptable but if it is nine or 10 weeks it is above community standards.' Imagine the Prime Minister lecturing ordinary Australian workers about community standards!

He does not apply the same when it comes to his superannuation entitlements. There is no talk about community standards when he starts to plan his retirement. Workers can only have eight weeks severance pay, but I tell you what: by the time the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister leave this House they will need a front-end loader to remove their superannuation entitlements from the Commonwealth Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme way in advance of community standards, but that is different. Different standards for the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister when it comes to workers' entitlements. Different standards on severance payments when it affected John Howard's big brother, Stan Howard, and National Textilesâfull application of severance pay and endeavours to protect the Prime Minister's brother from a proper investigation. Whose hand was in the pocket bailing Stan Howard out of trouble? John Howard looking after his big brother. Different standards on community standards on wages and conditions for John. Different standards when it comes to bailing out companies and helping to protect Australian jobs. The record speaks for itself.

I now go to the suggestion that future unspecified levies be imposed in order to ensure that greater entitlements are paid than currently provided under the government's flawed entitlement scheme. We have the failure of the government to protect jobs and the interests of Australian workers. We have Australian regional communities left without aviation services, jeopardising not only jobs and security in life but, very importantly, access to health services. Regional communities in terms of health depend on reliable aviation services. There is no regard for the health and wellbeing of people struggling in rural, remote and regional Australia.

We have had our aviation policy completely destroyed with respect to its integrity. We have also had the failure of the government to endeavour to broker a solution to the Ansett crisisâone that would save jobs, regional services and aviation policy. This is a prime example of why this bill is important and that we consider the performance of the minister, but there are other examples. Let's go to the issue of road funding.

The government has already spent the entire additional $400 million for roads of national importance and national highways announced in November of last year. The government has now advised on the web site that national road funding for the next three years has also been fully spent. That means no more federal road money unless the government can find other revenue streams. In aviation, after ripping off families and businesses on aviation fuel excise, the minister finally conceded that he was also ripping off the aviation industry by overcollecting $7.6 million on fuel costs when he increased the aviation fuel excise duty by 0.51c per litre in May 1999. Further, a bipartisan parliamentary report released in May confirmed the minister had failed on rail reformâa major rebuff to the minister's management of the rail industry. The House of Representatives transport committee report Back on track called for better planning and coordination of the national track and a strategic national approach to investment in the nation's rail track system. It noted such an approach to rail was lacking under the current government.

Another rail failure was the government's botched handling of the speed rail Sydney-Canberra very fast train proposal, a tender process that effectively was to start and finish at no net cost to government, which initially blew out to $300 million, then to $2 billion, before eventually leading to the collapse of the project at considerable cost to the private sector. An estimated $30 million was wasted by the private sector as a result of that debacleâthe tender process on the very fast train.

We also saw earlier this year the Liberal Party President Shane Stone's leaked memo, which was yet another slap in the face for the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and Leader of the National Party. That memo confirmed what people across Australia have been saying for some timeâthat is, that the Howard-Costello government, with its lap-dog the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, is out of touch with the needs of ordinary people, is mean and tricky and cannot be trusted. The memo confirmed that even government backbenchers realised the Howard-Costello government has been too tricky on issues such as GST on beer and fuel. It proved that the transport minister was more concerned with defending policies that have kicked workers in the guts, rather than standing up for regional Australia. It confirmed that the minister was not only missing in action but was also absent without leave while drawing a considerable salary.

The minister has tried to dismiss the impact of the GST on public transport fares and fuel costs, but Australians know that the GST has not helped public transport, particularly the bus industry, and therefore has not helped improve our environmental performance. Equally, the application of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme has not provided the incentives that could add to increased public transport patronage in urban areas. Again on road funding, the critical Australia National Audit Office report on management of a national highway has highlighted the total failure of the minister to do his jobâyet again. The report raised serious concerns about the administration of road funding within the Department of Transport and Regional Services. Further, it questioned the minister's competence to handle this most important policy areaânot a complicated area, merely a matter of detail and paying attention to the job that you are paid for. The report directly criticised the minister for failing to report to the parliament important financial details about road funding. The minister was then forced to admit that he had failed to fill his requirements under the Australian Land Transport Development Act. He said:

quote.para: Technically, like previous ministers, it would appear that I am in breach.

speech.para: What the minister did not sayâand this is about the whole performance of this tricky, mean governmentâis that only coalition ministers had breached the requirements of this legislation. That was proven in the House. The other thing: the minister used two staff as scapegoats. Two ordinary Australians hit the wall. They lost their jobs to enable the minister to hide from his responsibility with respect to nonperformance of his duties under the Land Transport Act. He sacked two staff and blamed them for his incompetence with respect to the Land Transport Act. Yes, that is what he did. Time is up, Mr Minister. People in the transport industry have had a gutful of your nonperformance. I also remind the House that this was the second time the Audit Office had criticised the minister for failing to comply with his own legislation. At the end of 1999 the Audit Office slammed him for breaching aviation legislation when he failed to supply corporate plans for two years, which the office concluded was in breach of the legislation. It was not good enough to say that he did not know about the requirements of the legislation, because he is the minister. He is paid to know about the requirements of legislation.

Another road issue goes to the ability to make a decision. I refer to the Hume Highway bypass at Albury. It is another typical botched decision. Revelations from the independent auditors that the minister did not have the final figures when he made the decision in February destroyed the integrity of this so-called decision. Labor went out of its way not to play politics on this decision. Prior to the decision, on a visit to Alburyâin fact, CorowaâI made it clear that the opposition would support an internal or external road. All we wanted was a requirement on the government to make a decision. It did not matter whether it was internal or external; we would support the decision because we needed a clear-cut decision once and for all.

But instead of the government being decisive, what did we get? Two bob each way yet again. In doing so, we later found that we are going to get a little bit of an internal road and a little bit of an external road, because it is about playing both sides of the road. They thought it was about time to please both groups in the Albury-Wodonga community. We then found that the minister did not even have the facts before him: he failed to consult the local councils and he failed to consult the New South Wales and Victorian governments.

I think the time has come for this minister to accept his responsibilities, be they for road transport, the railway industry or aviation. I also remind the House that, when it comes to aviation, because the minister's mind was not on his job we saw Ansett grounded at Christmas and Easter this year. An investigation eventually clearly proved that part of the difficulty with respect to the grounding of Ansett in December and at Easter was because of the nonperformance of CASA, an agency that the minister has direct responsibility for. A Senate report on the CASA investigation into serious irregularities at an Albury based airline had previously slammed the minister's handling of their management. The Senate committee concluded, in consideration of these matters, that CASA had botched the investigation into the maintenance records of air facilities and that senior CASA staff then tried to cover up their handling of the investigation, confirming the minister's continuing mismanagement of aviation policy.

I now want to deal briefly with the maritime and shipping issue. In essence, there is no policy. There is no maritime policy of the Howard government at the moment. I think that is a tragedy for an island nation such as Australia. It is also a tragedy on the eve of World Maritime Day. I want to remind the House today, not only on the eve of maritime day but also on the eve of potentially an international onslaught against terrorism, with a potential loss of lives, that the Australian merchant marine has historically played a critical role in defence operations for Australia. I refer to what Major-General Cosgrove said about the East Timor crisis. It is more pertinent than ever to remind the community of this today. He basically said that, without the contribution of our marine service to East Timor, the Australian armed forces and the United Nations could not have done their job.

I hope that the minister thinks about this today, because it is international maritime day tomorrow. I think we as a community owe a debt of gratitude to our marine services, who not only have helped in East Timor but all around the world in the next couple of weeks and months they will potentially help the Australian and international community in the fight against terrorism. I want to clearly state on behalf of the opposition today that it is imperative that the Commonwealth government recognise World Maritime Day and, in doing so, support moves to protect the health and safety of seafarers and eliminate substandard shipping in honour of the contribution of the one in eight seafarers who made the ultimate sacrifice during the Second World War. Surely at least that could be acknowledged by the Howard government on the eve of significant international turmoil in which our marine services can be expected to lend a hand.

We have long recognised the economic and strategic importance of maintaining vibrant, efficient and safe domestic services. I simply say on behalf of the opposition that if we are returned to the government benches after the next election then we will expect the minister's office and the department to perform with respect to our responsibilities as an island nation to have a decent shipping service in place in Australia.

I simply say in conclusion that, yes, the Labor Party supports the legislation before the House today. It is of a very important technical nature. But I want the minister to finally accept that he has let the Australian community down when it comes to his nonperformance of his ministerial responsibilities. Significant examples have been laid on the table today for the consideration of the Australian public. They are entitled to better from a minister of the Crown. They are entitled to a fair day's work for a fair day's pay, and the salary of a minister is more than fair. It is about time the minister accepted that he should do his job and take transport seriously rather than say, as he did recently in an interview with the Land, `Something has to give; the job is too big for me.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Transport and Regional Services Legislation Amendment (Application of Criminal Code) Bill 2001 is a fairly straightforward and non-controversial bill, but I could not let the opportunity go by without responding to some of the comments by the member for Batman.
âThe member for Batman has made a lot of allegations, as usual. I think he has testedâ
(Mr Mossfield)âOrder! The member for Batman, you were listened to in silence.

âYou are out of order, Batman! I now turn to the issue of Ansett. The Leader of the Opposition himself made the point 10 years ago that there was always the possibility that one of the major carriers could fall over when the Labor Party deregulated the airline industry. If you do deregulate, which the Labor Party said was the appropriate policy, then these things may happen. It never fails to amaze me how brilliant the Labor Party are in opposition. They are the most brilliant opposition Australia has ever had, but in government it is always a totally different picture.
âIs the fall of Ansett an achievement? That is one of your high points of government, is it?
âThe member for Batman will cease interjecting.
âWhy don't you just pull your head in, Batman? If you had an original idea, you would be dangerous.
âYou have something to cover up about airlines. That's your problem.
âYou are malicious and very foolish in the sorts of things you talk aboutâunacceptably foolish.
âYou know what I'm talking about.
âI will not be provoked by the member for Batman, but he will use anything for any political advantage. He will use even people's grief for any purpose. He is a disgrace.
âYou're a disgrace.
âOrder! I call the member for Batman to order again. He was listened to in silence; he should listen to other speakers in silence.

âAs things about Ansett come out they snigger and smile. Why don't you get serious about the issues of Australia for a change? The issue for Ansett, as has been well described in recent weeks, regrettably and sadly, is that their costs were far higher than their competitors'. The mismanagement has been well discussed. The clearest comparison I can make to the running of Ansett by its board is the running of the Australian economy by the Labor Party when they were in governmentâand I can talk about 20 per cent interest rates.

speech.para: We hear a lot about unemployment and, yes, there are many jobs on the line. In this last week, we have seen Traveland put back into business; in many places, we have seen Kendell put back into the sky; and, over the last five years, we have seen something like 800,000 new jobs created. Coming from where we were a fortnight ago with the aviation industry, I think this minister has performed in an outstanding manner given the degree of difficulty that he had to confront. I am well used to the Labor Party, as they were previously in government in my own state. I well remember the State Bank collapse, when $3 billion to $4 billion went down the tube due to lack of supervision, and the penalty that the state paid. I well remember the `recession we had to have'. I remember the promises in 1992, leading up to the 1993 election, when Labor said that they were going to give tax cuts and then never did. Then, even worse than that, they actually jacked up the WST, the wholesale sales tax, with not one cent of compensation given to age pensioners.

Let me come back to the bill. I think it is important that we do talk about the bill, and the fact is that it is being dealt with in the Main Committee because it is not contentious. I will just run through some of those issues which are germane to the bill. The Criminal Code provides for a standard manner of dealing with criminal offences in Commonwealth legislation. Essentially the bill operates by removing those parts of existing acts that establish criminal offences and penalties and replacing them with sections that are consistent with the code to aid the courts in interpreting criminal offence provisions in a consistent manner. For example, the bill deletes section 20A of the Civil Aviation Act 1988, which deals with the negligent operation of aircraft and replaces it with a new section dealing with the reckless operation of aircraft. This is to ensure that the act will be consistent with the concept of conduct, circumstance and result as defined by the code. These concepts are designed to establish a fault elementâthat is, to aid the courts in consistently determining the intent or state of mind of an offender when an offence is committed. The bill does not create any new offences of strict liability and does not amend provisions that deal with the process of appeals or rights during any appeal process. The bill will reduce penalties for a small number of existing offences so that they will be consistent with the Criminal Code, as there is no justification for maintaining the penalties at their current levels. It will also retain a small number of penalties, chiefly protecting the marine environment, at a level higher than those in the Criminal Code.

There are a number of acts covered by the bill and they are well listed in the explanatory memorandum. Some of them include the Adelaide Airport Curfew Act 2000, the Civil Aviation Act 1988, the Explosives Act 1961, the Submarine Cables and Pipelines Protection Act 1963. The bill also deals with the amendments of territories and regional services legislation, including the Albury-Wodonga Development Act 1973. So it is more of a procedural bill as described in the general principles that I have placed before the Main Committee.

In conclusion, I once again put on the record my appreciation of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and this government in the management of this nation, in its stewardship over the last five years. I think it has been an outstanding record of achievement. The support for the local roads fundingâthat $1.6 billion package which was so well received at the end of last yearâis really comment in itself of the way that this government is determined to look after and support and maintain the infrastructure of this country from the bottom up; that is, particularly at the local government level. I believe in this government and the people of the calibre of the Deputy Prime Minister. For the effort that he has put in, he is to be highly commended. I commend this bill to the Main Committee.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âI will be summing up the Transport and Regional Services Legislation Amendment (Application of Criminal Code) Bill 2001 on behalf of the Deputy Prime Minister. I am sure that members on the other side of the chamberâand we certainly on this side of the chamberârealise why he is so busy. It is a great pleasure for me to be able to sum up on his behalf. I certainly endorse the comments of the member for Grey, my colleague and neighbour out on our western Queensland borders at Birdsville. I think his comments in relation to the Deputy Prime Minister are very appropriate at this time.

speech.para: The amendments proposed by this bill will maintain the status quo with regard to the existing Transport and Regional Services portfolio criminal offence provisions. The amendments proposed by this bill must be made before 15 December 2001 to ensure that the offence provisions continue to operate in their current manner. The exemption of certain road transport reform legislation from the application of the Criminal Code is not permanent. The Commonwealth has referred the question of amending the acts to the National Road Transport Commission to be pursued through the workings of the Australian Transport Council. This application of part 2.5 of the Criminal Code to certain Transport and Regional Services portfolio acts is necessary to prevent competing corporate criminal liability regimes operating in relation to the same offences.

The bill does not create any new offences of strict liability. Instances where existing penalties exceed Criminal Code policy for strict liability offences are limited, in the main, to provisions related to protection of the marine environment. The penalties for a small number of existing strict liability offences have been reduced to comply with Criminal Code policy for strict liability offences where there is no policy justification for maintaining the penalties at their current levels. The bill disapplies chapter 2 of the Criminal Code to the state and territory criminal offences that are applied to Commonwealth non-self-governing territories.

In conclusion, I thank members of the Main Committee who have spoken on this bill. I also take the opportunity to thank the members of the department who have been responsible for the drafting of legislation. I think that often in this place we forget the hard work that goes on behind the scenes to bring forward such legislation. A lot of work by departmental people has gone into making sure that what comes forward does meet the requirements of government. This is a process that started long before we came into government. I do thank members of the department for their work in that area. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 September, on motion by Mr Hawker:

motion.para: That the bill be read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise this afternoon to speak on the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001. In doing so I would like to acknowledge that the member for Grey just scampered from the House rather than remain to speak on what I think is an exceptionally important bill. As a number of us know, this bill goes to vehicle manufacturing in Australia. Mr Wakelin, who contributed to the previous debate on the transport and regional services bill, represents a major seat in South Australia, the seat of Grey. One of Australia's principal vehicle manufacturing factories is Mitsubishi. It employs thousands of workers, directly and indirectly, in automotive manufacturing in South Australia.

speech.para: I would have thought it would be appropriate for the member for Grey, who prides himself on being an expert on transport policies, to have at least made a contribution to a debate that relates to jobs and job security in his home state of South Australia. But again we have the member for Grey missing in action when it comes to standing up for jobs and job security in his home state. I make these comments because the intent of the bill is to make significant changes to the regulatory regime for ensuring vehicle compliance with the Australian design rules. It is about a fair go for allâfor companies who trade in the second-hand vehicle market and for companies who employ thousands of workers directly and indirectly in the manufacture of new vehicles in Australia. It is about a fair outcome for all in the industry. It is also about protecting the best interests of consumers.

I regard the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001 as important because it is also related to vehicle safety and to the protection of consumers in their purchases. It reforms a system that has been open to abuse and exploitation for a purpose not intended. Having sought to achieve something with legislation, if we find that the legislation does not meet the mark, it is the role of the parliament to make sureâon this occasion, with agreement on both sides of the Houseâthat we achieve what was originally intended. On this occasion that is exceptionally important, because what has occurred with respect to the misuse of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act has had implications for Australian jobs and consequences for Australian taxpayers. While the opposition will support the bill, we call on the parliament to condemn the Howard government for their maladministration of the scheme. That very maladministration has led to a blow-out in the scheme and the number of vehicles receiving concessions offered by the low volume scheme. The maladministration of the schemeâunder the supervision of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and Deputy Prime Ministerâand the slowness of the Howard-Costello government to redress obvious problems have impacted on Australian jobs, created uncertainty in job security in vehicle manufacture and, in turn, king-hit Australian taxpayers yet again, at a time when they have been fully exploited by the Howard government through the inequitable application of the GST.

As I speak this morning, a second reading amendment is circulating for consideration. Before I turn to the specifics of the bill, I want to discuss the impact of the bill on many small businesses. In the main, those businesses are importers of second-hand vehicles under the low volume scheme. Whilst it has been difficult to get figures on exactly how many jobs are affected, it must be acknowledged that the number is significantâpossibly in the order of 400 businesses. You and I, Madam Deputy Speaker Gash, know the importance of that, because one of the engine rooms of job growth in Australia is small business.

The explanatory memorandum provides some clarification of the impact of the low volume scheme. In 2000, 943 individual businesses applied for plates under the scheme. As many do not rely solely on used import activities, and low volume scheme businesses have the capacity to switch to other vehicle types, industry representatives suggest that there are approximately 400 businesses that will be affected by the tightening of the eligibility criteriaâin particular, four-wheel drive importersâin the immediate term. However, small businesses will, correctly, benefit from an increase in the annual cap from 25 to 100 used passenger vehicles per approval holder. This will help to improve the viability of firms currently constrained by the 25-car limit.

No information is available on the number of people employed, the value of the turnover of low volume scheme businesses or the contribution to the economy. Last year, the then Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business asked the Office of Small Business to prepare a report on the impact of the new scheme. However, as the questioning by the shadow minister for small business, Joel Fitzgibbon, revealed, the government had decided that that report was confidential. So much for transparency, honesty and integrity in government.

That was the answer given to the shadow minister's question in February this year. The then minister for small business said that the report on the impact of the scheme was confidential. This is another example, I believe, of mean and tricky decision making by the current government. Alternatively, on that occasion perhaps the minister was too busy dealing with the telecard affair, which also cost the Australian taxpayer, until he was forced to accept his responsibilities.

Perhaps my colleagues in the other place can uncover that report and place on the record the true impact on small business. The impact on these businesses is a key reason why the bill was referred to a Senate committee for scrutiny, along with the regulations when they became available. This has enabled affected business operators, at the initiation of the opposition and their representatives, to be absolutely clear about what is envisaged in the bill.

In referring this bill to the Senate committee, however, I would like to make it clear that the opposition supports the intent of the billâthat is, to return the low volume scheme to its original or a similar purpose. We also fully support the measure to introduce a registered automotive workshop scheme to improve the regulation of design rules and enhance consumer protection and informationâan objective supported by those on both sides of the House. It is our view that this is necessary to restore the integrity of the scheme and to repair the damage from the government's maladministration of the scheme to date.

We as an opposition have empathy with the affected small business people who have built their businesses on the basis of the opportunities provided by the scheme to date. But we cannot escape the point that this scheme was not intended to provide an almost open slather concessional scheme for imported second-hand vehicles. That arrangement has a major impact on employment in other sections of industry and has unfortunately created an uneven playing field.

As stated earlier, the opposition has been critical of the government not only for their maladministration of the scheme but also for failing to properly assess the impact of the bill, and we have required the Senate committee to assist in this regard. The opposition has ensured, through an agreement with the minister for transport, that the government will not take the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill to a Senate committee until such time as there are draft regulations for the committee's consideration. Therefore, the Senate committee and the affected industries and representatives had an opportunity to comment on the detail, and that is important. It is about making sure that those who are affected are fully consulted and given an opportunity to see what the government intends with respect to this bill. We now await the report from the Senate committee, which I understand will be tabled in the other place today.

On that basis I turn to the particulars of the bill. Firstly, I refer to the content of the bill. The low volume scheme was introduced in 1970 to facilitate the issue of certificates of compliance to manufacturers producing fewer than 50 vehicles each year of a particular model, such as Australian made Bolwells and imported right-hand drive Buicks and Cadillacs. The other schemes in operation are the full volume scheme and the personally imported vehicles scheme. The full volume scheme is used by major manufacturers for large volumes of standard vehicles, which are required to meet all currently applicable design rules based on type approvals. The arrangements for the full volume scheme do not discriminate between new and used vehicles, except that used passenger vehicles supplied under the scheme are subject to a $12,000 special duty. The personally imported vehicles scheme enables migrants and Australian residents returning from overseas to treat their vehicle as part of their personal effects.

The concessions available on the low volume scheme are significant. The scheme allows alternative forms of evidence of compliance with many of the Australian design rules, such as not requiring destructive or other expensive testing. Secondly, vehicles are required to comply with Australian design rules that were in force at the date of original manufacture rather than the current applicable Australian design rule. Thirdly, there is an exemption from the $12,000 special duty on used passenger motor vehicles which applies if they were imported under the full volume scheme. These low volume scheme concessions were designed for specialist and enthusiast vehicles, as these may not otherwise be viable for manufacture with the high cost of volume certification spread over a small number of vehicles. The low volume scheme was progressively modified to increase the eligibility requirements from 50 to 100 vehicles and, from 1985, extended to used vehicles that were not covered by the full volume scheme. Today, the low volume scheme predominantly involves imported used vehicles and therefore most of the participants are now importers and converters, not manufacturers.

An interdepartmental task force established in 1997 identified, correctly, significant problems and issues with the operation of the low volume scheme and compliance with Australian design rules. These problems were, in essence, summarised as follows. The number of imports have increased markedly from 1,000 in 1993 to 16,825 in the year 2000, with a significant jump in the period from 1995 when 1,705 were importedâthe largest increase being in the passenger vehicle and four-wheel drive categories. Secondly, the measures for compliance with current Australian design rules are more lenient, therefore causing concern that the low volume scheme is increasing the risk and likelihood of high numbers of noncompliant vehicles on the market. Thirdly, while there is currently a limit of 25 vehicles per year per approval for passenger cars and either 25 or 100 for other categories, the number of approval holders is not controlled.

Fourthly, there are consumer protection issues related to the lack of after-sales service, availability of replacement parts and the inability to perform vehicle recalls. Fifthly, four-wheel drives where the only difference from the full vehicle scheme model is the nature are being imported under the low volume provisions. For example, the Toyota Surf imported in large numbers is the same as the FV scheme Toyota 4-runner in every respect other than the diesel engine. Sixthly, the low volume scheme is being used to import from Japan, where the regulatory regime results in a higher vehicle turnover, large volumes of what are essentially standard vehicles.

As well as the safety and consumer issues that I have listed, the escalating growth in used car imports is causing concern both in the mainstream industry and at a regulatory level. These issues were identified by the government. The explanatory memorandum notes that the Australian vehicle manufacturing industry directly employs 51,000 Australians and exports nearly $3.3 billion worth of automotive parts. Therefore its need for stability in regulatory policy is a must. Such stability is about maintaining and attracting future investment to the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia and also enabling those companies to plan for the future. The essential problem voiced by the manufacturing industry is that many of the imports are in direct competition with vehicles supplied without concessions.

The task force and government considered a range of options to address the issues with the operation of the low volume scheme and the impact on compliance with Australian design rules and industry. Various options for reform were considered in the areas of eligibility requirements, type approval versus an individual vehicle approval regime versus self-regulation, and options to smooth the transition to any new arrangements. In relation to eligibility requirements, the task force originally rejected the option to tighten up the operation of the scheme, preferring to just clarify the guidelines. The reason for concern was the impact on small business. The government ultimately opted to totally overhaul the low vehicle scheme to return the scheme to its original purpose: concessions only for specialist and enthusiast vehicles. The burgeoning number of used imports was the reason the scheme needed more than mere tinkering.

Under the renamed low volume scheme, all imported vehicles will be assessed against new criteria set out in the administrator's circular 0-2-12 specialist and enthusiast vehicle scheme eligibility. Transparency will also be increased with recent eligibility rulings and eligible vehicles published on the Internet. The option to retain the current type approval system was rejected by the task force. A registered automotive workshop scheme will be implemented to introduce a certification scheme based on vehicle by vehicle approval by registered workshops for used vehicles. All registered automotive workshop scheme participants will be required to have ISO9001 certification. The registered automotive workshop scheme will increase the level of assurance that vehicles being supplied to the market comply with Australian design rules in place at the time that the vehicle was manufactured.

Other measures under the registered automotive workshop scheme will ensure the consumer is aware the vehicle is a used imported vehicle. I think consumers are entitled to have that knowledge at hand. Various transition arrangements were considered with a two-year option adopted. That is about making sure that on the way through, and overcoming faults in the current legislation, we also have regard to the impact of the new bill on the industry. This will therefore allow, and correctly so, time for legislative change, finalisation of administrative arrangements and for business to adjust. This was clearly preferred to an option that allowed the current low vehicle scheme to continue for the life of models currently approved. The life of approvals for these models would continue for seven to nine years. Under the preferred two-year transition, low volume scheme imports will still approach 28,000 in 2002 on current trends. Should the transition period be extended to 2005, this figure is expected to rise to over 50,000 vehicles.

The Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill will, in essence, amend the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 to include these and other related changes. In summary, what will the amendments do? Firstly, and importantly, these amendments allow for a register of specialist and enthusiast vehicles to be established which will be used to restrict the importation of used vehicles, except used motorcycles, to those assessed to be specialist and enthusiast and prevent the importation of what are effectively standard vehicles. Secondly, these amendments introduce a scheme to regulate registered automotive workshops. Thirdly, these amendments require imported used vehicles to be modified and inspected by registered automotive workshops on a vehicle by vehicle basis to ensure each vehicle's compliance with the appropriate national standards, which provide for vehicles to be modified and inspected and approved for plating on a vehicle by vehicle basis rather than on the basis of vehicle type.

Fourthly, these amendments introduce a charging regime for registered automotive workshops that aims to cover the costs of administration of the scheme. Fifthly, these amendments limit the number of vehicles a registered automotive workshop may supply during a specified period. Sixthly, these amendments create various offence provisions. Seventhly, these amendments replace the existing approvals to modify imported used vehicles with transition approvals. Finally, these amendments provide for the transitional approvals to be enforced for a period to be set out in the regulations. The period of the transitional approvals will aim to achieve a smooth transition to the new arrangements.

In conclusion, the opposition believes, as does the government, that the bill will definitely make significant reforms to vehicle importation and replace the current low volume scheme with a scheme that is more akin to the original purpose of the low volume scheme. The bill will also lay the groundwork for a regulatory scheme for imported used vehicles that will improve quality, safety and consumer confidence. It is an important requirement for us as legislators to guarantee that, with respect to improving used vehicles, we will contribute to improving quality, safety and consumer confidence in the application of this scheme.

I suggest to the House that the government is to be condemned for the maladministration of the scheme. This maladministration and its consequences mean there will be pain for many small business operators. This would not have happened with a competent minister and with a competent government. In the other chamber, Labor awaits the tabling of the Senate committee report; a report that was initiated from a request by the opposition for an appropriate inquiry into this matter. We clearly wanted to ensure the best possible outcome: we wanted to have the bill on the table for consideration and we also sought to ensure that the industry had access to the regulations that will cover the operation of the bill.

At a recent ministerial briefing on this bill with departmental officers in attendance, I was surprised that the government was still unable, after many months of consideration, to table the regulations that will cover the operation of the bill. It is another example of the government not doing its homework with respect to major changes that have an impact on small business operators not only in capital cities but also in many regional communities around Australia.

It is clear from the comments I have made today that the government ought to be condemned for not doing its job. On that basis, the opposition will move a second reading amendment to the bill. As I have indicated, the opposition supports the intent of the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001. Those on both sides of the House have given serious consideration to the implications of this bill on major manufacturing establishments, jobs and job security and the potential impact on small businesses around Australia, many of whom also employ a considerable number of people. Clearly, there is agreement on both sides of the House that the bill cleans up existing difficulties within the industry. When the regulations that will cover the operation of the bill are in place, they will guarantee that we have paid sufficient attention to the transitional arrangements that protect not only Australian consumers and the travelling public but also the best interests of small businesses who operate in this industry. I therefore commend the bill to the House. It is a bill that is very much supported by those on both sides of the House. In doing so I move the following second reading amendment that stands in my name:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its poor administration of the Low Volume Scheme, thereby jeopardising Australian jobs and threatening the safety of Australian motoristsâ.

talk.start.para: (Mrs Gash)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment.

âI rise to speak on the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001. I have to say that the member for Batman was going all right until he got to his pious amendment and started condemning the minister and the government. Two of my constituents, Craig and Robyn Dean, own and operate a company called Crossover Car Conversion in Ferntree Gully in Victoria. They not only are lovely people but also have a fantastic business and they produce beautiful vehicles. They do conversion of American left-hand drive to Australian right-hand drive standards and you cannot tell that the cars have been converted. They keep spare parts for all the vehicles that they import.

speech.para: They came to me about the issue of the motor vehicle standards being amended something like five years ago because it was already the intent of the Department of Transport and Regional Services to make amendments to the low volume scheme that was, and still is, in operation. The reasons for that became apparent. Originally, as I understand it, the importers of used vehicles under the low volume scheme could bring in 100 vehicles. I think it was in 1992, ahead of the 1993 electionâif my memory serves me rightâthat the then Keating ALP government brought in a $12,000 duty on imported used vehicles. We supported that measure. The reason for the measure was simply the fact that Japanese regulations for their motor vehicle regime posed a threat of flooding Australia with Japanese second-hand motor vehicles at very low prices and putting at risk our manufacturing industry.

Why would the Japanese want to sell their second-hand vehicles to Australia? Because their regulations mean that the inspection that a car must go through once it is three years old is so expensive that they cannot afford to reregister the vehicles. The cost is literally non-affordable. So they buy a motor vehicle, drive it for three years, trade itâit is almost worthlessâand the dealers want to export those vehicles because they cannot sell them in Japan and nobody can afford to buy them. That is exactly what happened in New Zealand. New Zealand had an assembly industry but it has since closed down because they opened the door to the used vehicles. I have to say that they have very low priced vehicles in New Zealand, but they lost their industry and they lost all the support structure that goes with the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. The Labor governmentâagain, I think, it was in 1993âbrought in the $12,000 duty, but then the low volume scheme was adjusted down to a limit of 25 vehicles per importer. You needed a piece of paper to get approval as a licence plate holder.

Over time, the industry itselfâand particularly backyardersâfigured out a way to get around the regulation by having their uncle or cousin or aunty or whatever import the cars. They then did some work on them, had them inspected, passed and got approval plates in order to be able to get enough vehicles. The industry, having figured out how to get around the regulations, started cranking up and importing more and more vehicles, many of which are from Japan and are very similar to models manufactured here by the two Japanese manufacturers in AustraliaâToyota and Mitsubishi.

My constituents were concerned because backyarders were hurting their business and doing so by not really properly making their used vehicles meet Australian standards, putting at risk the safety of the motor vehicle travelling public and the general public overall. They were concerned about the safety issues; they were concerned that they were having unfair competition because these backyarders with no infrastructure, no spare parts, no backup serviceânothingâwere able to bring in these vehicles, do very little work on them whatsoever and have them approved for sale in the Australian market. They thought that was hurting their business and the legitimate industry and legitimate small businesses in Australia that have developed.

I have been working on this issue for a very long time, and I am particularly pleased with two aspects of the specialist and enthusiast vehicle low volume scheme. One thing I am particularly pleased about is that the government and the minister agreed with my suggestion that we go back to 100 vehicles per workshop.

The other recommendation that I madeâand these recommendations, by the way, came from my constituents, Craig and Robyn Deanâwas to bring into place a registered workshop system so that the workshops themselves approved each vehicle and they were responsible to the department for keeping up standards. We did not have to have a third party inspect every vehicle, but workshops would have to go through a testing program to convince the officials that what they were doing was up to the standards which we require of all motor vehicles in Australia. As part of the registered workshop requirements, the industry must now meet the ISO9001 year 2000 quality management system which has been developed for this new scheme. I am pleased that my constituents have now satisfied those standards: they have met the quality standards and they are ready for their registered workshop approval. They are looking forward to this legislation being passed so that they can get vehicles on the way. They want vehicles on the water in order to give employment to the employees in their workshop and sell really lovely motor vehicles to the Australian public.

This is good legislation. I am disappointed that the member for Batman had to try and take a cheap shot at both the minister and department officials, because it is a difficult issue to work through. It has caused some pain for some small businesses and it has caused some controversy in the industry because there are some operators who are still very unhappy with the proposals. I can say that honestly and truly, because it is so. There are others who would rather some of the issues in the proposals were different than they are but who are prepared to live with the new set of regulations and make them work.

One thing is for sure: we do not want, and I do not think any side of politics wants, to wind up with the New Zealand situation where we literally destroy our new-vehicle manufacturing industry by bringing in Japan's rejects which have been rejected through their regulations. That is not fair business; that is unfair business and unfair trading. We definitely do not want to replicate the New Zealand experience. We value our major motor car manufacturers.

We also, though, value small business, and people like Craig and Robyn Dean who have an excellent business are the kind of people that I support. I literally insist we must keep them in business; we must not regulate them out of business. I am pleased that they have now spent the money in order to meet the new ISO standards and that they are ready to comply with the regulations associated with being a registered workshop. They want vehicles on the water. They want vehicles in Australia so that they can start converting them and selling them. We can keep another small business alive and well in the Australian economy.

I congratulate the minister. I thank his departmental officials for all the hard yards that they put into the work on this particular measure over a long period of time and look forward to working with them as the regulations themselves are developed. I support the bill. I think it is a shame the member for Batman had to destroy his own arguments, if you will, for a pious amendment.

talk.start.para: âI want to speak to the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001 today in order to indicate, amongst other things, the problems that its passage, together with regulations which we have not yet seen, will create for segments of the small business sector in Australia. Like many people, I have received very strong representations from my own constituents, Western Australians, and from Queenslanders particularly indicating their dissatisfaction with the proposed regulations, although we have not seen those. Some constituents, as the previous speaker indicated, are unhappy with the entire bill, but most of them have said to me that they are happy with various elements of it. They are very concerned, however, that the way it has been introduced and the regulations as they appear to be proposed may well have very significant detrimental effects on their business.

speech.para: At the outset I would like to quote from a couple of people who I understand are here with us today: Brian and Ingrid Lynch of Trucks Plus. I am sure they have made representations to everybody in the parliament. They have been very energetic in their lobbying, as have various industry organisations. But I think we need to give a human face to these problems. In writing to me on at least one occasion, Brian and Ingrid Lynch said:

quote.para: As you are aware, this bill in its present form will put us out of business.

speech.para: That is pretty blunt and direct, but I understand that to be the case, not just for Trucks Plus but for others as well. Brian and Ingrid express the view that they are:

quote.para: ... very concerned that in the flurry leading up to the election we may see the bill rubber-stamped with other minor legislative change, thereby destroying our business and rendering our family savings valueless.

speech.para: I think that is something that has not been sufficiently taken into account. I appreciate what the previous speaker has said about some changes that have been made at his behest and at that of other backbenchers within the coalition parties, but they have still overlooked the needs of a significant proportion of the small business sector which is dealing with these motor vehicles. The coalition is apparently prepared to add to the growing list of unemployed that we have in our community. If I may just refer to that for a moment, this is in the context of very significant job losses in large and small businesses togetherâsome of them due to corporate failures; others to businesses having to significantly wind back their employment. Frankly, we can ill afford a piece of legislation which, while its intent is to protect our local manufacturersâsomething that I strongly supportâmay well have the effect of driving some of these people out of business without compensation, especially if the regulations are as proposed.

The government do not appear to have had a good look at that question and I am very concerned that they are not prepared to act, for instance, when we have seen so many jobs go. Yesterday we saw 1,000 go from Coles Myer. We saw the closure of Daimaru with the loss of a further 1,000 jobs. We saw that 1,400 are to go from One.Tel and 360 from Bradmill. Pasminco are in trouble. Harris Scarfe have dropped significant numbers of employees. There are also problems at Franklins, HIH Insurance, Diamond Press, Liberty One, Oakdale, Cobar, Braybrook, STP, Woodlawn, Merrywood, Exicom, National Textiles, Grafton and Scone meatworks, Parrish Meats and of course Ansett itself, with the follow-on effects that we are seeing around Australia at the moment.

I had the Parliamentary Library look at a number of companies that have gone completely belly up. This does not include the small business sector; these are just the larger corporations. We have a very sad list indeed from 1997: Gilbertson meatworks with 245 retrenched; St Andrew's hospitals in Rockhampton and Yeppoon, 157; CSA copper mine in Cobar, 270; Woodlawn, 154; Austral Pacific, 780; Roadmark, 30; and Oakdale, 127. These jobs all add up to a very substantial loss of high paid full-time employment in Australia, and I think it is time that the government, in looking at legislation of this kind, actually looked at the impact. One of the things that the government has not been prepared to do in industry policy generally is look at the impact where adjustment is being made, either because of standards changes or a desire to protect another area of industry. It is not apparently prepared to look at the cases of a number of small businesses that have made very clear the problems that they confront; yet they have been largely ignored in the way that this has been undertaken.

I am sure that most people, under circumstances where change is required, will accept compensation and will accept perhaps that things need to be done in a different way, but there needs to be fairness in all of this. The government simply announced the cancellation of import licences held by about, in this case, 100 small Queensland businesses, which entitled them to import 25 carsâor 4x4sâper year from Japan. These businesses, as Mr Lynch has pointed out to me, had invested their life savings to meet the federal government's licensing requirements and those of the transport department. The licences were issued for the life of the model, which in many cases was 2012, and investment costs, of course sensibly, were amortised over this period. The cancellation of those licences will mean financial ruin for many of these small family owned businesses, and I do not think that is stating it too highly.

I understand, particularly because as the shadow minister I have responsibility for industry, that we do need to protect our local manufacturers and our local jobs from imports but, in the scheme of things, these low volume importers are not the problem. The major loss to our domestic producers has been brought about by the significant increase in imports of the full volume. We have been losing our own market share here to new imported vehicles.
