I think that is a whole separate set of questions, and this one should not be confused with it. In my view these people, properly managed, do not represent a threat to the motor vehicle industry.

This bill makes significant changes to the regulatory regime for ensuring vehicle compliance with the Australian design rules and amends the operation of the low volume scheme, which is not in itself offensive. The scheme was introduced in 1970 to facilitate the issue of certificates of compliance to manufacturers who produced fewer than 50 vehicles each year of particular models of vehicles. The low volume scheme is one of a number of vehicle importation schemes. I mentioned oneâthe full volume schemeâand the personally imported vehicle scheme is another. The full volume scheme, of course, is used by major manufacturers for large volumes of standard vehicles, and the personal scheme enables migrants, Australian residents et cetera returning from overseas, to treat their vehicle as part of their personal effects. In essence, the low volume scheme allows alternative forms of evidence to determine compliance with the Australian design rules without requiring destructive or expensive testing, and that is the basis on which many people have made their investments.

Under the scheme as it exists, vehicles are required to comply with the rules that were in force at the date of original manufacture, and that is partly where these ground rules have been changed, rather than the current applicable design rules, and are exempted from the $12,000 duty on used passenger vehicles imported under the full volume scheme. These low volume concessions were designed to apply to the importation of specialist and enthusiast vehicles as the high relative cost of full volume certification, if spread over a small number of vehicles, clearly would make such low volume importation prohibitively expensive, which is really what is happening now. We are having costs added on that will make the businesses simply unviable.

On this basis, we can clearly see that the scheme was originally designed to ensure that low volume importers were not unfairly penalised in a financial sense when importing vehicles with a known or readily determined compliance. Again, that seems a very sensible thing to do. I know that the department and some others perhaps in the motor vehicle manufacturing sector were concerned about increases in the volume of vehicles coming in under this scheme. But in the scheme of things, that is really not the problem. It is under the full volume scheme that we have really sharp competition with local manufacturers.

However, having said that, if they were concerned about increases in the volumeâand I have put this to officers of the department, and indeed to othersâwhy did they not simply require all vehicles that are imported to come through a licensed motor vehicle dealer? I have not had a straight answer to that question and, frankly, it would have meant that a lot of the single permits that have been given would disappear. Small businesses like Trucks Plus could handle their volume sensibly with the regulations that we have required and the dodgy operatorsâthe ones who operate through advertisements in the local press and specialist second-hand motor vehicle dealers' organsâwould simply disappear. I still have not had a sensible response from the department to that proposal. I know that the licensing in that case devolves to the states, but it surely is possible for a federal government with any integrity to work with the states to get together a comprehensive scheme rather than go through the very expensive and, in a sense, arms-length operations now required by this legislation and by the regulations that we have not seen.

As the shadow minister for industry, I certainly think this is an unnecessarily complex set of procedures that has been gone through. There were, we know, operators in the field who were exploiting loopholes, but the department was the one issuing these single permit licencesâI am not quite sure of the exact description; I am sorryâand then they would turn up in the local motor trader and then they would do it again and again. There is plenty of evidence that that has occurredâwhereas if they were going through licensed motor vehicle dealers, who have to meet certain standards of safety and guarantee the quality of the work that is done there, the problem would have been solved. I still think that is one of the best ways of going about solving this problem. I am mightily puzzled that it has not been picked up by the government for reasons that I do not understand.

I am aware there are agreements about how long we are supposed to be speaking this morning because there is a volume of legislation before us, but I did want to make those points as this goes to a Senate committee. It is important for everyone here to recognise that, while we are certainly not objecting to this bill at this point, the Senate committee will have a capacity to examine carefully the real impact of these changes on the various businesses who have made representations to us. It is not reasonable to dismiss them as either being in a minority or not playing the game properly or not having a case to make. It is very clear to me they do have a reasonable case, that there are other ways of thinking about this and that a government that was committed to ensuring employment growth would be worried about the loss of a single job. The small business sector, as we know, is the driver of our economy and we cannot allow small businesses to simply be tossed aside as if they were of no relevance. We do need to have our own motor vehicle manufacturing sector and it needs to be strong and vibrant, but the real competition is coming from imports not under the low vehicle scheme but under other schemes. We need to set aside any ideology on this and sit down and work out a scheme that is comprehensive and fair. If people, having been given certain assurances over time about the viability of licences and agreements entered into, are put in a position where their business is going to be destroyed, then the government should look at appropriate compensation. To do less is really very unjust indeed.

talk.start.para: âThis Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001 is a matter which has been considered for a lengthy period by the government and one on which there has been extensive consultation with all sections of the industry. I was a little surprised to hear the spokesman for the opposition on industry matters not refer to the concerns that are being expressed by those great motor vehicle manufacturing industries which have been so concerned about the future for the Australian auto industry and the impact low volume imports are having on the vehicles manufactured here in Australia. That affects jobs and livelihoods of hundreds of families. It brings to mind the Button plan, where great concern was expressed by the Australian Labor Party about the future of employees in the Australian auto industry. It is obvious that the spokesman for the opposition has reacted to whatever comes across her desk rather than find out exactly what is going on in particular industries and delve deeply into the policy implications for the future of Australian industry, whether it be for low volume or for the manufacturing sector.

speech.para: For me, this is a matter that dates back to January 2000 when I received a letter from one of my constituents, John Penlington, who is the director of Unique Auto Sports. John operates a really good business in Castle Hill and has been there for a number of years. He wrote me a letter saying he was very worried about the future for his business and the prospect of being able to trade in unique autos. I quote part of the letter:

quote.para: I am a hard working honest Australian trying to have a go in small business. I have been involved in imported and selling imported cars for over four years in the Castle Hill area where I have lived since 1976.

speech.para: John is a well-known individual in the area and a well-known businessman. I went to see John and have a look at what he was doing. I was impressed by the conversions he was doing, the level of competence in his workshop and the style and finish of his product. I myself felt that this man seems to be providing something of a unique car, a car for enthusiasts, and something that would be in high demand.

This type of vehicle commands a considerable premium in the marketplace and, to my way of thinking, is unobtainable by any method other than by going to specialised dealers who directly import new vehicles or to those who do conversions of second-hand vehicles. I then started to pursue that with the government. The next person to contact me was Nathan Sawczak, who is also involved in the conversion of high quality vehicles for use by Australian purchasers.

In the meantime, I had the opportunity of visiting New Zealand and seeing what had happened to the car market there following the uninhibited import of second-hand cars. I saw pretty starkly the problems that would confront the Australian government as well. There is consumer demand for low cost second-hand vehicles unobtainable here in Australiaâvehicles which they feel are a great deal and would make good first cars for young drivers or be second family cars, vehicles which have a few miles on the clock but still have a bit of life in them, and vehicles which they feel, with some work and conversion, could be very suitable for use on Australian roads. That is the problem on the one hand.

On the other hand, there is the existing program that was put in place some years ago by the Australian government. That program seeks to allow enthusiasts and people who want cars that are unique or different to import those cars and to convert them, at their own expense, for use on Australian roads. So we have the upper end of the market with unique enthusiast vehicles and the lower end of the market with second-hand vehicles straight off Japanese streets.

I saw the damage that was done in New Zealand. I knew that we would not want to go in that direction. I do not think anybody has advanced the argument that we should. But where should we draw the line? The government has consulted with the industry. There have been many meetings with representatives of the converters, particularly AAIMA and other people involved in the industry. Those meetings have gone on over many hours. The government sought to allay the concerns of the manufacturers, who are very significant in Australian employment, Australian export drive and Australian productivity, and the concerns of consumers and businesses involved in conversions.

First of all, the government looked at the statistics. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the chart from the explanatory memorandum that sets out the statistics for the import of vehicles other than motorcycles under the low volume scheme.
Leave granted.
The table read as followsâ

quote.para: Used motor vehicles (except motorcycles) imported under the LVS by category.

talk.start.para: âI draw the attention of the chamber to the number of vehicles imported. In 1993 there were 992 vehicles and that rose to 10,094 in the year 2000. There was a low number of four-wheel drive vehicles in 1993âonly threeâand that rose to 5,705 in the year 2000. There were 35 light commercial vehicles in 1993 and that rose to 981 in the year 2000. The number of heavy commercial vehicles was low in each year, but fluctuated as people saw market opportunities. Total imports rose from 1,000 in 1993 to 16,800 in the year 2000. Having a huge increase in the number of vehicles entering Australia under the low volume schemeâfrom 1,000 to 16,800âwould be a concern to any government and any manufacturer.

speech.para: The process of analysing what was coming in, what they were being used for and what value they were in the marketplace was undertaken by the government. It was found that there was a wide range of vehicles but that there was a growing tendency for vehicles at the lower end of the range to be imported. From the consumer's point of view, there were advantages in price, but there was also some downside. The purchase of vehicles for which there is no guarantee of replacement parts or repair processes is one thing that has been raised by consumers. Complaints have come to members about vehicles being purchased which were supposed to have off the shelf parts and did not have off the shelf parts. Some consumers have had to wait long periods for special imports from Japan, where most of these vehicles were sourced. The safety and quality of tyres had also been raised by a number of consumers. Tyre types and Australian design rules are very critical for vehicle safety in Australia. There was a need for compliance with ADRs, Australian design rules, and there was a need to solve this problem of a rapidly expanding level of imports as compared with consumer demand and the interests of enthusiasts.

I believe the government has come forward with a scheme that is beneficial and workable. There were a number of options considered by the government: to keep the status quoâthat is, to retain the current type approval systemâto have a registered automotive workshop scheme or to go for self-regulation. It is interesting that the government has really limited the number of models by tightening the current eligibility criteria to ensure that the category is confined to specialist and enthusiast vehicles. I know this is going to cause pain in the industry. Where converters have gone into the Japanese market, they have certainly teed up sources of supply based on particular models that they have found in demand in Australia, and there will be some problems. But the government has sought to overcome those problems by allowing those who wish to establish a registered licensed workshop where the work can be undertaken to do so. They can go through a process of finding out what needs to be done to each model of vehicle as it comes in to equip it to conform with Australian design rules. I thought it was an extremely sensible and generous decision to have compliance with ADRs as of the date of manufacture rather than with current ADRs. It would have been impossible to make most of these vehicles comply with current ADRs, so the government set the target on the ADRs at the time the vehicles were manufactured. That is within this legislation.

I think it is very valuable to have the changes made on licensed premises so that there can be a reckoning on the type of vehicle that is being changed to Australian conditions, on the quality of the work and on the fact that there can be a chain back to the person performing the work. In addition to these things, there has been an extensive transition period to allow the industry to adjust. I know when I read the popular press that, on the one hand, there was a lot of scaremongering from those who were doing this type work, saying it was all gloom and doom and saying, `Things are going to be terrible. Ain't things crook?' On the other hand, there were the claims made by the current manufacturers that it would mean the loss of jobs and that sort of thing. I think the government has chosen the right answer. It has not been done without consideration of and care for the needs of everybody involved. If you watched the progress of this low volume vehicle import system, it was obvious that it was expanding into areas that it should not have been expanding into. People were starting to import vehicles that were not of the type originally envisaged. The scheme had been extended by model type and quality to the point where it was starting to mirror what had occurred in New Zealand, and it was not the intention of this government to go in that direction.

We value the Australian manufacturing industries. Whilst we value the small businesses that have taken advantage, over a comparatively short time of five or six years, to move into this market, I think that the longer lasting and permanent need for a manufacturing industry in Australia weighs very heavily on the Australian government. There are two factors here. The balance is right. There is a transition period; there is a proper process of licensing and registration. I believe that there is a process whereby smaller converters can still import, have somebody do the work for them andâdespite their claims that it would be unprofitableâgo on to supply their current markets. I have great pleasure in supporting this legislation. It has not been easy for the government but I think the decision is the right one.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001 because of the importance of the motor vehicle industry to my electorate. As members may know, my electorate is home to Toyota. The plant at Altona in my electorate is where Toyota consolidated all of its Australian manufacturing operations in 1994 and 1995. The plant is worth some $420 million. It is world class in efficiency in manufacturing and in the use of technology and processes. Particularly pleasing for the local community is the fact that the plant is a leader in environmental technology, so the environmental issues generated for the local community that lives in and around the plant have been minimised as a result of the technical processes that Toyota has adopted.

speech.para: Toyota is a major employer across Australia generally and particularly in my electorate. The livelihood of over 4,000 Australians depends upon Toyota, and approximately 2,400 of those people work at the Altona plant. Clearly, many of them live locally in my electorate and throughout the western suburbs of Melbourne. It was, therefore, of concern to me and to my electorate that it appeared that the low volume scheme was no longer being used for its original purpose of facilitating the importation of low numbers of specialist and enthusiast vehicles.

As I am sure members are probably aware, there are three schemes of arrangements applying to the importation of motor vehicles. The first is the full volume scheme used by major manufacturers for large volumes of standard vehicles. Such vehicles are required to meet all currently applicable Australian design rules based on type approvals. After extensive, expensiveâand what can be destructiveâtesting, an approval is granted for a particular type of motor vehicle. The second is the personally imported vehicle scheme, which allows migrants and Australian residents returning from overseas to treat their vehicle as part of their personal effects. Obviously, by the very nature of that scheme, it deals with a very small number of vehicles.

Thirdly, there is the low volume scheme which is the subject of this bill. The low volume scheme allows an alternative form of evidence of compliance with many of the Australian design rules so that the extensive, expensive and destructive testing, to which I referred, is not required. In addition, vehicles are required to comply only with the Australian design rules in force at the time of the vehicle's original manufacture rather than the rules currently applying.

Finally, and probably most important of all, there is an exemption from the $12,000 special duty on used passenger motor vehicles which applies if they are imported under the full volume scheme. There is a $12,000 duty difference. Clearly this concession on duty would not have been a significant problem for the industry domestically if the low volume scheme had genuinely been confined to specialist vehicles and to those who wanted to import Cadillacs or Buicks or some sort of specialist or enthusiast vehicle. However, as the number of vehicles imported under these arrangements shows, increasingly the low volume scheme has been used as a mechanism for importing slightly used Japanese motor vehicles identical in type to full volume scheme imported models. However, such vehicles are at a significant competitive advantage because the $12,000 duty does not apply. This is also a problem for the domestic car industry, given such vehicles have the cost advantages of being free from that duty, slightly used, not needing to comply with Australian design rules and not needing to supply after-sales service and maintenance.

The issue of the increasing numbers of low volume scheme imported vehicles was first raised with me by Toyota as a domestic manufacturer, but it was next raised with me by a local car dealership, Rick Wolany motors. The Rick Wolany company is a major car dealership in the city of Wyndham, which forms part of my electorate, and is a considerable contributor to community events and functions. I will read to the House the letter he sent to me in which he raised this issue. It dates way back to 6 September 1999, which perhaps indicates how long this has been a problem and how long the bill that is before us has been in generation. He writes:

quote.para: A recently completed report on the subject of used vehicle imports is due to be submitted to the Transport Minister, Mr John Anderson, for consideration. This will then be followed by discussion in Cabinet and the Party in general.

Being a Multi-Franchise motor vehicle dealership, it is a great concern to me that the increasing importation of used motor vehicles continues to grow unchecked. As one of the largest private employers in this City, I feel I must protest at the potential disaster, imported vehicles will have on the future growth of my Company.

If growth continues at this rate it runs the risk of undermining new vehicle sales in Australia which in turn will impact on Australian produced vehicles. Rick Wolany Toyota, Daewoo, Suzuki and Lexus of Wyndham has invested millions of dollars into the Wyndham Community and continues to offer the highest standard of after sales service and of course the appropriate parts and accessory support. Used vehicle importers usually cannot and will not supply this support.

In most cases imported motor vehicles are only available due to very restrictive safety requirements for Japanese used motor vehicles. In turn they only have to supply reduced evidence of compliance with Australian Design Rules for this to conform.

The above concerns are a sample of what may happen if imported vehicles continue to grow at this unprecedented rate. Julia, I would appreciate the opportunity to meet with you at your earliest convenience to discuss this important subject.

speech.para: Having received that correspondence, I did meet with Rick Wolany. To give a very clear example of the sort of problem that was starting to occur through the low volume scheme, Rick, who deals in Lexus motor vehiclesâwhich, as we all know, are quite luxurious and expensive motor vehicles in terms of what is on the marketâwas able to point to the identical motor vehicle being imported as a used motor vehicle from Japan under the low volume scheme. So Rick Wolany, as a dealer, is trying to sell Lexus motor vehicles to a certain segment of the market that is interested in a car of that quality and of that luxury type, but is finding that the identical vehicle, slightly used, could be imported under the low volume scheme and not attract the $12,000 duty.

That probably indicates the sorts of problems and pressure that motor vehicle dealerships were facing as a result of the expansion of what historically has been a scheme for the importation of specialist vehicles and those for enthusiasts. Mr Wolany's market experience in terms of the city of Wyndham is bolstered, I suppose, when you look at the overall statistics. He was able to recount his experiences anecdotally, but if we look at the figures, we do find a very big increase in the number of vehicles being imported under this schemeâfrom 1,000 in 1993 to 16,825 in the year 2000.

The bill that is before us today represents the government's endeavour to deal with this problem and to try to get the scheme back to what it was originally designed forâthat is, allowing the importation of very small classes and particular types of vehicles. The numbers were not supposed to expand to the point where we were dealing with issues like identical vehicles being imported from overseas as slightly used vehicles, thus not having the duty imposed.

Clearly, the bill before us now has been a long time in generation. I think there are some issues, given that this is framework legislation, about where we will end up in terms of the regulations. To quote a phrase, `the devil is often in the detail,' and the regulations will be a very important component of how this scheme actually works and operates within the Australian market. I am therefore very supportive of this bill going to a Senate committee for further consideration and examination at the time that the regulations are available in draft, and of the whole schemeâboth the framework legislation and the relevant regulationsâbeing looked at to see whether or not it achieves the purposes which the government set out when drafting this bill.

I think that process is a very important one. Clearly there is an issue of balance here: balance with the domestic motor vehicle industry, balance with our domestic dealerships like Rick Wolany and balance in terms of allowing importation of specialist and enthusiast motor vehicles. There is also an issue of fairness in terms of the industry that has grown up around that. I think those things are best addressed in a further look at this bill and its regulations in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI wanted to say a few words on the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001, because, although most industry groups agree that there need to be tighter controls on the low volume imports, I think some of the measures proposed by the Department of Transport and Regional Services were unduly harsh on those in the industry who have operated within the law and have long-term interests in converting low volume vehicles. In 1998, when the Motor Vehicle Standards Act review took place, this industry comprised between 500 and 600 compliance plate holders. It involved about 1,500 small businesses, employing somewhere in the order of 5,000 people and its value to the national economy was around $350 million a year. It was not a big industry and it was highly specialised, but it was meeting an important consumer demand within the marketplace.

speech.para: My concern about the bill was based on the fact that previous legislation had been passed. One of my Western Australian businesspeople was a low volume importer. He and his family had invested about $1 million in his businessâand that was a forward investment that would normally be amortised over a five- to seven-year period. With the bringing down of this legislation, he is unable to retrieve that forward investment, and that is a major concern for that particular individual. It was on his behalf that I made representations to approach the changes in this sector in such a way as to allow long-term low volume operators to recoup the money they had invested on the basis of previous legislation and to allow an orderly transition from one system to another, recognising the reality that change had to take place. Nevertheless, I believe our small businesses should be given time to work through the new system. We were given a two-year transition period, and I will address that in a moment.

The main drivers of the legislation have been the new-car manufacturers, who maintain that the floodgates were open and that thousands of cars were pouring into the Australian market and creating unfair competition for cars manufactured in Australia. I think sometimes we forget, when the new-car manufacturers make this claim, that they are still the beneficiaries of a tariff barrier, which is worth somewhere in the order of $3 billion a year to new-car manufacturing in this country.

One of the claims being made was that the four-wheel drive industry was particularly at risk from imports. It is a curious thing, because there were no diesel four-wheel drive vehicles being manufactured in Australia. The fact is that farmers, miners and those working in rural and remote areas of Australia wanted diesel four-wheel drives because of the extra power that those vehicles could provide, and the low volume dealers were meeting a demand that the new-vehicle industry did not choose to meet. It is therefore difficult to justify the exclusion of diesel four-wheel drives from the low volume scheme.

This scheme has already had quite an impact on that Western Australian businessman in my electorate, and he employs his brother, his son and his nephew in his business. At a time when he should be able to think about retiring because he is getting on in years, he has just seen a million dollar investment wiped out. I do not disagree with the proposition from the government that we need to look after our new-car manufacturers because it is an important industry, but if we are going to change the original intent of some legislation, then we must ensure a fair transitional arrangement.

I agree with my colleague the member for La Trobe when he said that we must keep small businesses in business, not regulate them out of business. That is why I took up this issue: essentially I want a fair outcome for the new-car manufacturers and for small businesses. I note that the motor vehicle review report recommended option 2, which was to retain the current criteria with clearer working guidelines. We have moved to option 1. I think, even using option 1, we could still work within the scope of option 1 in a way that allowed an orderly transition. We still have that ability within the regulations to make sure that it is an orderly transition and that we do not create a problem for this group of business people.

New-vehicle manufacture is an important industry to Australia. No-one denies that, and it is a great generator of jobs and opportunities for Australian workers. I value the new-car dealerships in my electorate; I have a good many of them. They are an important industry, and they are good community citizens. However, I believe that there is room for both industries. It is important to understand that, according to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act, the low volume industry supplied only a fraction of the car sales market in Australia. In fact, it was estimated by one group to be as little as 0.45 per cent of the total car sales in Australia.

In fact, the review report noted the rapid increase in the numbers of imported used motor vehicles over the last three years, but considers that they are small compared with that of new vehicle sales. They were also unable to quantify in that review task force the impact of low volume used vehicles on either safety or the environment. It is not to say that there are not some bad practices, because there are, and that is acknowledged by all sides of the industry. However, I want to make the point that many of these imported cars come from countries that have much stricter emission laws and much stricter safety laws than we have in this country. So we have to be careful about broadly using that argument. There are exceptions to that, but I believe that could have been dealt with in the way in which the department monitored the import of these vehicles.

The industry has been right to call for proper controls to protect Australian buyers, and that is supported by the low volume industry organisations. However, it is important to note that in the Motor Vehicle Standards Act review the observation was made by the task force that the industry policy is more sensitive to increasing numbers of imported used vehicles, rather than the safety and emission aims of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. My contention is that these issues can be dealt with without making regulations so harsh that it puts decent people out of business. As I said, early in the review task force they formed the view that the intertwining of industry policy and uniform vehicle standards in the operation of the low volume scheme under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act was the major cause for the administrative problems engendered by the scheme. So I think there was an acknowledgment that there were problems there, but they can still be resolved in a way that looks after both industries.

I support the move to the registered workshops and to the ISO accreditation standards and to generally improve the practice standards of the industry. But if the regulations are too harsh, it looks more like a way of protecting the new-car manufacturing industry instead of looking after the safety and protection of consumers. My involvement from the start of this process has been to work with the new-car manufacturers and their representatives, and the representatives of organisations looking after the low volume industry, in an endeavour to achieve a fair outcome for everyone, and I believe that is achievable.

Last year I convened a meeting in Adelaide to bring together some of the new-vehicle manufacturers and the low volume industry. I thought we had a very constructive meeting. But then it goes back and it gets off the rails again. One of the main representative groups, VICAA, has worked constructively and tirelessly with the government and industry to achieve a fair outcome. This is a small organisation. It is bit of a David against Goliath, I have to say. It has worked very hard and I have been grateful for the assistance of Jack Vanstone and Joanna Easterbrook of that organisation. It is very important that we understand the impact of legislation on everyone in the industry, not just one side of the industry. This consultation process and this representation by a small industry organisation has been a very important part of achieving sound legislative outcomes in this place. We cannot do it unless we do look at these issues objectively.

The matter is now before a Senate committee. I am confident that, after taking evidence from all parties, the Senate committee will make some sensible recommendations in relation to the regulations that will follow and the passing of this bill. That is imperative because, from the start, some of the regulations proposed in the draft were unnecessarily harsh on the longstanding businesses in the low volume industry. This industry was to be given a two-year transition period. More than half of that period has now expired and the industry still does not have the detail of what the new regulations will be. It is very hard to make that transition when you do not have those details. Just a week ago when I made inquiries, there was no application form available for the registered automotive workshop scheme, for example. The evidence package is still only in draft form with several contentious issues not clarified. The definition of `fit and proper person' was proposing to make people go back and do a TAFE course. This is unrealistic for those who have been doing conversions for many years, like the person in Western Australia who has been in this industry for 30 years, has a clean record, has been doing the right thing and does a good job. Why should he go back and do a TAFE course in mechanics when he has already proven his ability and competency? The business rules are still only in draft form with contentious issues still to be determined. There are still grave concerns about the costs to the industry that may be imposed on the low volume importers under the new legislation.

I was very pleased when I saw this piece of legislation go before a Senate committee to be scrutinised. I appreciate that those senators have spent many hours taking evidence and deliberating on the detail of the regulations. I am supporting the passage of this legislation through this place today because I am confident that the recommendations made by the Senate committee will be taken into account in the regulations, and will bring about important changes to support small businesses that rely on low volume importing to keep their businesses operating. As I said, there is room for both industries in this country. If we proceed with sensible legislation, this industry will not have a detrimental effect on new-car manufacturing in Australia.

talk.start.para: âBefore I call the next speaker I wish to remind the Main Committee that it is intended that we should adjourn at 1.30 p.m. There are still two other pieces of legislation which I hope will be dealt with. I seek the cooperation of all members.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âI am summing up on behalf of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and our Deputy Prime Minister. There are three main amendments to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 in the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 2001. The first of the amendments to the act will allow for determinations to be made for the placement of used import plates on imported vehicles. The second is the set of amendments to the act that will allow the minister to keep a register of specialist and enthusiast vehicles. The third amendment provides for corporations to apply for approval as registered automotive workshops with set guidelines to determine the `fit and proper person' status of applicants.

speech.para: In addition, there are new offence provisions in relation to the manufacture, supply or placement of a used import plate or the breaching of a condition of an approval or the use of a false plate, that is, without approval. The bill also sets out the transitional arrangements for dealing with approvals granted under the current arrangements.

The bill will enable implementation of the government's decision announced on 8 May 2000 in relation to new arrangements to administer the importation of used vehicles. In view of the time and your comments, I have kept my comments as brief as possible. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âI thank the minister. The original question was that the bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Batman has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by Miss Jackie Kelly:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI listened very carefully to your appeal, Mr Deputy Speaker, to members to keep their contributions very short. I am happy to accommodate you on that. The opposition will be taking a bipartisan approach to this Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill 2001 and therefore will be supporting it. We are satisfied that the bill contains provisions designed to balance the rights given to the AOC and the interest of third parties with a legitimate claim to use these expressions. No doubt the shadow minister for sport, Senator Kate Lundy, will give a more detailed response when the bill reaches the Senate. I reiterate that the opposition is happy to lend its support to the bill.

âI realise that we have a very heavy legislative program today so I will keep my comments brief as well. I rise to support the Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill 2001. It was this time 12 months ago that we had the Sydney Olympics, and all of Australia was in a euphoric state watching a magnificent event. It was a huge industry and it still is, worldwide, and it is amazing the difference that a year has made to the feeling within the community. It was certainly a great tribute. It is important that this bill is passed because it amends the Olympic Insignia Protection Act 1987 to grant the Australian Olympic Committee ongoing protection for the expressions `Olympic', `Olympic Games' and `Olympiad' from unauthorised commercial use for promotion or advertising purposes. This will ensure an income stream for the Australian Olympic Committee and will further protect its rights on those insignia and on those words. Those few remarks conclude what I want to say about the bill.

speech.para: This might be my last chance in this parliament to speak in the Main Committee whilst you are in the chair, Deputy Speaker Nehl. I congratulate you for the work you have done in the Main Committee as the Deputy Speaker and I wish you a long and happy retirement at the conclusion of this parliament.
Honourable membersâHear, hear!

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âI thank the honourable member for Robertson.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism

talk.start.para: âin replyâIn summing up the second reading debate on the Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill 2001, I note that it has the support of the opposition. I thank the member for Robertson for his kind words on this bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would also like to endorse his comments on your tenure as Deputy Speaker. I would like Hansard to record my regret at your retirement after the coming election.

speech.para: This bill is evidence of our further support for sport. The bill allows the Australian Olympic Committee to undertake its own fundraising efforts which will complement what the government is already doing in a substantial way and will ensure that Australia remains at the forefront of sport. It complements our sporting policies to date. In this International Year of the VolunteerâI always hate to see sport miss outâI note that volunteers are an important part of our sporting arenas. This bill represents a good balance which will enable better support for all of our Australian Olympic teams in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION APPLICATION CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition has absolutely no objection to the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Amendment Bill 2001. It is a triumph of bipartisanship. It reflects the fact that the migration agents scheme does require funding to operate effectively. If I might make one small criticism, we have been aware for some time that the enforcement powers of the migration agents board do not seem adequate to deal with some of the abuses that seemingly occur within that area. These are issues that I am sure have been conveyed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. When I was the shadow minister for immigration, they were the subject of discussions between us. In the absence of my colleague the shadow minister for immigration, the Hon. Con Sciacca, who is currently receiving urgent dental treatment, I am pleased to commend the bill on behalf of the opposition.

speech.para: I also want to thank you for your service to the House, Mr Deputy Speaker. This may be the last occasion when the Main Committee sits before the end of this parliamentary session. It has been your special responsibility, I understand, to chair this chamber. It has been a worthwhile innovation in the parliamentary process because it enables the passage of non-contentious legislation. I wish you the best for the future, as I do to all departing members of this House. I commend the legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âI thank the member for Denison.
âMr Deputy Speaker, like my colleagues, I would also like to wish you the best for your retirement.
(Mr Nehl)âThere is still tomorrow.

âThere is still tomorrow. When you leave this House you will be sorely missed. I would also like to commend the government on the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Amendment Bill 2001 and commend the member for Denison for the bipartisan support we have for the bill. The purpose of the amendment is to increase the migration agents registration application charge limit. The charge payable by migration agents for registration will now not exceed $1,800 for those agents seeking registration from 1 July 2001. A migration agent is an individual who uses their knowledge and experience of migration procedure to give what is defined in the Migration Act 1958 as immigration assistance.

speech.para: I know through my own electorate office the number of inquiries that members get on immigration. A migration agent plays a very important part in being able to give advice, if it is needed, on sometimes very complex application forms needed under our migration legislation to enter our country. I would like to say that I do agree with the bill. Migration agents must be registered and must have demonstrated that they do have the necessary skills and expertise to give migration advice. To apply for registration as a migration agent, a person must pay the relevant application charge as set out in the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Regulations 1998. This amendment will enable future increases in registration application charges where appropriate. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I rise very briefly to support the remarks of the member for Robertson and other opposition and House of Representatives members on your long and outstanding service to the Australian parliament, to the House of Representatives and to this Main Committee. May you have a long, prosperous and happy retirement.
(Mr Nehl)âI thank the honourable member for La Trobe.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Denison, as shadow minister representing his colleague the member for Bowman, for his contribution to the debate on the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Amendment Bill 2001. I thank him for the support for the bill. I thank the members for McPherson and La Trobe for their supportive remarks.

speech.para: This bill does increase the charge limit for registration of applications by migration agents for their continuing entitlement to practise in this area. Under the legislation, the charge imposed on an individual who applies to the Migration Registration Authority to be registered as an agent can be varied in regulations. This bill, therefore, does not increase the actual amount charged. It lifts the upper limit to which the charges can be increased. It provides flexibility to ensure that the authority has adequate resources to carry out its statutory responsibilities.

I do have some concerns about the extent to which unmeritorious matters are pursued at times to achieve what members of the legal profession advise us are entitlements that are pressed for an opportunity to remain in Australia when there is no proper basis for such claims to be pressed and the only objective of pursuing the matter is to obtain extra time. Extra time is often sought to enable some people to continue to remain here and to work either lawfully or unlawfully in Australia. I think that is clearly an abuse of process.

Some of my friends in the legal profession think that, if we leave gaps whereby people are entitled to get bridging visas, they are entitled to exploit them. Over a period of time I have said to migration agents that I think they have some overriding responsibilities to the nation in much the same way as members of the legal profession often assert that they have an overriding responsibility to the courts and fellow practitioners as well as their clients. We do need to be looking for ways in which we can develop a more ethical approach to dealing with these issues. It is highly questionable whether we are able to do it under the existing arrangements. As we have sought to protect people from administrative decisions, we have built in very significant checks and balances which are exploited again by migration agents, who are entitled to appeal decisions taken in relation to their entitlements to practise.

talk.start.para: âThe vast majority are reputable.

âI do not dispute that. The point always is to find ways and means of being able to deal with the dishonourable and to do so effectively. I make this undertaking to the opposition that I will constructively look at any proposals that you are able to bring forward and I will continue to look at ways and means in which I can of my own initiative deal with these issues, because it remains a matter of continuing concern to me. I thank honourable members for their support for the bill.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I have known you for a long time. I do not feel like it is goodbye. I am sure you will continue to play a very significant role in public life and in your community. We will no doubt see you from time to time at the many events and activities that bring former members to the parliament. I have enjoyed my friendship with you and I wish you well in your well-earned retirement. Thank you very much.

talk.start.para: âWe'll miss the kilt, not the legs.
âYou will miss his very assertive and effective leadership from the chair. I commend you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I do this bill, to the chamber.
(Mr Nehl)âI thank the minister and the committee.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 December 2000:

question.para: (1) With respect to the obligations placed upon the Certificate of Registration holder for aircraft, how many instances in 2000 has the Civil Aviation Safety Authority been aware of where an aircraft owner has failed to pass on maintenance information to an operator, lessor or maintenance organisation.
(2) Of those cases, how many owners were (a) investigated and (b) prosecuted, and what was the outcome of those investigations and prosecutions.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised the following:

(1) and (2) CASA is unable to provide the number of instances in 2000 in which the Authority became aware that an aircraft owner has failed to pass on maintenance information to an operator, lessor or maintenance organisation. Failure by an aircraft owner to pass on safety information to an operator, lessor or maintenance organisation is not an offence under the current regulations. In many instances this information was passed to the Authority anecdotally and consequently CASA does not have records.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

question.para: (1) In response to a call regarding the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme does he recall saying on Brisbane talk back radio on Tuesday, 20 March 2001, that aspects of it are under review; if not, why not.

(2) If aspects of the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme are under review, can he detail (a) which aspects are under review, (b) who is conducting the review, (c) when the review is expected to be completed and (d) whether the results of the review will be made public; if so, when they will be made public; if not, why not.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The government reviewed the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme. As a result of the review, the Minister for Finance and Administration introduced the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme Amendment Bill 2001. The Bill received Royal Assent on 18 July 2001.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 25 June 2001:

question.para: (1) Did the Australian Federal Police (AFP) conduct re-profiling processes in approximately 1998 with a view to paying out those members considered unsuitable; if so, was Federal Agent (F/A) Francis Day nominated for re-profiling by any AFP member.
(2) Was the re-profiling process conducted in an unbiased and non-discriminatory manner.
(3) Did Mr Day nominate for re-profiling and was advised by the then General Manager of Northern, F/A Keelty, that he was disappointed with Mr Day's decision as Mr Day was regarded as an asset.

(4) Was Mr Day advised approximately 1 and a half years after the re-profiling process by the new General Manager of Northern, F/A Overland, that his contract was not to be renewed due to concerns covering a period of 4 years.
(5) Is the Minister taking action in relation to Mr Day being told he had a future in the AFP and not being advised to the contrary until the non-renewal of his contract; if so, what.

(6) Will the Minister investigate and take action in relation to the failure of F/A Overland to nominate Mr Day for re-profiling, including the failure to provide Mr Day with counselling and remedial training, as required in the case of a staff member's work standard being found to be unacceptable; if so, what.
(7) Did F/A Overland allow Mr Day's alleged poor performance to continue unabated for 4 years.

(8) In the report prepared by F/A Overland recommending the non-renewal of the contract, are there references to F/A Overland having spoken to Mr Day during the preceding 4 years or providing counselling, remedial training or disciplinary action to Mr Day; if not, why not.
(9) Did F/A Overland take any disciplinary action against Mr Day over this period.
(10) Is there any official record of F/A Overland's concern on Mr Day's PMP; if not, will the Minister investigate why not.
(11) Was Mr Day's PMP signed by his Team Leader and Director as meeting the standard; if so, will the Minister investigate why.
(12) Was Mr Day made aware of F/A Overland's concerns and given an opportunity to address alleged shortcomings.

(13) In light of the above, has the AFP failed in its duty to undertake the requisite action of providing remedial training, counselling, disciplinary action or dismissal; if so, what action is the Minister taking in relation to this.
(14) Will the Minister investigate why F/A Overland failed to advise Mr Day's Team Leader and Directors of his concern.
(15) Has any action been taken in relation to F/A Keelty or Mr Day's Team Leader or Directors, given the allegations about Mr Day.
(16) Is Mr Day the only person to have been disciplined in regard to this contradiction and failure of management to carry out its duty in relation to Mr Day's performance.

(17) Did the Review Panel for Mr Day's case have conditions which included that (a) Mr Day would not be allowed to speak except to answer questions, (b) Mr Day's accusers would not be attending the Review Panel and would not therefore have to answer questions from either Mr Day or the Review Panel and (c) Mr Day be denied legal representation; if so, are these conditions in line with government policy and natural justice afforded all employees.

(18) Did F/A Overland declare on 17 November 1999 in an email regarding the non-renewal of contracts to all members of Northern Region that he had spoken to all the people in the workplace who he intended to speak to as part of the process, and that this was a one off action and would not be repeated.
(19) Will the Minister investigate why Mr Day was not notified of his contract non-renewal status until 1400 hrs on 19 November 1999.

(20) Is the Minister aware that Mr Day was misled by the statement made on 17 November 1999 and of the distress this has caused Mr Day's family and himself, and which has been further compounded by the failure of F/A Overland to reply to requests for a response since 19 January 2000.
(21) Is the Minister aware that Mr Day has tried on many occasions in the past 2 years to obtain a response to this matter from the AFP.
(22) Was Minister Vanstone, when Minister of Justice and Customs, advised by the AFP that information provided by Mr Day had been reviewed by the Review Panel.
(23) Is the Minister aware of an interview that was instigated by F/A Overland prior to the Review Panel reviewing Mr Day's case in response to Mr Day's report.
(24) Will the Minister investigate statements allegedly made by F/A Overland at this meeting, concerning F/A Overland's unwillingness to provide written responses.
(25) Will the Minister investigate whether the AFP denied Mr Day the opportunity to properly defend himself against the allegations by denying him the right to speak at the Review Board hearing.
(26) Does the Minister condone such procedures conducted by the AFP in this matter.
(27) Will the Minister investigate how a review can be conducted when the relevant persons do not have to appear before the Review Panel.
(28) Was the information supplied to the Minister not made available to the Review Panel as claimed by the AFP.
(29) Will the Minister investigate why the Commissioner of the AFP has refused to grant Mr Day an appointment to discuss his report.
(30) Have some of those members re-profiled as being unsuitable for continued employment with the AFP been employed by the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland.

(31) Will the Minister investigate why numerous members of the AFP were paid out under S26E before and after the non renewal of contract period commenced, when the more appropriate action would be to allow their contract to expire or simply stand them down in the interim period as with other members.
(32) Was F/A Overland responsible for two members receiving S26E action for poor performance issues at the time Mr Day was advised of the non-renewal of his contract.

(33) Was the AFP responsible for a least 10 other members receiving 26E or other pay outs for poor performance in the few months just after the non renewal of contract action; if so, what action is the Minister taking in relation to this matter.
(34) Will the Minister investigate why F/A McKnight was allegedly observing Mr Day whose work station was located three floors above his own office and who was assigned to another department.
(35) Will the Minister investigate why F/A McKnight during this supervision of Mr Day did not discipline Mr Day at the time of his observations, nor provide counselling or remedial training.

(36) Will the Minister investigate the period of 5 weeks during which Mr Day was transferred to F/A McKnight's department and how F/A McKnight was able to make a reliable observation of Mr Day given the logistic impossibility to conduct such observations.

(37) Will the Minister investigate how it was possible for Mr Day to pass his evaluation assessments during the 18 months F/A McKnight allegedly observed Mr Day in another department given his stated concerns.
(38) Did the report submitted by F/A McKnight contain any indication that Mr Day was made aware of any performance problem prior to the report.
(39) Was Mr Day's treatment during this process in accordance with departmental guidelines.
(40) Was feedback not given to Mr Day prior to the Review Board which impeded his ability to defend his position.

(41) Did the AFP advise that the Review Panel had investigated all matters raised by Mr Day; if so, will the Minister provide a detailed account of the investigations conducted by the Review Panel, such as the interviewing of relevant personal, reviewing of files, resources allocated and Mr Day's personnel record; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In 1998 the Australian Federal Police (AFP) set in train a strategy to re-skill the organisation, particularly in the areas of computer and communications crime and forensic accounting. This program included the targeted early cessation of personnel who were assessed as being unable to adapt effectively in the present and emerging work environment, or unable to be retained for the new and emerging roles in the national teams work environment. The number of people included in the re-profiling program was governed by the $3.5 m set aside to fund it. Federal Agent Francis Day was not nominated for re-profiling by another member but he made an application on his own behalf.
(2) to (41) The remaining questions address issues surrounding the internal employment regime of the AFP particularly in respect of the employment of Mr Day.

At the relevant time, employment in the AFP was governed by the provisions of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (the Act) and regulations made under the Act. Employment decisions made under the Act may be reviewed under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

The Minister for Justice and Customs has no role in the internal employment processes of the AFP. In particular, the Minister does not review employment decisions. The Minister will not investigate the matters raised in the question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 28 June 2001:

question.para: (1) How many Australian Protective Service (APS) officers were deployed for Operation Mandalay to Port Hedland on 25 May 2001.
(2) How long did the officers remain in Port Hedland.
(3) How much notice were the officers given.
(4) For how many officers did this deployment constitute a change of shift.
(5) Under the Public Service Award 1998, are APS offices entitled to payment of penalties for a change of shift without the required 7 days notice.
(6) How many officers have been paid this entitlement.
(7) Who made the decision regarding the payment or non-payment of these entitlements.
(8) On what grounds was such a decision made.
(9) Was there any discussion with the officers regarding shift changes or entitlements for Operation Mandalay before the deployment.
(10) Did any officers waive the 7 days' notice of shift change provision; if so, (a) how many officers did so and (b) were these recorded in writing.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Twenty Australian Protective Service (APS) Officers were deployed for Operation Mandalay to Port Hedland on 25 May 2001.
(2) The APS officers departed Canberra at 0100hrs on Friday 25 May and returned to Canberra on the 3 June 2001. The OIC of the contingent returned to Canberra on 6 June 2001.
(3) The APS officers were notified 29 hours prior to departure.
(4) The deployment would have constituted a change of shift for 17 APS officers, if mutual consent to waive the change of shift allowance had not been achieved.

(5) Under the Public Service Award 1998, APS officers may be entitled to payment of penalties for a change of shift without the required 7 days notice depending on the circumstance of each case. The payment may be waived by mutual consent.
(6) No APS officers involved in Operation Mandalay have been paid this entitlement. It was waived by mutual consent.
(7) The officers involved in Operation Mandalay made the decision to waive the payment by mutual consent with the delegate, Director APS.

(8) The decision was made on the grounds that the APS received only 30 hours notice of the deployment. Volunteers were sought and were asked to waive the payment in lieu of shift change because of the short notice received by the APS. They each individually agreed to waive any payment that may or may not have been due under the APS Award 1998 (as varied from time to time).
(9) Discussions occurred on the 24 May 2001 with the staff. It was on this day that they were advised they would not be paid an allowance for change of shift without 7 days notice.
(10) All officers waived the 7 days' notice of shift change provision, none of these waivers were recorded in writing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 June 2001:

question.para: (1) Has he seen a New Scientist report of 16 June 2001 titled Feeling Lucky dealing with a NASA-commissioned study claiming that military aircraft are now much safer than 20 years ago while the same affordable technology is yet to be made available to commercial airlines.

(2) Is he aware of the results of the NASA-commissioned study into the crashworthiness of commercial aircraft, completed in February last year by crash consultancy Simula Technologies in Phoenix, Arizona.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the claim in the New Scientist report that four out of five airline crashes occur during take off and landing, at relatively low speed and could be largely survivable by passengers if certain practical modifications are made to the structure, floor, seats, fuel system and interior fittings of aircraft.

(4) With the current large purchases of domestic aircraft now being made by the Australian aviation industry, what requirements is he imposing on airline companies to require them to order aircraft with modern safety design features and fittings.
(5) Will these aircraft be required to have strengthened overhead lockers to prevent loose objects being flung about the cabin in the event of a crash.
(6) Will these aircraft be fitted with strengthened shock absorbing seats that are able to protect passengers from the forces generated during a crash.
(7) Will these aircraft be fitted with seats with three point harnesses that hold passengers firmly in their seats in the event of a crash.
(8) Will these aircraft be fitted with strengthened floors that hold the seats in place during a crash.
(9) Will these aircraft be fitted with foam filled cells in the underbody of the aircraft that protect passengers by absorbing the energy of a crash.
(10) Will these aircraft be fitted with valves that automatically shut off fuel-flow if the wings break off during a crash.
(11) Will the Government ensure the introduction of improved airline safety initiatives as outlined in parts (4) to (10) of this question; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I am aware of the The New Scientist report and its contents.

(3) With regard to the New Scientist report claim that four out of five airline accidents occur during take-off and landing, I have been advised that, according to a US National Transportation Safety Board Safety Report, 80% of all transport aircraft accidents which occurred between 1983 and 2000 were survivable.

It is important to note that in Australia, accident statistics for this type of activity are extremely low. For example, from 1 January 1980 to 30 June 2001, only two fatal accidents have occurred during take off, while none have occurred during landing. Of the 105 transport aircraft accidents recorded on the Australian Transport Safety Bureau's (ATSB) safety database, which have occurred in Australia during that same period, 5.7% (or 6 in total) have been fatal (Source: ATSB). However, caution must be exercised in drawing any conclusions from these statistics due to the low numbers.

(4) The Government does not impose any requirements on airlines when purchasing aircraft. It is a commercial matter for airlines. However, the design and manufacture of transport category aircraft, components and fittings must comply with internationally agreed safety benchmarks.

Many improvements in standards to enhance occupant survivability in commercial aircraft have been introduced over the last 20 years. Such improvements are usually applied to aircraft designed after the change. However, in safety critical circumstances, these improvements can be applied retrospectively to existing aircraft in services, where an accident or incident has revealed a critical problem.

Such retrospective action was taken to replace all passenger seat cushions to meet higher flammability standards. In 1986, the US Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) issued a requirement for all passenger seat cushions in Air Carrier aircraft to be replaced with cushions meeting a higher flammability standard. This was determined to provide improved survivability from post crash cabin fire. An equivalent requirement was subsequently imposed on Australian Aircraft in Airworthiness Directive (AD) AD/GENERAL/63.

Similar retrospective action was also taken to increase access to over-wing exits. The UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) introduced increased access to over-wing exits in 1989 (UK Airworthiness Notice No 64). In 1992 the FAA issued both a design standard change (FAR Par 25.813 (c)) and retrospective action (FAR Part 121.310(f)(3)) for improved access to over-wing exits. This is more stringent than the UK CAA Notice (20 inches verses 13 inches) although provision was made for existing aircraft to have access less than 20 inches. The CASA requirement (AD/GENERAL/73 dated 1992) paralleled the FAR 121.310 rule.

(5) Improved structural retention of overhead lockers and their contents is currently under investigation by the FAA. In 1993, a FAA AD was issued to reinforce each overhead locker in all Boeing aircraft types. Subsequently, a parallel AD was issued in Australia (AD/B737/73). Those deficiencies in overhead lockers which have been detected by overseas tests have since been rectified by the manufacturers. CASA is unaware of any overhead lockers which do not meet the current design standards.

(6) Improved standards for testing aircraft seats and restraint systems have resulted in energy absorbing techniques being incorporated into new seat designs. These new designs are being progressively introduced into regular service as airlines purchase new aircraft or re-configure existing aircraft with new seats.

(7) The installation of shoulder harnesses in passenger seats would significantly alter load paths and require a major redesign of both seats and aircraft floor attachment. This would involve revision of the international design standard: a matter which needs to be addressed at an international level. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is unaware of any further action being taken in this area at the international level.

(8) The new seat design standard requires the new seat designs to remain attached to the floor structure in existing aircraft while providing protection from a very severe but survivable accident. The new seat design standards for Transport category aircraft were implemented through Federal Aviation Regulation (FAR) 25 amendment 64 on 17 May 1988.

(9) Energy absorbing performance for under floor structures in large transport aircraft is currently under investigation by the FAA. It is important to note that the US Army developments, referred to in the article, relate to crash protection in small, fixed wing aircraft and helicopters. These factors are being addressed in the design standards for these categories of civil aircraft.

(10) It is important to note that the US Army developments in relation to automatic shut-off fuel flow, referred to in the article, relate to crash protection in small fixed wing aircraft and helicopters only. These factors are being addressed in the design standards for these categories of civil aircraft. CASA is unaware of any action being taken in the international arena to address this issue for larger transport aircraft.

(11) Aviation safety is an international issue and it is important that the CASA maintains an influence in improving aircraft occupant protection. The above mentioned issues, together with others relevant to occupant safety, specifically in transport category aircraft and their operation, will be considered at the International Fire and Cabin Safety Conference to be held in the USA in October 2001. The US FAA, European Joint Aviation Authority, Transport Canada, Japanese Civil Aviation Board and CASA are joint sponsors of the conference.
